review: MH World is one of the most revolutionized in the series for newcomers and veterans alike. Interactable Enviroment Using Scoutflies to Locate Monsters A Small Crossbows on your left arm ( Slinger ) and Various Types of Mantle that provides different traits are all welcoming additions. Monsters can provide you some challenge but if done correctly is really walk in the park but can be fun too. Graphic/Visual have never looks this good in any other MH Titles. Most Importantly bring your friends along. It makes it 10x more fun as Monster Hunter is always known to hunt with your pals. The only downside of MH World is there no G Rank theres only Low &amp High Rank and what comes close to G Rank is Tempered &amp Arch Tempered Monsters. Theres nothing really looking forward to for Veterans that previously played the older MH Titles. A G Rank Expansion ( Iceborne ) is coming this year Autumn YEAH!!! Overall MH World truly delivers it to the old familiarity and newly crafted experience to the latest gen. Really Recommended to pick this game even if its full price.

However because I played it solo/with random players I picked it back up on PC to play with friends who also just picked this game up for the first time during the winter sale. And it's been so much more fun than ever before! The game still has some issues with connectivity from time to time and the fact that you cannot join friends in assigned quests until everyone has viewed the cutscene in their own quest is completely unnecessary and takes away from the flow of the game but besides that? This is definitely a fun experience to sink a lot of hours into with a group of friends!Just be aware that there is a lot to take in as a new player and it can be easy to feel discouraged to try out the different weapons offered and all of the features in the game so take your time with it!

review: Monster Hunter is a game that truly perfects its own gameplay loop. You engage in fun hunts for materials to engage in other fun hunts. What makes the hunts fun is that the monsters are not entirely predictable and while they have their own patterns to master they vary them enough to be reptetitive. While there is a lack of weapon variety and the roster is smaller than in other games the game should satisfy anyone looking for a deep gameplay system tied around a satisfying loop... unless you are trying to farm materials like the gems then you sometimes feel like you are going on more hunts than needed.

review: MONSTER HUNTER WORLD a 60 dollar game without any microtransactions.thanks!despite playing the beta on PS4 a long long time ago and having an aneurysm while trying to solo nergigante i've always had this game in my crosshairs and only a few weeks ago decided to make the purchase.suffice to say i don't regret it at all!my experience with the game so far in a nutshell i've played most of the game solo in order to get a hold of the steep learning curve (given i've never played a monster hunter game before). while i do get the occasional network error aka the classic mw1 it is in no way intrusive to my current experiences and i feel it is more of a result of unnecessary network traffic since it always happens in the hub area. while it does get annoying every now and then when i want to kick back and enjoy slaughtering a giant beast with some pals the solutions aren't time consuming or in depth. all i have to do is back out to the main menu and re enter. (EDIT now that the game is all patched up i rarely get an MW1 error and when i do it's usually a fault on my end)i won't deny that there are likely a lot of people who get screwed hard by network issues but so far everything for me and my friend has went smoothly. the game is optimized pretty well for how it looks with some astonishing views and unique beastly designs for monsters. while i would complain that some textures do look fairly low res in comparison to others it is in no way breaking my immersion and instead serves as a small annoyance instead of an eyesore. the sound design in this game is phenomenal with some monsters sounding downright terrifying and their impacts sounding as if they shatter the earth beneath them. i really like how they pulled off just about everything in this game everything flows together very smoothly in my opinion.i've heard of a potential bug which may or may not affect me in the future regarding xeno jiiva but i'm fairly certain the problem is well under my control given that i've made sure to play it careful and backup my save regularly (as i'd also advise you to do just in case!)the only thing i've found to really agitate me about this game is the occasional wonky hit registration (looking at you nergigante) which results in either unnecessary damage or worse an unnecessary faint which ends up leading to an unnecessary quest failure. while these are a thorn in my side i still find that they are fairly few and far between but it'd still help a ton to add some polish to these.of course do play this with a controller! it makes things a lot more compact and easy to understand. (EDIT nergigante's kryptonite is diving using a greatsword makes this much easier to do with its sheathe time)this game is wonderful and i've had a blast playing it despite being new to the series whether it's admiring the view taking on the towering ferocious beasts that roam the new world or just having fun tinkering with armor for optimal fashion. i've binged this game for a while with the only thing breaking that streak being my friends wanting me to party up with them to enjoy another title together. make it a goal to at least give this a try!

review: Love it or hate it's Monster Hunter...
title: MONSTER HUNTER: WORLD

review: TL DR Game Score 7.5/10Pros *Appeals to both Western and Japanese game preferences*Engaging Hunts*Environment feels alive*Combat is pretty satisfying*Overall pretty god damn funCons *Story is not the main appeal*Weird multiplayer design*Not the good kind of grindy*Lack of variety Monster Hunter World is an awesome game and a great step forward to unite the Japanese and Western preferences when it comes to videogames into an enjoyable experience for both sides. Capcom took the risk and put great effort in creating an outstanding amalgam of both.It may still feel a little bit weird for us here in the west but it is accesible enough to provide a great gaming experience where we don't feel too alienated. Most of the battles are great and challenging for those who are learning and interesting enough to keep those who have mastered the game engaged even after the 10th or 100th time hunting the same monster (except Zorah Magadaros and Xeno'Jiva). The combat is unique for every weapon and even though you can use every one of them once you find your main and use that weapon in combat you'll feel true power when going out in hunts.The world itself feels alive with its small fauna populating the scenarios its passive inhabitants becoming part of the chain food in front of your eyes its monsters that show how they've adapted to their environment and the turf wars that trigger when monsters engage in battle over a territory. Even after all that the game is not without its issues. The story is regular at best and not the main focus of the game the multiplayer aspect is a little bit weird with a lot of limitations apparently dragged over from the previous games' design and while grinding is one of the things that makes the game interesting the decorations and augmentations system makes you feel like the grinding is really unfair. Finally the game lacks a lot of variety in its weapon and monster designs.I would definitely recommend this game especially to people new to the franchise but I'm aware that some of its flaws definitely need to be adressed in future updates or in the next installment. 7.5/10.

title: MONSTER HUNTER: WORLD

review: The good The core gameplay loop of killing monsters and making them into armor and weapons so that you can kill more monsters is absolutely fantastic. A huge variety of weapons that have very differnent playstyles. Tons of awesome armor. Cool monster deisgns with satisfying boss fights. The open world areas are really cool. Very high skill ceiling that is satisfying to improve. Really deep builds/customization. A lot of fun in multiplayer.The bad The interface is a complete trainwreck. The multiplayer system is needlessly difficult to use and actively discourages co op with randoms due to a single person being able to cause a complete mission failure. Multiplayer health monster scaling is bad (same health for 2 players or 4 players). A certain monster has hundreds of potential weapons another (much cooler one) has only a single weapon. The endgame RNG grind for decorations and augments has insultingly low drop rates to keep you farming. Visual variety on weapons is pretty poor. A lot of monsters are basically reskins of existing monsters with low monster count overall. Tons of pointless busywork in menus and farming/crafting items between hunts. Limited time event quests can be frustrating to grind out while they are active.Summary Easily the best Monster Hunter. If the Monster Hunter series seems interesting this is the one to jump in on. They have stripped out a ton of the cruft from previous titles but a lot still remains. Overall a great but heavily flawed game.

review: Safe to say MHW has turned into one of my all time favorite games.I'm generally not someone who REALLY gets into any kind of game. I usually play about 100 hours max and then just peace out (I do have some exceptions but you get the idea). I first played this game on PS4 around february ish thought it was decently fun but just kinda left it after I hit Pink Rathian. It initially struck me as fun but kinda tedious and a huge time commitment. Especially since I didn't have any friends who had a PS4 and this game. Then August rolled around and I decided to jump back in. I kinda had all the same feelings as earlier because I couldn't really get any of my friends to play it and trying to figure out the complicated game mechanics by myself was confusing for me. But after a few weeks I finally managed to get a Dark Souls buddy of mine to get it and start playing it with me. And holy canoli I instantly realized why there's such a huge following for this game. I actually ended up getting to the end game and I'm still somehow playing. It's hooked me like no other game has.It's kind of hard to explain how much better this game is with friends or just in co op. And yes this is a co op game at heart. But suffice it to say the combat is really satisfying the monsters are super cool the maps are beautiful there's a stupid amount of depth there's constant updates and I'm gonna be playing it for a long time to come. Although be warned how you go about playing co op doesn't make a whole lot of sense. It doesn't let you invite a friend to a main mission unless you both have watched to cutscene in said mission. So playing through the story together can be a little difficult. The only real negative thing I have to say is that the optimization for the game is not the best and a couple of the monsters are really broken difficulty wise (Vaal Hazak and Behemoth). But other than that it's freaking amazing.

If you're going to actually say something make sure its actually true. Or this will result in negative reviews. Remember the abomination of a port at launch with connection issues graphical issues. and the lack of commmunication? They promised that the PC port will match the port quality of consoles at launch yet the port was plagued with many issues that this should not have been released. For now this review will be a negative until I see massive changes for the better it will stay negative.Edit 2 Really good and they fixed teh bugs

review: After 12 hours of gameplay I can say that this is a good game but has some major problems.The mouse seems to emulate the way a controller would control the camera. This isn't a huge issue when exploring the map but it can get annoying during a fight when you want to turn the camera fast to see the monster. The only way to turn off motion blur in the game seems to be turning off TAA. Also on Intel CPUs the game uses massive amounts of CPU (80 90%) but on an AMD system its only around 40 50% of CPU usage. The servers are also unstable at least at launch.The gameplay however is extremelly fun and surprisingly difficult at times with a wide variety of weapons to choose from. The soundtrack is fantastic and the game has tons of content in its grind based nature with tons of armor and weapons to collect.I would reccomend the game if you're willing to put up with the issues present. Otherwise wait for a patch or a sale.UPDATE All of the major problems I listed have been fixed. You can now turn off motion blur the game seems to run at a more consistant FPS the mouse controlls are fixed and the servers are no longer unstable. As the game is right now I would suggest buying it even at full price.

review: I have to say playing 150+ hours on console than coming back to this on PC still the same fun experience as a new player to the monster hunting series. Since this released on consoles and most of you will know what a monster hunter world game is heres the summary settings and optimization +/ controls on the keyboard vs. controller..... ehhh takes some time getting used to but there are settings that can swap it to be more optimized for keyboards (EX Radial wheel must be toggled in settings if playing on keyboard)+ graphics are great and the normal settings allow you lower the graphics much more compared to other games which is always a plus when you don't mind decreasing the graphics for performance+Since getting the game during 2018 Christmas season no bugs or issues have stopped me from playing the game (only 1 fatal graphical error after playing for 70+ hours recovered fast) compared to the first days there was probably tons of bugs and chrashes and I am glad I don't have to experience any of it.+ game plays out extremely smoothly (as if it were still the console) //////may depend on specs these last two Multiplayer +/ fun/frustrating always available(depends on players only 3 faints....failures can happen but builds can prevent that)+/ only 4 players may join a quest 16 in total for a player's session (only 1 raid Kulve Taroth 4 teams of 4) multiplayer is a bit annoying due to the need for players to see a cutscene before joining others in STORY related missions (assigned missions) other than that you can join an SOS missions whenever for Investigations/Optional/Special etc. ( I played the entire game up until elder dragons solo but watching others they thought it was tedious)+/ connection errors aren't that common but they may happen when least expected ( so far connection errors occur the most with Kulve Taroth raids of course with up to 16 players in 1 session ...but both console and PC can suffer from this RIP rewards) Content in game +multiple weapons( 14) of choice different playstyles However for some the combat may become bland as there is no leveling only upgrading gear + town resources+/ multiple monsters to hunt (increases with updates of course) give or take 30 large monsters (some are similar)+Collaboration with other games and special events happen often (free updates often)+/ only 4 zones (aware of fifth ice zone update in Fall 2019)+/ Story is straightforward yet also meh which makes sense..the gameplay is much more exciting anyway+/ Grind starts after beating the main boss in "Hard mode"+/ Some armors suck even though they may look cool which slightly is sadMods can answer for customization tbh (limited base customization and armor transmog/layered armor)

review: When I bought this game I had no problems installing and getting the game to run however terrible FPS during cutscenes the audio would be finished about 30 seconds before the video. The game was unplayable. I tried the suggestions others gave to get the FPS up and they did make the game a bit better but nothing big. Overnight they updated the game and after that I was able to run the game perfectly on med graphics. I played the game for a couple days and then today when I turned the game on I now have the exact same problems again regardless of the settings. Great game wonderful graphics when it works multiplayer drops giving you disconnect errors frequently and it's a CPU hog. If they get the multiplayer and FPS issues figured out I'd be hooked.**Edit** I'm now 400+ hours into this game they have taken care of the majority of the problems the disconnect issues are gone the FR seems to be better and I'm playing the game on "high" settings again with none of the issues from before. It's refreshing how they add new events every month to give new content and depending on the price of the DLC I'll pick it up and continue playing this one.

review: This is Capcom's boss grinder finally on PC.The good Brilliant level designThe best animations I have ever seenVery good monster design14 different weapons to learnIncredibly deepAbsurdly (and successfully) ambitiousCo opVery longThe bad Has iframes with no indicator of when they start or endOnly 5 real zones far too small for an endless grinderMenu hellForced craftingThis is a "memorize the attacks" gameSeveral weapon animations are absurdly slowThe controls are convoluted in an attempt to add complexityThe ugly Absurdly low drop rates for many itemsThe game explains nothing correctly you need to google every little thing.You are forced to farm bosses you have already killed long after it stops being funPerformance is much worse than it should beThe game contains a lot of BS (e.g. attacks hit you that clearly missed things you used did not trigger no timers on timed missions Lavasioth)The automatic leaving after a quest CANNOT BE DISABLED and is guaranteed to cost you items at some pointWeapon balance sucks with some weapons having barely any access to severing damage (which is the only way to remove tails which is a necessary part of the game).Thoughts The monsters in this game are incredible. They animate so beautifully that they never look like a collection of polygons and textures they look real. The AI for the monsters is similarly brilliant allowing them to easily find their way across large and complex levels interact with the environment reacti to the presence of other monsters and react to you. You will see monsters eat other monsters hunt in packs protect other monsters destroy parts of the environment and even some friendly interactions if you are well hidden.The areas they inhabit are similarly complex. Monster Hunter World has a surprising amount of verticality to it and a huge number of paths through any one area. Each time you enter an area you will find new paths you missed new tricks you can use new shortcuts to traverse the zone quickly. The level design is so good that you will constantly feel like you are learning about the area and simply travelling through each zone is a rewarding experience.The level design and monster design combine to make each area feel like a small ecosystem complete with plants to collect a food chain monsters that are passive to one another monsters that hunt natural traps and more. This is by far the best aspect of Monster Hunter World.Unfortunately when this game made the jump to PC it was riddled with porting problems. The porting problems originally had the game in a borderline unplayable state which is how the game got so many negative reviews. Fortunately nearly all issues (atrocious mouse controls broken multiplayer and a bug that made all lightning weapons and one zone cause stuttering) are fixed. There are still performance problems though.The performance is sub par. Not only will the game not run as well as you would expect given how it looks but there are straight up performance bugs.Even once you get past the performance problems though this is a far from perfect game. This Capcom team is seemingly incapable of doing basic things right. The controls are a sloppy mess the menu screens are infinite and disastrous timed missions bizarrely do not display a timer loads of gameplay mechanics exist simply to be annoying nothing in the game is well explained and enormous gameplay mechanics are never mentioned at all. Many small things that you have taken for granted in every other game you have ever played (how does someone even make options menus this convoluted?) will be botched in this game. It seems like all the care was put into the monsters and environments while everything else was designed by a janitor on loads of acid.The problems are not enough to ruin the fun though. Now that Capcom has finally fixed this port up enough that it is actually a functioning PC game it is a good purchase. Seeing the quality of the majority of the game really does make the bugs and bizzarely bad parts stick out though.The verdict This game is very good finally feels like a PC title and is worth buying as long as you can stomach the terrible drop rates and frequent BS.
title: MONSTER HUNTER: WORLD

title: MONSTER HUNTER: WORLD

review: I've been playing Monster Hunter games since their slow trickle to the western market and I've been following the series ever since. TLDR for anyone that has never played Monster Hunter before (or any game like it such as Dauntless Toukiden God Eater and the like.) I strongly recommend the game. try it out and I seriously doubt you'd be dissapointed. the game is gorgeous it feels wonderful and for those that are familiar with the MH series you should definitely give it a shot if you haven't already. Coming from a MH background I am familiar with the game's mechanics and nuances and Monster Hunter World has made SO many Quality of Life changes that it is mind boggling. While I will say that many of these QoL changes have likely been done to make it easier for newcomers to the series I still feel they are very welcome and it has streamlined much of the clunky and time consuming aspects that many of us veterans would be used to. Gameplay wise and at its core it has still captured what makes Monster Hunter at it's core SO much fun and that is that the monsters themselves. While likely seen as bosses to other games or those unfamiliar with the series they have still made all the monsters feel. alive and not exactly enemies for the sake of being enemies. They are all part of an ecosystem something akin to Jurassic Park with some anime thrown in. Each weapon type are all simple to learn hard to master. And the more time you spend playing the game the more you not only learn about the monsters you hunt but you become overall a better hunter and a master of your chosen weapon. If you use nothing but a specific weapon for an extended period of time then switch to something else it almost feels like a completely different game. Since each weapon has its own play style strengths and weaknesses. The best part of it all? ALL weapons are 100% viable to play through the whole game solo. Capcom have had a very long time ironing out all of the weapons over the years and I feel that the iteration of them all in MHW is one of the best 'version' of each weapon yet. They all feel great to use and a lot of fun.Graphically speaking the game is rather gorgeous. I wouldn't say it is the most optimised PC port to date but for the most part it is pretty solid. Still think there could be some more improvements to make the game smoother (and stop tanking frames at certain points/situations) but I've never had it to a point where the game became unplayable especially in such an action orientated title. Content wise I feel the game is pretty good. There is plenty to do farm acquire and obtain in your adventures and on its own I feel there is a good amount of content here. For Monster Hunter veterans however I feel you may be a bit... disappointed in the overall content. For those unfamiliar with monster hunter... this is what the game has and doesn t have in a nutshell Low rank monsters (yes) introduces most of the monsters. You could say low rank is the tutorial for the most partHigh rank monsters (yes) this is where the majority of the games content is for the most part. You'll be fighting HR monsters for most of your playtime farming their materials making armor upgrading weapons etc. G rank (no...?) okay for those that don't know what G rank is this is basically the endgame of Monster Hunter. Here. The monsters are stronger than ever. They will even have expanded move sets. Completely new armor sets to obtain. New weapons/upgrades to get. Having said that. MHW sort of...? has its own version of it but for the most part... I think it sucks. In MHW you get Tempered monsters. And at the end of the day the only real difference between HR and Tempered is that the Tempered monsters hit harder and are more likely to drop decorations that you use to help give you a little/major edge when customising your armor and skillsets. There is going to be Arch Tempered coming soon for those that have only been following the PC release of MHW since consoles already have it but really again. ONLY the Eldar Dragons have been Arch Tempered they DO give a new armor set with some variations to the skills they provide outside of that there are MINOR visual differences and thats it. SOME of them have new moves (and really I think its Teostra and thats it) but outside of that... they just hit harder again.... and that s it... its the laziest form of G rank I feel they could have done here.... and I feel they have seriously dropped the ball here....in the other Monster Hunter games. G rank was a step up again... new armor sets with completely new visuals... aka Low/High rank Rathalos armor looks different to G rank Rathalos etc and generally its not just some minor detail some armor sets are completely different to their normal counterparts which was SO cool imo.Not only that but the other Monster hunter titles have so many more monsters in its roster...MHW has 31 monsters in its roster... which isnt bad considering the MAJOR change that MHW is in comparison to the older titles in the series... but just for comparison...lets say monster hunter 4 as a comparison. Not ultimate... just the base game75I'm so annoyed that many new players won't see the glory that is the Nerscylla or the Gore Magala. Zinogre or Nargacuga. Gammoth or Rajang... there are SO many more monsters out there and some of them are SO cool/badass that I wish were in the game. now I understand that MHW is the first step in a new line of games so for what they have done. It has been a phenomenal job. But I am seriously hoping for new additions either as DLC or something as time goes on. But you can see where my dissapointment lies in terms of content. Especially coming from other MH titles. One thing that the PC version does have going for it though.... is mods... I've come from a gamming community where mods have done nothing but improve the current game.... mods from games like Dawn of War Fallout. Oblivion... etc mods have made some utterly AMAZING content that I feel once those incredibly dedicated and talented people get the hang of it... there is SO much potential for the monster hunter modding community. In time... we could have something truly glorious here. All in all Monster Hunter World is a fantastic game. Even if it is missing some of the content that people that have followed the series are familiar with. In time I feel this could really be an amazing new direction the series is going. Its first steps have been incredibly impressive so far... now to see where it goes...
title: MONSTER HUNTER: WORLD

review: Fantastic game. I hesitated to buy it for such a high price even though it was on sale for around $50 Canadian when I bought it but it was worth every penny and I can safely say I'd justify the price to a friend. The hunts are varied and entertaining there are plenty of optional missions and side quests for us completionists out there and you can collect fish and tiny critters for your room which is the cutest. There are a lot of different weapons and each of them feels unique and fun to play.That said the game DOES have it's flaws the servers can give out for no reason sometimes and it'll kick everyone from a hunt with no way of returning from it. It's relatively rare in my personal experience but worth mentioning. The graphics sometimes like to take a minute to fully register for me so I have to endure a bit of blur at the start of some hunts. It doesn't last more than 20 seconds from what I've noticed.

review: This game got a lot of negative reviews at launch due to connection issues but all of that was quickly fixed and this deserves a way better rating.If you're familiar with Monster Hunter then you'll quickly notice all the improvements made (open areas fluid movement simplified armor skills etc.) but this might also be the most accessible Monster Hunter for new players.Other than a list of minor gripes my main issue with the game is the lack of incentive to play with groups. Outside of one or two examples solo play is almost always easier and often faster for grinding. I envy people with friends that play MH because it's difficult to even find effective groups for this reason.

review: Would not recommend this game right now. While it is fun performance is unacceptable for a full priced AAA game. Despite being very demanding on hardware the game has no fidelity to show for it (antialiasing is very inconsistent and many textures are very low res despite being at max setting). Multiplayer is an abysmal experience as well constantly disconnecting with disrupting pop ups that will kill you in game. As of writing I cannot even find an online session only errors. Mouse controls also feel grotesque lacking raw mouse input. This game is not worth the price tag until they fix all these issues.Edit (10/09/18) Connectivity issues have been mostly resolved and while there has been some optimizations in terms of performance there is still a lot of room for improvements. Without the blatant connectivity issues I can at least recommend this game.

review: I'm a major Monster hunter fan. I Played every single one of them even the region locked ones and this game is wonderful. Best Monster Hunter yet but there are a lot of things that i dislike about this one. If you wanna do a quest that involve a monster that you didn't see yet you must see the video related to the monster first or else nobody can join your quest. If you play with a friend that is at the same progression than you you must both go in different quest to see the video on your own then one of you quit and join the other one's quest. Also i know that this game is a port but i feel like we did wait a year for them to release it on pc but yet it feel like a console game i don't see any improvement made for PC. The game had the same issues than the console versions right at the start and it took them weeks to fix a couple. This is also the first Mh that i don't have clocked 300 hours on it unfortunatly and im pretty much done with it waiting for the expension to release.. I would like to see more maps added to it because there are only a few and some of them are not my cup of tea

review: monster hunter veteran? this game is definitely worth the pick up and if you're patient enough for the updates you wont be putting this game back down soonnew to monster hunter? a lot of the negative reviews you see (especially those posted back in august) have already been fixed. this is NOT a hack n slash game. if you're used to playing bayonetta nier automata or devil may cry do not apply it in mhw. you will end up dying a lot story? what story? (joking aside monster hunter does have a story but you wont be paying attention to that any time soon) grinding the game in general isn't grindy if you wont be dying a lot when you transition from low rank to high rank and when making end game equipment. farming for decorations is the only grinding youll be doing 24/7 cheating there is no anti cheat system in monster hunter. if you wanna cheat the game its up to you. but dont expect regular players to treat you lightly if they catch you cheating during a multiplayer session. just keep it to yourself there are players who want to play the game as it is. extra payables all the extra dlcs are cosmetics. emotes chat stickers and costumes for your handler. "but how about the Fair Wind Charm? it gives bonuses!" it does but youll be replacing that item and forget it even exists after a few hours of gameplay. multiplayer i HIGHLY recommend bringing along friends in this game. it does get very frustrating when you do your best but lose anyway and lose your resources because some random guy answered your SOS call and dies 3 times in a row. no friends? hate playing with people anyway? no worries the game actually amps the difficulty depending on how many players are joined in the quest. if you're playing alone the difficulty will be as it is. price if you're a bit sketchy about the game waiting for a sale never hurts. but if you play it long enough youll see what you paid for. PC requirements &amp graphics even im surprised on how beefy the requirements are. If you dont mind playing on not max graphics settings then it shouldn't be a problem. but if you're really picky when it comes to graphics there are a handful of negative reviews pointing out the graphics issue of mhw. haven't done my research much so i can't say anything useful either. p.s. Reviews pointing out how there are graphics settings that can't be changed through settings that has been changed now. events missed out on an event? dont worry monster hunter events are always set to repeat in a schedule. there's an official calendar for mhw where events are listed and when some events will repeat. combat system again it is not a hack n slash game if you try to play it as one you will end up like one of those scrubs pointing a negative review towards "how bad" mhw's combat system is. mh's combat has always been its center focus up until now and im very confident when i say its combat system has been smoother than ever. if you think it isn't you're either playing it wrong or it's really just not your preference. mods yes www.nexusmods.com overall I tried my best to review MHW without having to compare it to old monster hunter games (as it would be a pretty biased review and there are enough reviews for veteran players of mh to read and know how the game works.) It's definitely worth the pick up but the game isn't for everyone. There are games that seemingly have this unique aura of being able to garner such a wide and diverse playerbase that everyone pretty much knows the story or how to play the game. Monster hunter is NOT one of those games so it wouldn't be a big surprise that you like the game so much but your friends dont or vice versa. pick it up if you're a fan of monsters you're a fan of hunting monsters you're a fan of swinging impractically large weapons you're a fan of asmr (seriously the sound design of the game is amazing)

review: If you have been looking for an extremely fun satisfying and rewarding game that you can play both co op and solo then this is it. In a world full of huge terrifying beasts it becomes your job as a hunter to take them down. With a array of 14 weapons each with their own unique playstyles there's something here for everyone. If your the type to play tank or heavy hitting dps roles then the lace/gunlance or greatsword is for you. Maybe you're the type who likes to go in do damage and then quickly escape or dodge. In that case the dual blades Insect Glaive or long sword are the right fit for you. Or maybe you're looking for something with a bit of range Monster Hunter World has that coverd with the light/heavy bowguns and the regular bow and arrow. This game is all about taking down these huge monsters and carving their corpses for parts in order to craft better weapons and armor. It's a very simple gameplay loop but it never gets old because the game keeps throwing new and interesting challenges your way.I have thoroughly enjoyed my time with this game. I have had so much fun teaming up with my friends or challenging myself to take on a tough monster solo. And while regular updates can be slow (especially for PC) they still come out often enough to keep me coming back. With a new expansion coming out next year I can guarantee that I will keep coming back to this game for years to come.

I've discovered new play styles even 200+ hours into the game. Each detailed monster fight requires a different approach (if they're near/higher than your gear level at least). The frequent free updates and events are also really nice. A bit of a time investment with the grinding playstyle but a really fun game.

review: This game is my game of the year for 2018 if not for the last five years or so. I have 300+ hours played on PS4 and not much on PC (I couldn't wait for the PC release so bought a PS4 specifically for this game). This is the game we have all been waiting for after playing Monster Hunter 2 on PS2 which I rented from a DVD store back years and years ago I have always wanted Capcom to deliver a fully fledged HD Monster Hunter and boy did they ever. After years and years of mixed quality portable games for PSP/Nintendo 3DS and not listening to the Western audience Capcom went full HAM on this game and produced a masterpiece. The core gameplay is the same yet every single aspect of the game has improved. The ammount of simple quality of life improvements in this from previous Monster Hunter titles was perfect and welcomed a huge influx of new Western players. I am so happy for the success that Capcom has recieved from this game and am excited for the expansions coming in 2019. I hope they keep adding and expanding on this wonderfly beatifully made game. Give this a go you won't regret it (they plan to release a free trial versions soon so keep your eyes peeled). &lt 3 &lt 3 &lt 3

review: Played on a PC consisting of the following Windows 10 Pro 64 BitRyzen 7 2700X16 GB of RAMEVGA 1080 TIAOC AGON 241QX MonitorNotes No Overclocking on Processor or GPU. Played the PS4 Version before playing this version. Started with MH3 preferred 4 Ultimate before this one (Underwater Combat was great on paper but terrible in practice).TLDR The game I play when I wake up in the morning and think "I want to feel like a dude wearing the remains of a giant monster that failed to tear my face off."Monster Hunter World is the initial installment of the 5th Generation of the Mainline Series of Monter Hunter games. More important it is the first Mainline installment that has been on what Capcom has described as more powerful hardware compared to the handheld installments which previous games have been on.Building on the slightly more story focused Monster Hunter 4/ 4 Ultimate World has a more considerable focus on a main story to give players a reason as to why they're out hunting these large monsters that roam the land. This time you're a Hunter who is part of the Fifth Fleet of the Research Commission sent out to aid them in their investigation of a phenomenon known as the Elder Crossing. One thing leads to another and you find yourself hunting large monsters with your choice of 14 weapons alongside your Palico companion. Don't expect a story on par with Shakespeare or Tolkien but it still serves as a decent reason as to why you're out in the middle of a new continent trying to kill a lightning unicorn so you can turn what's left of it into a tube top and a loincloth before you turn it's horn into a sword.Gameplay is along the lines of an Action RPG where you roam around hunting monsters collecting items and exploring areas. You have a choice of 14 weapons to choose from with a wide variety of moves and abilities along with a wide selection of armor. While the most basic of both weapons and armor can be bought in the game the majority of your equipment will come from the items collected from the areas you explore and the monsters you hunt. The quests that pit you against large monsters around the continent follow a straightforward difficulty curve with a few monsters and quests spread throughout that serve as potential barriers to test everything you learned up to that point and your equipment that you have forged throughout the game. It is important to mention that this game can be quite grindy for those who have never played any other Monster Hunter game. There will be points where you may find yourself hunting the same monster multiple times in a row in order to collect items to forge armor and/or weapons.Multiplayer is much different from previous installments no longer is there a divide between single player and multiplayer quests. Additionally a Drop In/Drop Out system has been implemented in the form of the SOS Flares which players can launch in order to call for help from up to 3 other players. Important to note that in quests this comes at the cost of dividing the Zenny from a quest reward by the number of players who arrive to help. However launching an SOS Flare can be a risky endeavor at times due to the fact that all players in a quest share the same pool of limited continues after fainting and there's no way to determine the skill of a player who responds to your flare. So there may be times where you are fighting a powerful monster and launch the flare for help only to have a woefully unprepared hunter arrive and burn through your continues as they immediately faint against the monster time and time again.My main gripe about this is that it does takes away from the Gathering Hall in the Hub Area rendering it a ghost town unless you bring friends or arrive during particular in game events and makes the game feel a bit less social than other installments. Still I do approve of removing the divide between Single Player and Multiplayer Quests and simply adjusting the difficulty based on the players present so it doesn't bar the late and post game content from players who don't feel like being forced to play with other players all the time or latecomers who arrive after the playerbase is mostly gone.Visuals are rather stunning ranging from the landscape to the monsters themselves. This serves as one of the most obvious improvements after transitioning away from handheld systems. Based on the parts and monitor that I mentioned earlier the game runs at a stable 60 FPS and 1440P with no visible issues. For those coming from previous Monster Hunter titles some of the weapon designs do leave a bit to be desired seeing as how they look like the base weapons with some parts from a monster added to it. However armor designs are still just as good as previous titles with a wide variety of appearances.The music from a personal perspective is absolutely amazing with the various pieces properly fitting their locales and situations.The voices sound relatively good and don't have too many instances of overacting with the English VA. For those who want to seem as if they're in another world or just to preserve the dialogue experience from the previous games there is an option to have the characters speak in Monster Hunter Language which sounds good as well. Regardless of your language choice the lip syncing leaves a lot to be desired though.Overall I do recommend this game to anyone who wants to play a relatively straightforward Action RPG where you hunt large monsters in various locales either by yourself or 3 other people. Especially if you don't mind grinding for items or a loop of fighting monsters to get stronger equipment to fight stronger monsters. The story that follows your hunter isn't going to be an epic tale but for what it's worth it isn't bad. Regarding music as of the date that this review was posted the Soundtrack is on sale. If you haven't bought it already you should consider buying it now. It's really that good.
title: MONSTER HUNTER: WORLD

review: This game's a great investment if you're into third person melee brawlers or the Monster Hunter series.It's also a great starting point if you're curious about the series.It's endlessly streamlined removed things like stopping to drink and eat the loading times between areas and balanced some weapons around so you can beat anything using nearly any weapon.It looks great has a ton of visual options and is overall a great port.You may experience some issues with connection but these were rare for me and definitly not deal breakers.The game gets updated frequently with new content and crossovers although a couple months after the content hits consoles. It's also getting an expansion DLC next year and if you're unaware with how MH does expansions expect a whole new complete campaign new monsters and a new hunter level cap.Overall this is a great game worth the money wether on or off sale and you're garanteed one or two hundred hours of content at the very least.

review: Don't understand why the reviews are so mixed. The game is really great. Yes there are connection issues right now. But I'm sure Capcom didn't foresee MHW selling like crazy on PC and the servers buckled under big player counts. They'll get that fixed up though within a week. The PC port isn't the BEST port but it still runs absolutely fine on my mid range PC while still looking great. Again they'll probably update and polish the game some more in the future with updates. So don't let the mixed reviews steer you away. For a AAA game it is a surprisingly deep and complex game with tons of mechanics and variety. There are so many different beasts to hunt armor to forge and collect and weapons to try out. It's a fun grind to get into and a satisfying gameplay loop.

review: Monster Hunter World is a very fun game and has a wide variety of different experiences. There are 14 different weapon types and each one has its in's and out's. Using each one has almost a completely different playstyle so you should be able to find something for you. You unfortunately have to grind out the story by yourself and can only do the optional or event hunts with your friends online. The Armor and weapons in this game are amazing to see and the feeling of accomplishment for grinding to finish an armor set is really nice. Overall I highly reccomend this game as it has instantly become one of my favorite games.

review: The game is a lot of fun even if it is pretty grindy. Don't play it with big picture on the steam hud is horrible for that. Networking worked fine for me for the most part rarely have I not connected to someone elses game. All in all it's a good game with tons of hours of play story mode isn't too long i completed it in about 20 hours or so. There's a lot more quests and optional stuff to do as well as weekly events and all the content updates are free. The only thing you have to pay for is dances and costumes for the handler. All in game costumes for your character are free. They added a bunch of monsters for free since it came out Deviljho Kulve Taroth Lunastra and Behemoth. It's more fun coop.
title: MONSTER HUNTER: WORLD

review: The game as a single player experience is pretty solid. However the big draw for most people is playing with friends. The constant drops from online play can be pretty frustrating for multiplayer. Even in sigle player you can get pop ups when disconnected that can cause you to ruin a hunt. The performance of the game is not where it should be but if you have a good system you shouldn't have any problems keeping it above 60fps with a few tweaks. There is also currently a bug where the textures are not loading in to the highest resolution which can make the game look less then stellar. Monster hunter world has the underlyings of a good game but the execution leaves a lot to be desired. It doesn't help when Capcom is silent about most of the problems. If you just want to play single player I could probably recommend the game to you. If you intend to play with others I would wait to see if they at least fix the multiplayer first. Single player the game is about a 7 or 8 but multiplayer is about a 4 or 5. If we see a good patch soon the game could be a solid 8 across the board but right now I would wait and see.EDIT Most if not all of the issues that were present at launch have been fixed up. Since then I have put well over 100 hours into the game. I find the grind for decorations a bit extream but overall the game is a very enjoyable experience. Since the multiplayer issus have been fixed the game has become my goto game. I wish they would clearly state that visual mods are 100% ok but I can understand why they dont. I'm looking forward to the expantion later on in 2019. I might just make it to HR 100 by then.

review: Monster Hunter World is easily one of the best gaming experiences I have had this year.The graphics are fantastic the gameplay is frantic yet precise and the controls perfect... for a controller anyway.The graphics customisation options were good when it released and each major patch is adding new options like the ability remove depth of field or motion blur and many others. The control customisation also gets additions every patch which makes the keyboard and mouse controls less clunky as they are able to be tweaked in many indipendant situations.While the game was plagued with a miriad of connection issues at launch these seem to have been completely eliminated for me. Any issues that most people get are during connection to multiplayer quests which gives an unhelpful error is when the game is full and they joined too late.The only real downside is that in order to play with friends through the Assignment quests the "story mode" you will have to watch all cutscenes before your friend can join. If you are in the same online session as your friend this is as simple as joining the quest when they get the message that SOS flares can be used. While clunky it does work.A second downside if you are this way inclined is that many of the weapon models tend to repeat a small number of base models with only minor flairs to let you know they are different. While the weapons were vastly different in earlier Monster Hunter iterations they were able to pretty much carry their work over from one game to another. For this iteration all the models have had to be recrreated from scratch which does explain the lack of variety but some hunters may feel a little let down by this.Overall the experience i have had with Monster Hunter World has been a very pleasant one full of fighting dangerous monsters to turn them into my precious weapons and armour.
title: MONSTER HUNTER: WORLD

review: The game is a LOOP. Once you have kill a monster you have pretty much done everything there is to do. If you focus on the gameplay you can get bored fast as the combat feels slows it's one move after the other and you can go get a tea before your character's done with that strike. However maps and fauna are great it's lush it's vivid and the monsters look cool. The multiplayer system sucks you play with unknown people who never use their mic and only meet them for the time of a mission as most of them drop the team as soon as they are done. It's feels very empty knowing that this is a multiplayer game and no real end goal. Why can't we all be playing on the same servers? I don't get why they just don't do a lobby?! Console games suck. For what I have paid I will insist on the game but so far after the great first impressions and almost 40 hours in I do not see Monster Hunter in my gaming pantheon and I really expected something grandiose. Look I like gameplay and I am not impressed at all by the combat system it's not a hard game it's a GRINDING GAME. Maybe it's just a niche game and it's not my style but I can reckon the efforts put in this game it's still an excellent production.

review: I waited patiently for this game to release for PC and my wait was completely rewarded. When I jump off a cliff I still occassionally get squimish and think "oh crap I'm dead" because of how immersive the environments are. It's stunning graphics. I do play with a controller and recommend using a controller for this game. It's still too difficult to control with a keyboard and mouse imo. Once you figure out a weapon that works for your playstyle and get a handle on the controls it's a blast. It's always a thrill to be fighting the pink T rex and to get blindsided by the big Iguana. The first time that happened I laughed so hard. You never know what's going to happen on your hunts. It's a different experience each time and depending on if you play solo or with other players it also affects your gameplay. It's really fun to jump into someone else's game to respond to their SOS and help them beat that really tough lightning unicorn matchup or just collect shrooms. Very versatile. Events are awesome too. If you are on the fence with this one know that it's the first time I've paid full price for a game in like 10 years and I don't have buyers remorse in the least.

review: Now my stance on MHW is mixed really but I'm giving a positive rating because I did genuinely have fun despite the several quirks I have about this game which ultimately led to my overall disappointment.Before I start however I must mention that MHW has a absoutely mediocre story and bland characters. THIS IS HOW NOT TO EXECUTE A STORY. It's a shame because the animators are clearly talented yet are restricted by poor writing.For the main bulk of the game hunting the boss monsters are well executed and satisfying bringing in tons of interesting mechanics such as tracking breaking limbs tail dismemberment mounting turf wars monster habitat behaviour not to mention the wide variety of builds and weapons to choose from. Honestly I found this overall to have a steeper learning curve than the Dark Souls series.Unfortunately the difficulty can feel very artificial and straight up unfair on many occasions especially once you traverse into the late to end game where monsters are able to effectively to stunlock you through combos most annoyingly through Roars and Ground Tremors. This gets even worse on Special Assignments where they have blindingly fast attack speed (Behemoth) unavoidable stuns (Lunastra) or overly large hitboxes (Deviljho). This game is not intended to be fair you will very often face unfair monster design and must empIoy appropriate strategies in return. I did not feel any remorse using cheesing strategies such as kiting monsters to force Turf Wars or using the Bow to get easy hits. Think about this point carefully before you finalise your decision on buying this game.
title: MONSTER HUNTER: WORLD

review: I feel like Capcom has done a OK job at adressing the problems of MHW there is still some disconnect but not even close to the problems that i had when first playing the game on release. Super fun game!
title: MONSTER HUNTER: WORLD

review: Short version You hunt monsters (like you couldn't tell from name of this game). You can play this as solo or with friends you decide. Some battles can be showy. Good graphics need better PC than minecraft PC.Long version Release was awful servers were so bad that only thing you saw was "Error 50382 MW1" which you still might see but not that often. After 200h I can say that yes this is worthy game......tho the first 100h was me trying to get online without success when this game was released so basically after 100h. Anyways I were new to Monster Hunter series until now. Graphics are nice only thing bothering me is horrible lip sync but good cutscenes will make up for it. I was expecting clunky controls but they are actually really good with controller. I used to play with mouse and keyboard but noticed how much easier it was for me to play with controller.Main quests are usually tracking monster then killing or capturing it. There are other quests too which are easier like gathering stuff and hunting mosquitos etc.You can hunt some monsters in arenas which is easier when they can't leave or which position.Loot system is random(ish). For example you need a tail from certain monster. You get it if you manage to cut it off on the fight but if you need like a hide from certain monster there is about 30% chance to get it since you can get other body parts aswell. Only thing which I like the most is that every hunt last from 10 to 20 minutes. This game is really time consuming. I usually go with this saying that "When game offers you 1h/1 game time it's a good game. This is a good game which had horrible launch......but all good now.
title: MONSTER HUNTER: WORLD

review: Very addicting game. Playing the franchise since day one. Only downside on the PC version is the lack of content. Ca$com holds back updates and gives them to consoles first. If we get the update eventualy then they adjust the loottable so you are forced to grind the event next time again only to farm the stuff you really wanted.Apart from that the game is pretty solid lots of grinding (it's MH duh!). No toxic MP.Hope to see better updates cycles for new content in the future.
title: MONSTER HUNTER: WORLD

review: This game is awesome and I'm having a lot of fun despite its flaws.I wish I could recommend it but the online has been completely broken since launch and its just getting sad at this point. Constant disconnects I rarely can complete a single mission without getting dropped. Even single player gets interrupted with error messages. This wouldn't always be a dealbreaker in some games but multiplayer is EVERYWHERE it even makes you change/start a server just to play single player. There's no excuse for it to work so poorly if you're going to push it this hard. I expect better performance in a game where MP is just an afterthought.Capcom fix your and I'll thumbs up with pleasure otherwise I'm going to keep telling people to stay away.Alright seems like it works okay now. Still leaving my rant because it sucked during the 40 hours I played it broken.
title: MONSTER HUNTER: WORLD

review: Be patient. If something seems you are likely doing it wrong. Keep trying to figure it out and it will become easier and more enjoyable. Example Transfering items from your pouch to your item box can seem extremely tedious and dumb until you figure out pressing "E" transfers a whole stack. Greatly reducing the number of clicks required. So as stated it's prolly just you being new. Keep at it.Things to do.Upgrade armor and weapons.Upgrade your Palico's (cat friend) armor and weapons.Capture small pets to let loose in your bedroom.Hunt huge hulking monsters.Get hunted by huge hulking monsters.Hide from huge hulking monsters.Watch huge hulking monsters fight and kill eachother.Creep around where you just watched said fight and pick up scales/feathers/broken bits. Use said broken bits to upgrade your armor and weapons.Have a cat cook food for you.Fly climb jump slide swim.Mine dig up bone piles/corpses tear down spider webs.Shoot small animals out of the sky.Fight bugs.Collect bugs.Drop a variety of traps that have a variety of effects.Try to hide from a giant T Rex lookin thing only to have it sniff you out and destroy your hiding place to murder you and your grandchildren.Much Much More. I only just started and I love it.On a more realistic note. It's mostly open world there are obvious boundries and you can only climb things you are allowed to climb. The map is layered. So the map is actually 3 7 times bigger than when it initially looks like.The "monsters" interact with one another chasing fighting killing. You often get caught up in the carnage.You can track all the monsters on the map so your job is to keep an eye on the big bad bosses while roaming around completing your missions. These eventually result in you fighting the big baddies which are long fun painful fights.A typical boss fight will take you 10 15 minutes as a two person team.You can team up with friends it's complicated but when you figure out how it works it becomes EZ.You can free roam with a friend. Expiditions are endless running about killing/fighting. Bosses respawn mobs respawn all things respawn. It's just a big grind fest (for as long as you want). All this can be complimented by doing optional/bounties that reward you with items/points/money.Or you can progress the story line by doing story related quests.Absolutely recommend this. The only complaint I have is that my PC sucks and I have to play it on potato settings. And the multi played can be a bit challenging for a new players.DON'T GIVE UP! If it seems hard or too complicated you are likely doing it wrong! Me and the wife struggled through the first few hours (having fun) but unsure how it all worked. The early story lines will help you figure out alot of it take your time and READ try all the options it becomes clear eventually.HIGHLY RECOMMENDED.
title: MONSTER HUNTER: WORLD

review: I've been a big fan of the Monster Hunter series ever since "Monster Hunter Freedom Unite" and I'm not disappointed by this game either. To sum the game up you hunt monsters in a fantasy world but unlike other games Monster Hunter tries to build a resonable even if sometimes special ecosystem you really feel like in a living breathing environment. But what are differences to it's predecessors? Well for a start it is the first game of Monster Hunter in which you can play with other hunters from all over the world instead of being restricted to one continent hence the name "MONSTER HUNTER WORLD". Although at first glance it may look like a complete makeover it still feels like any other Monster Hunter game. Of course there are obvious differences such as the new gadgets (mantles slinger) the new quest layout (no more key quests) and of course the voice acting (which can be disabled in the options menu) but there really aren't many changes to the gameplay except maybe the new weapon combos. What I really like about the game is the effort that has been put into the environment to make it not only look realistic but also make it more dynamic with slopes to slide down and natural traps for monsters. The only downsite I can think of is the rather small monster roster instead of numbers up to 98 there now are only 53 monsters in the game because unlike in previous games the developers couldn't just reuse models and animations they had to make everything from scratch. I definitely recommend buying this game even if it seems like a game that gets boring very quickly there are hours upon hours of fun to be had especially if you play with friends ) .
title: MONSTER HUNTER: WORLD

review: Good Different and fun playstyles Can approach each fight many different ways Cool and unique monsters (except ing Lavasioth)Bad A bit grindyOverall it is a very fun game. You can play alone or take on the monsters with up to 4 friends. Best to play with 4 as the monster auto scales up to 4 people when on co op. 8/10

review: I used to play Monster Hunter on my PSP and never got so far. Bought this game with the personal mission of finally getting on the famous late game.Had some issues with the optimization I have a fairly decent PC had no problem running games like Final Fantasy XV but this one gave me some headaches but I turned off some of details on graphics and now it's all smooth now I can't deny it I'm really loving the game. Don't say I recommend it as a whole it requires patience with both the bad optimization and the amount of information the game throws on your face but if you're prepared go ahead. It's surprisingly worth it.

review: Super fun game. I bought it on PS4 originally becaue I couldn't wait then a PC friend bought it for me on here. I have loved it both times and am so excited for the release of G rank. As a long time fan there is one thing in this game that bother me it feels like it holds your hand a little more than in the past which is kind of lame.There are somethings I really love though. Quality of life changes mostly. The farm is really easy and intuitive and gives you more than ever so you can spend more time hunting than gathering. The whetstone actually lasts forever which just makes sense. There are less dumb gather quests and egg transport quests which make the pacing of the game feel more natural. It's an exciting game if you are into bludgeoning monsters until their teeth fall out.

review: December update A lot of work has been poured into this game since release and a lot has improved. I think it can be but right now I can not with good conscience recommend it. The glut of multiplayer errors broken settings poor performance and well lack of content compared to the PS4 version are just not great selling points.One of the worst sticking points for me right now about this game in general is that it still requires every party member to have seen all cutscenes before they can proceed together. This makes trying to co op the story together nearly impossible. It really needs to be addressed.All that said Monster Hunter World is a wonderful great satisfying game. This particular version just needs a lot of work.

review: PUT THE GAME ON AN SSD Starting with Monster Hunter Freedom Unite on the PSP I've always been a fan of Monster Hunter games. Back then I wasn't really able to do much since the game can be pretty tough if you don't know what you're doing (this holds up in Monster Hunter World) but part of the fun I had back then was in the more casual exploration areas of the game seeing big Woolly mammoths (the Popo) running around the first snowwy mountain map trying to learn the layout finding gathering spots so I could actually make items that I needed since the game wasn't going easy on me and my young brain. When it came to actually hunting a monster I had to learn all the specific weaknesses Not just types but about the fact that you can use a sonic bomb on the Cephadrome to make it resurface on my own because back then I didn't know where to look online for useful information.Monster Hunter World takes these things that I loved doing and makes them so much more rewarding. If you've mastered a map or a monster it shows! You can easily find gathering nodes that you're looking for you can easily tell what type of damage is more effective on certain monsters if you want to know if a monster has a tail that's severable so that you know going into the hunt to cut it off the game will give you that information all you have to do is explore the amazingly designed enviroments that the Monster Hunter Dev Team have made.Going from Monster Hunter 3 to Monster Hunter 4 Ultimate was a dificult decision due to the system downgrade (From the Wii U to the 3DS) but overall the quality of the game persisted and the experience of MH4U was phenomenal. So when I was thinking of going from MH4U to Monster Hunter World the choice was a nobrainer because not only was the platform better but the quality that you could see just from trailers and teasers and other promo content for the game was so high I couldn't not pick up a copy on PS4.When I heard that this game was not only going to be on major consoles but it was getting a PC port as well I was blown away. Now fast forward a couple months after the console release to the PC release and the game has some problems. Chiefly among those problems (as of launch) Poor online connectivityPoor co op functionalityPoor optimisationPoor M+KB controlsSince then the Dev Team have ironed out a lot of these issues. Most have been improved others I'm not sure.I personally haven't been dropped from an online lobby in what feels like months This one is still not great story quests afaik still can't be played co op until all members have watched the cutsceneThe game runs quite well for me (60fps on med/high) with a mid range setup (1050ti i7 3770kM+KB controls have been updated and improved although I prefer using a controller for Monster Hunter games so I can't speak for if they've been changed for the betterThis game has received a lot of quality of life updates that fix a lot of peoples initial problems with the game and because of that I can't recommened this game enough it is personally my favourite game of 2018 hands down. TL DR The game has been updated to fix a lot of the problems with the initial negative reviews the recent reviews reflect this accurately.

review: Monster Hunter World is both an entry point in the series for an audience who have only ever heard of the monter slaying slasher and a remake of the formula for an age old series that has fans of both the west and east joining together to explore the new world.As a long time fan of the series I was both excited and cautious of this instillation in the series due to its major change in both platform and gameplay. The open world aspect of each map seemed like both a dream and curse as I explored new rich environments and quickly learnt that the vastness could be my downfall in a fight. Although the new maps and world as a whole are a challenging change in mechanics and strategy the beauty of a small enclosed beach or a view over a vast lush forest can leave you lost for words during a difficult hunt.The veriety in weapons hasn't changed since the last title however the way that weapons are presented has changed considerably. Each weapon being in your box from the start like in every start to a MH Game but the practice area allows for in depth training that can make a world of difference when learning a new weapons style. As this is a new world that also means new monsters which will also lead to a new array of weapon and armor match ups all of which in the later game can be mixed to boost specififc stats and allow you to hunt to your full potential.The multiplayer is also heavily sold for hunts in both the story and in the Gathering hub for more advanced hunters allowing you to team up with friends or just friendly hunters to get through a hunt with ease. This doesn't however limit the solo experience as the difficulty level will increase with every added hunter leaving no solo hunter at a disadvantage to a monster should they choose to go it alone.In conclusion Monster Hunter World is a sensational step forward for the franchise showing advanced graphics on both console and PC and a system that can be sustained through teams or solo artists to achieve the very best results in a hunt. The game is gripping from A Z and although there can be some slow slopes to the story during investigation sections these all link to a greater mission that will prove to be a challenge to any capable hunter.10/10 would put far too much of my free time into this game again.

review: I love this game but I am a long time Monster Hunter fan so my opinion is biased. I've done 100% of available missions on PS4 and on PC for this game and still just have fun going out and killing stuff for the heck of it or to try and make a deadly clownsuit. A few things to consider before you buy The game's difficulty is based around being slow this is not really a fast paced game. It's more about predicting what the monster is going to do and acting accordingly and striking when you have an opening. This game is about grinding a large part of this game is killing the same monsters over and over to get materials to make gear some materials are very rare and may require killing the monster multiple times. This game can be frustrating. Very very frustrating. It's something that you may start off sucking at but you can breeze through monsters once you get the hang of it. Don't be afraid to look up guides and suggestions from other players. Yes the story is awful. It's a tacked on feature that the older games did not really have outside of a few dialogues and "boss" battles. You can't skip cutscenes and it sucks. There might be mods that can fix this but use at your own risk since the game does not support modding. I know that the list may seem like a bunch of negatives but it's honestly a solid super fun game and the most fluid and best starting points for new hunters in the series.
title: MONSTER HUNTER: WORLD

review: Played over 200 hours on PS4. Just started a new character on PC and I can say they did an awesome job porting this game! I did have to change some keybinding to make play more comfortable for mouse and keyboard (see AREKKZ GAMING's control remapping video on YouTube for details). Once I got the controls to my liking this game feels great to play on PC. Graphics are top notch on my big gaming rig and even serviceable when turned to "Low" settings on my laptop. Loading times are much faster than its PS4 counterpart even without using a SSD in my laptop. The story can be hit or miss and the Handler is annoying as F. But Monster Hunter was never praised for its storytelling and this game at least tries to have a cohesive narrative sewn within its boss battle focus on gameplay.Many negative reviews are from people that haven't really given the game's mechanics and vast control options a chance. When Western audiences think of "Action RPGs" they think of Devil May Cry God of War or Diablo. This is a different kind of Action RPG. It's a HUNTING RPG. The focus here is on tracking giant monsters while you gather flora and fauna that will help you in your hunts. Once you locate the beast combat becomes a VERY LONG WINDED dance between you and it. If you have the patience the payoff when a giant monster finally goes down can be exhilarating.
title: MONSTER HUNTER: WORLD

review: Writing my first review for a game ever on steam that's how good this game is. Note the review is probably going to be somewhat all over the place and not very well structured but here it is. This is actually the first game I've played that I'd say is absolutely worth the money (not counting single player games). Amazing environment mechanics monsters and the amount of weapons that you can use. There's always something that you can do in this game be it a day where you want to chill and just go to collect some materials on an expedition (like ores different herbs meat fish pets etc.) or just spend your whole day on investigations optional quests and hunts in general or even helping out other people by responding to SOS flares. Considering all the armour sets and upgrades for the weapons you always have something to strive for. Just changing one of your weapons brings a whole new experience to the game. I especially like the fact that the game doesn't really hold your hand completely through the playthrough. Feels somewhat similar to the Dark Souls series which is a big plus for me. It does teach you the basics and let's you explore the rest of the possibilities in the game (ex. the combos for the weapons shows you the basic ones but not all possible moves the weapon can perform). There are some problems with the game but I wouldn't say they are too major considering all the other AAA title games that are around the same price range as this one and are complete garbage compared to this game. Mentioning this here as I can see there are a lot of negative reviews for somewhat ridiculous issues which can be resolved (and the devs are working on fixing as well from what I can see in the past almost 1 year of updates). Regarding the co op side of the game. It is a bit weird in the beginning but once you figure it our it's not bad at all. At the time of writing this I have only 63 hours played but man they have been the best 63 hours I have spent in a game in a really long time. So I'd say that this game is completely worth checking out and giving it a chance regardless of the mixed reviews that can be seen. Go ahead and buy it and build your own opinion for this game.
title: MONSTER HUNTER: WORLD

review: If you enjoy action games then get this game! Worth it at $60 or more.I like this game so much that I am upgrading my graphics card for it to run better.For me the biggest reason why gamers should buy this is it is the kind of consumer wallet friendly product that developers are moving away from. It doesn't have loot boxes just paid DLC for specific not random cosmetic changes and gestures. The developers keep adding content for free and the expansion that's coming in 2019 isn't going to be sold as an all new game like they had to in the handheld versions.This is not my first monster hunter game experience. I have played some of the PSP and 3DS games but never got that far in any of them. I have reached end game (Arch Tempered Monsters) for two characters in this one. For those that have tried the handheld monster hunters this game includes a variety of Quality of Life (QoL) enhancements that makes prepping for a hunt require less management. The graphics are stunning in comparison as well.You play a hunter joining an expedition into a new continent. NPCs are other hunters researchers and support staff for the expedition. The story is pretty mediocre and not that much happens to the other characters. Your job is to explore gather and hunt. Your tools include a wide variety of close combat and ranged weapons with their own unique move sets a slingshot/grappling hook potions and capes with special abilities. The levels are large multi leveled and full of life. In those levels there are small animals to capture fish to catch plants to gather slingshot ammo to equip environmental traps to trigger environmental hazards to avoid or compensate for shortcuts allies to find rocks to mine bones to pick through ramps to slide down various places you can grappling hook to small monsters you can interact with in a variety of ways and of course the BIG monsters who you have extended fights with often over several sections of the map. Monsters respond to other monsters falling rocks flashes of light fire your blade against their hide and more. They eat they sneeze they sleep they get bored they burrow and they scratch. The monsters you hunt are the most interesting part of the game. Now how does the game make you want to keep hunting them even after you have killed or captured them all several times? Loot. Loot that can be crafted into armors charms and weapons that are extra effective against various monsters.You can call for help from other human players and you can help them in their own quests. It is very fun taking down monsters as a group and I recommend joining other people's quests when you can. I do recommend that you learn how to take monsters on solo especially on your story missions.To do more damage with a weapon you don't spend points you just get better at the game. To dodge attacks more easily you learn the timing. To survive longer you have to make and use the consumables at your disposal. You the player are the one leveling up. It is very satisfying to be able to beat monsters with the same gear you were wearing when you were struggling against them earlier.The different weapons allow you to hunt your way. Fast and aggressive? Heavy and crushing? Ranged? Each have a few choices to pick from that all feel different. The game does not teach you everything about the movesets. I recommend watching Youtube tutorials to learn. This is the other aspect of the game that lends itself to immense hours of play. You can switch weapon types and experience a very different playstyle. Good if you're getting a little bored.It is perfectly fine to take breaks from this game! I just recommend that you try to play more during the special events like the ones they have for Halloween and Winter so far. People after 300 hours or so of gameplay start complaining about a lack of things to do. That's reasonable!Happy Hunting!
title: MONSTER HUNTER: WORLD
