title: Moonlighter

review: I regret being on the fence about buying this game. I've been loving it ever since i picked it up. It has that Stardew valley feel to it but unfortunately without most of the things that makes that game adorable. On the flip side it's reminiscient of Legend of Zelda games and is entirely focused on clearing dungeon floors sort of like the Binding of Isaac.I'll try doing a pros / neutral / cons thing for this review for once.PROS + Very charming and smooth pixel graphics á la Starbound Valley+ Gameplay is something like Recettear meets Legend of Zelda with storytelling like Rogue Legacy+ Relatively fast paced and reaction / pattern intensive. Mildly hardcore but not unfair!+ Clearly inspired by older Legend of Zelda games such as those found on GBA+ Magical soundtrack parts of it dynamic (changes while playing based on what you are doing or where you are). It's the kind of music you never really get tired of listening to. Very catchy and mix up intensive.+ No enemy recycling every biome has its own unique enemies and some only show up on lower floors or at night+ Clever randomized map design with secrets to find encourages exploring+ NPC writing is good if rather lacking in quantity... (Will elaborate)+ There is no hard time limit. Like Starbound Valley but without seasons or a day clock.+ Interesting fair bosses with no "learn by death" patterns. If you pay attention you can overcome everything.+ The default difficulty is "Hard". That's not something i've ever seen before but it can be adjusted if you want to.+ Every armor piece shows on your character and they can freely be mixed and matched at your leisure. + You decide prices of items you sell. This can be stressful and confusing if you do not like thinking.+ Dark background world / story that belies the cute graphics. You have to piece this together yourself.+ Very interesting dungeons with unique aesthetics and suitable music.Now for the neutrals. I will put these in because they could be a matter of opinion or playstyle some people won't mind this at all while for others it can be very disappointing.NEUTRAL The game is a rather short one. Few weapon upgrades (although progression locked due to material requirements) Besides grinding for money there's very little else to do than conquer the dungeon. Once you unlock everything... ..You no longer have anything to do in town except resupply. Small inventory forcing you to manage it wisely and return to town often or throw items away. Clever curse system on items that requires different and still clever inventory management. I doubt there's anything to do after conquering the few dungeons. They are fun but... Mobile game length. NPCs do not remember conversations. They will repeat themselves endlessly. Random town NPCs share lines. If you talk to multiple in a row they will finish each other's monologues. Some NPCs have portraits when they talk yet no more significance than any other NPC. Scrapped story assets? There is no player NPC interaction. They will only ever monologue to you. No decisions or similar. Good shop management is not actually important as you can endlessly grind for items in the dungeons. As you have a monopoly on the market there is no flooding the economy. Endless money! No real attack variation. Usually not a problem but lacks the flair of better hack&amp slash games when it comes to combat. You cannot hire guards to your store or expel repeat offenders. Thieves will constantly leave and come back immediately. You also have to wait for said thieves to commit a crime before you can stop them even if you know them well already. Movement in six directions for the most part. Walking diagonally feels unresponsive but it's there. You only attack in four directions. This is alright as so do your enemies. Easily exploitable with our flexibility. Your character is (barely) established no backstory but everybody in town knows you.CONS Each weapon class has ONE special attack regardless of what weapon type or tier you have. This attack SUCKS. The town feels very bare bones. As if there was more planned for it but then it was all scrapped once they had the shell. The other NPCs than your guide / tutor never gets fleshed out. They seem designed to have a larger part in the story. While the other NPCs have good writing in itself (elaborating on their stories and their society as a whole) they do not Play any significant part in the game and you can easily ignore them without missing out on anything. The only real reason to even manage the shop is to afford adventuring upgrades. Cynical and repetitive. Eventually guessing prices for new items can get overwhelming as there are a lot of items and no price references.I have probably missed out on a couple things but overall i still recommend this game. It's a great experience (especially when just starting out) and it's an enjoyable dungeon crawler / loot collecting game with generally satisfying gameplay.Please ask questions in the comments field if there is anything specific you would like to know or for me to add to the review.
title: Moonlighter

review: Moonlighter is a dungeon crawler with management elements. The story takes place in a small town built around dungeons that randomly appeared one day. As Will you play a shopkeeper who gets his inventory out of those dungeons. He is told to only stay at the first level and return safely once he found enough loot but Will dreams of becoming a full fledged hero.You can explore the dungeons during the day or the night but your shop will only find customers during the day. As you start of your adventure you're still very weak. As you fight you get loot meant for your shop but it can also be used to create stronger weapons and armor as well as health and other potions. If you lose all your health in a dungeon you lose most of your loot and have the choice to try again or return to the town. If you have a short run i.e. left on an early level you might even have time for another run after storing your current loot in your chest or on display in your shop.The dungeons themselves are pretty straightforward. They all have three levels that lead to one boss room. Some room have secret rooms underneath them which are indicated by a little sparkle. The dungeons are somewhat randomized but they all follow the same pattern. For example if you come across a healing room you are on the right path. If you manage to beat a boss the next dungeon will unlock. You can always return to the previous dungeon if you need those items. Beat all four dungeons and you open the mysterious fifth door that holds the secret to the town.The enemies inside the dungeons all have specific attack patterns. It's easy to defeat to them but also to die because of them. Honestly the boss fights are much easier than getting through the dungeons. The patterns of all bosses can be easily avoided when using a bow and arrow to fight them. Once they idle you can do a lot of damage to them with a strong direct weapon. But the bosses are really easy in my opinion. You might need one or two tries to understand their pattern but once you learn how to avoid taking damage or take enough health potions with you there's nothing stopping you. I beat the 3rd boss on my first try without even preparing for it and just entering the boss room just to see what the fight looks like. And I'm not that good at dungeon crawlers. If you're a dungeon crawler lover looking for a challenge this isn't the game for you.The shop elements of the game are somewhat lackluster. You place an item you price it and then the customers will react to it. You basically have to guess the price of an item and it'll make you lose a lot of good money in the beginning if you want to play the game the way it was meant to be. I'd recommend using a price guide some specific items later on are incredibly valuable and it's very easy to sell them at 0.1% of their actual price. Honestly though the items in the last dungeon are too valuable and you'll make too much gold that you'll never find any use for. I think I beat the game while having 2m in gold left. It is justified through the story you're the second (or third given that there's another merchant selling the same items as you) person to ever enter the last dungeon and thus everyone is willing to pay a lot of gold for these items. I just hope that future updates include new upgrades or just something new to do with your leftover gold.Running the shop itself is also kinda boring. You just stand at the cash register and accept people buying your items. If you idle and don't accept they will just take the items with them and leave the shop. There are also multiple thieves that can come to your shop. You have a prompt to tackle them and get the stolen item back so if you see someone with a thief symbol come into your shop you should accept all ongoing sales and then follow them around. Later on you can upgrade the shop and get more display cases requests and an additional employee but it's just not as exciting as a typical shop simulation management game could be. And it doesn't have to be since it's not that kind of game but seeing how the dungeon crawler element isn't really difficult or long I just wish there would be a little bit more to the shop and the town life. The town itself does offer upgrades as well. You can pay for more shops to appear like a blacksmith and a potion brewer but they all just benefit yourself and don't affect anything else. I really enjoyed the game but it just feels empty. Like the NPCs could have their own ongoing story that develops with each dungeon you beat. But they just have little quirks they repeat. That doesn't change the quality of the game and make it boring I just think there's so much more potential in the game.The one thing about the game that I didn't like was the story or more specifically the ending to it. You start off as a shopkeeper trying to follow his granddad's footsteps and discover the secrets of the dungeons. Your mentor is worried about you since he's already seen someone take on more than they could handle. But you push on and open the fifth door. I'm not going to spoil the story here but there's no emotional payoff for the story. What you find behind that door is so random that it ruins everything the game has built up. It seems like they tried to copy another incredible popular RPG with it but that ending just doesn't fit with this story. The game is a lot of fun but you get excited to see where the story goes and the ending is just kinda dumb and meaningless. The ending is about how the dungeons got there and it makes sense to explain it no matter how weird your explanation for it is but to not have any payoff for the emotional conflict? It was a letdown for me.Overall I recommend this game to anyone who wants to experience a nice adventure game with a story and maybe someone who wants to test out a simple dungeon crawler game for the first time. The game is complete as it is but seeing the developers work on more content and different modes gives me hope that the current problems will also get some attention.
title: Moonlighter

review: It's sad to give this a "not recommended" because there's a lot to like in Moonlighter. It's not really a "bad" game but there's not a lot of depth to it and it has a huge number of small annoyances that end up making the game feel incredibly clumsy to play.The shop mechanics are... fine but you basically do the same thing with every type of item. Figure out the best price for the item (you do this by semi randomly trying out different prices unitl the customers show a certain face) then put all the you don't think you need up for sale at that best price. You sit in your shop and wait for customers to come in bring an item to you then you hit A. Occasionally a shopliflter will come in and you have to run and stop them after which the item falls on the ground and you have to re put it up for sale. There's just not a lot going on in this section of the game.So is the combat worth it? Well... kinda. It's again fine but nothing special. You have a few different types of weapons (which can be upgraded in town). There's an alternative attack (which is usually a super underpowered charge attack) and a normal attack. You can also dodge roll. The enemies look nice and aren't terrible to fight but something feels just a bit too slow and awkward about the fighting.You also have to do constant inventory management during your dungeon runs. There are 3 floors to each dungeon but you'll probably be full after 75% of the first floor. This means that after every room you're often opening your inventory trying to figure out which stuff to dump (you can convert all objects to money while in the dungeon) and then going to the next room. This really breaks up any attempts at "flow" and the sheer NUMBER of different items is really silly. They tried to mix things up with an "item curse" system where some items have to be placed in specific spots or other items destroy items in certain adjacent slots if you return to town but this system doesn't really work at all it just makes the whole process more annoying (you can't stack "normal" items with cursed variants).And the small nitpicks... there are so many small things that get in the way of enjoying the game. Want to craft healing potions? Select the potion hit A on the potion move the cursor from "no" to "yes" hit A again wait for a short animation. Now repeat if you wanted more than 1 potion (which you always do). Upgrading your shop or adding a merchant? Get locked in an awkward animation where a random builder guy SLOWLY walks from off screen to where the shop will be the screen fades out then again the builder SLOWLY walks back off screen. Have an item held in your cursor and try to swap it out with another item? The item doesn't come into your cursor it goes to where the original item was so now you have to move back to that item to move it again. No way to quick sell items in the inventory No mouse support at all so you can't really speed up inventory management Buying items doesn't remove them from your "wishlist" so you have to do that manually Upgrading/decorating your shop seems interesting at first but the impact it has feels very minimal The dungoen design is really repetitive and no rooms really feel unique in any way. "harder" enemy variants are the exact same but just do more damage and have more health Many enemies can be cheesed extremely easily by hitting them through the solid level pieces with your weapon "Story" text that you find in the dungeons repeats itself and you can't skip them once you've started reading them (and there are a few that are 10+ dialog boxes worth of text). Each "run" feels extremely similar as you don't get any mid run upgradesI could go on for more. The art is great the sound/music is fine but man the game is lacking in actual fun design.
title: Moonlighter

review: This... is hard for me. I kickstarted this game and loved every bit of the premise of it. I wanted something like Recettear and to be fair I got that... (to an extent.) I want to see the genre succeed and expand considerably. I want more games like it. But with that said I had some core issues with this game. Perhaps you won't have those sorts of issues so please read through before deciding not to buy based on this. I still want to see the game flourish and grow.Pros Beautiful art style.An entry into a very rare genre not easy to scratch that itch.Rouguelike procedurally generated so layouts won't get repetetive.Can be an interesting challenge if you let it.The story is told indirectly through item descriptions and notes.Cons Small like a well but sadly so very shallow.Almost no items have a use beyond 20 or so to make weapons and armor.Weapons and armor are very small in number and no depth or customizability to them.The shopkeeping is very simplistic learn a price set it wait for someone to buy it. That's all.Short. 4 real dungeons 3 floors each and when you know what you're doing it can take something like 5 hours to beat.Combat wasn't overly satisfying. The bosses might have been fun but a couple of weapons can trivialize most encounters. Even when playing on the hardest difficulty.Relatively buggy. The devs chose not to beta test anything beyond the first build and dungeon of the game. This has a cost in bugs unfortunately with performance issues crashes softlocks and the like.In the end... there was just next to nothing to do. It felt so hollow... I wanted depth and complexity but instead I got a lot of pretty art with some sprinkled gameplay. In the beginning I thought the tighter focus on a smaller area would mean there'd be a lot to explore within those areas to do to spend the money you make on. But really there isn't. No big payoff. No real reward. Even the story sort of hangs you out to dry at the end.I really do hope I get to change this review into a glowing one before the end. I really *want* to love this game as much as I loved Recettear... but unless it gets a whole lot more depth I simply cannot recommend it at this time.
title: Moonlighter

review: It's fun for a while but it's shallow and there's not a lot of content. It feels like the basic framework that could've been vastly expanded upon but right now it's lot of very basic gameplay systems.You have your procedurely generatored dungeons with 4 different environments and bosses (the bosses CANNOT be refought in any way a very strange decision for a rogue lite game). Enemies get slightly stronger on every floor with 4 floors per dungeon and they drop items you can sell or craft with.You have your standard overhead 2D combat with lite and charge attacks on 5 different weapons. You do not gain extra combat abilities as the game goes on and the weapons only do more damage or sidegrade to some light status effects. Combat stays the same.You have your shop in which you ostensibly play a merchant putting things on sale but really this isn't much different than selling things to a vendor in other games just slower. Every item has an internal best price you can sell to your customers at and once you find it that's it. There's an "item popularity" mechanic but it doesn't affect much of anything. There's shop customization but it's much shallower than in Recettear. You can basically just expand the space and install items to provide flat bonuses. There is no customization of shop ambiance to attract different customers or cosmetic touches.There's crafting which basically means you pay money at the town billboard to unlock shops before you can buy from them. The village outside your shop is pretty lifeless with a lot of nameless NPCs that have 1 3 lines of dialogue that never change. Some inexplicably have portraits hinting that NPC stories or quests that were planned but never put in. Weapons crafting is also very strange in that you can craft completely separate lines of either Physical or Elemental based weapons but the elemental weapons have a specific element per tier so you can't have say a fire based elemental weapon of the highest level only lightning. This is a hugely missed opporunity to beef up the enchanting system which only allows you to buy a flat attack damage or defense upgrade to your weapons/armor.In short a bunch of different gameplay elements mixed together can be more than the sum of its parts but this doesn't happen in Moonlighter. Everything feels very separate and still basic. The combat starts ok and fails to get more interesting the dungeons start ok and then just become very easy as you learn without any major surprises. The boss fights are fun but there's only 4 + the final boss and you can't do a boss rush or replay the fights. The shop only has one or two mechanics behind it for the entire game. There's an interesting concept here but the devs were only able to do the minimum with it.
title: Moonlighter

review: Games like this make me hate steams review system. The game is fun but it's pretty lacklustre to be honest. Only 5 bosses randomly generated maps paper thin story line barely engaging shop system and the most straight forward weapons and armor you've ever seen. Have you seen the trailer? Well you've pretty much seen everything worth seeing as far as story is concerned. The rest is basically an old man who tells you to stay outta the dungeons constantly well the ending is weird. There are various notes hinting at a deeper storyline but they're kinda disjointed and uninteresting. Mainly because what they actually reveal in the end is kinda stupid. The monsters are pretty good solid enemies. Lot's of creative patterns. The bosses are also consistent and solid challenges. The main problem is that you can pretty much just buy your way through any dungeons you're having trouble with. As the game goes on your income becomes stupidly high and every time you return from a dungeon without dieing you can make a massive profit. Then you can just upgrade or enchant your weapons load your inventory up with potions and then the whole dungeon is basically free. That brings us to the next problem the over simplified weapon and armor choices. They literally boil down to do you want armor that makes you 1)faster with weak defense2)average speed average defense3)slower with stronger defense. Those are LITERALLY your armor choices. And your weapons aren't much better. Everything about this game is over simplified. They figured since they were basically making a game with two different concepts they could skimp on both. Whether it's the shopping or the combat neither one is anywhere near complete.
title: Moonlighter

review: Moonlighter is first and foremost a dungeon crawling game with strong memories of Legend of Zelda. Meanwhile the shop management segment will rarely have you shouting "Capitalism ho!"PROS + Would you wrap your eyes around those pixels It looks quite nice! The bosses and monsters all look colourful and impressive and everything moves with a silky smoothness that is both pleasant and delightful.+ Inventory Management? Somehow they've made inventory management fun and puzzling! Trying to avoid all of your items exploding in a fit of curses turns the whole experience into it's own little puzzle to solve+ Keep your belly to the floor in those dungeons! As you're dungeon... crawling. It's fun. They're effective and interesting and there's a constant tension as you go for one more room only to die and lose everything.CONS Shopkeeper? I hardly know her! The shop keeping aspect is incredibly light and lacking. Working out the right price for an item is fun but it ends there immediately. There's not much going on in your shop. Help I'm part of the 1% and don't know what to do Money money money could be funny in a rich man's world. You'll have lots of money too much money. There's nothing to spend it on. Upgrading your equipment only costs so much so why are you really selling anything? There's a lack of soul In the most capitalistic aspect of the game it feels like it just lacks sense of soul. The town itself is devoid of personality and you rarely interact with another character outside of Old Man Jenkins. Haven't I been here before? The dungeons do become a little repetitive as all you eventually want to do is progress to the next dungeon but you've got to go through yet another full dungeon run to get to the final floor aaaaaah.Moonlighter is by no means bad it's "alright". It's shop management aspect suffers heavily from just having very little managment to it. Honestly I'd rather have the well known game from 2007 as at least that didn't have the option to hire someone else to do the shop keeping aspect for you removing half of the game. Capitalism ho!(Read more here! mozillogames.wordpress.com )
title: Moonlighter

review: Good game idea addictive gameplay let down by poor controls inconsistent hit detection on inbound damage a multitude of softlocks and an overall lack of polish in terms of input handling and UI.Poor controls 8 way movement but only 4 way facing. Makes positive use of the analog stick tricky when you move diagonal is subject to finnicky zones cutting between up/down or left/right movement alongside diagonal movement. When using the d pad diagonal movement always faces the character up or down never left or right making targeting a hassle. Ledges are finnicky. Sometimes you fall down a pit with practically no provocation sometimes you have to lean on it for half a second before you actually jump down. Rolling over double wides in anything but ideal conditions has about even odds of you seeing the other side vs. seeing the door you came in on. Incoming damage is extremely unpredictable. Sometimes projectiles will hit hard cover sometimes they'll burst through it like it's not even there what finally set me off that it wasn't me was the fact that standing in the exact same location behind a pillar two long wise lava streams passed me... the first one missing completely the second nailing me. The register in the store can be tempermental sometimes requiring repositioning three or four times before allowing sales to a waiting customer.Poor UI A keyboard is also cool not. While I could get to the menu with the keyboard/gamepad switch option I was unable to figure out which key to press to actually get the UI to switch to the keyboard controls so I could see the rest of them. Gave up and just plugged in a gamepad. No "sort my storage/inventory" option. No "repack my storage/inventory" option. Walking into the dungeon resets any teleport you might have set without warning and without any ability to get it back. The teleport by your shop is just far enough out of eyeshot that it's quite possible to make it out of town without noticing you have a port up. With no fast way to switch cursor between storage and inventory when placing cursed items and causing items to be switched between inventories when over placing directly that "mini game" becomes bounds more tedious and much less enjoyable than it otherwise would be. No min/max recording in the merchant book regarding price reactions making finding the highest "ideal" price mildly obnoxious. Price reactions frequently fail to be recorded in the merchant book making finding the highest "ideal" price an active headache. Price bubbles on tables' lower items cover up the item above them making keeping track of what's actually out/on sale an annoyance. Trying to cursor in the up direction to the top left storage inventory slot causes the UI to switch to the previous chest instead of selecting the desired topmost leftmost item Not being able to save and put the game down at any time is an annoyance. Wishlisted item components show as wishlisted... even when they're supposed to be "unknown."Silver linings GREAT choice to allow crafting with vendors so long as you own the items needed they don't have to be in your inventory. GREAT choice to allow wishlisting stuff so you don't accidentally sell necessary crafting materials.Patched to a moderate degree could easily be worth the asking price of $20 but In its current state only a $5 game. Unfortunately it took me longer than the Steam return policy limits to come to that determination.
title: Moonlighter

review: So here's a simplified list of what you'll find in Terraria This is a 2D RPG with platformer and sandbox elements It has an incredible amount of content to it Multiple classes that are shaped through armor bonuses (but you can use other items not of your class) Idk like a billion items? Lots of weapons armor cosmetics and building material. It's crazy A good healthy serving of cool and interesting bosses to fight Lots of NPC's to buy stuff from (be ready to build basically a hotel for the like 30 of them in the game now) Really good retro soundtrack but more modern that fit the creative environments they pair with. Boss fight music gets you pumped! Is it too easy for you? Try Expert mode! Don't feel like you're penalized enough for dying? Set your character to Hardcore! I almost forgot to mention SO MUCH CRAFTINGCons? Hmm. Inventory management the abundance of items will overwhelm you. I usually make a structure dedicated to storing all my loot in chests. Stay organized! Fishing is pretty useful but well it s not exactly exciting. You can get some great stuff that way though. Expect a big difficulty spike after defeating the boss in the Underworld! You ll feel like a noob all over again but once you work past it is where the game feels like it truly begins for me. Some items in the game are pretty rare and some of these rares are used to craft or otherwise obtain some of the best loot in the game. Other thought If you can play with friends or find people to run through the game with do it. It's much more fun that way. You can still enjoy it quite a bit single player however... it's not the same when you can't laugh when someone gets destroyed by a boulder trap.Story time (if you want to torture yourself and read my rambling) I bought this game ages ago back when it was still in development before any of the expansions and cleanups it's gone through. I spent $10 on this.Since then the Dev team (at least back in 2014 2015 or so when I kept up with it) would post threads about once a month at the least to let people know what was planned/ the progress of the game. It kept getting updated adding more content and mechanics. I remember being super excited when new weapon types were added rare mounts were added. Accessories so your character can fly around the map? Gimme. Something I always admire too is Re Logic did not simply focus on adding more stuff end game they kept polishing up early game too adding things like Ropes to make things easier until you get hookshots simple versions of weapons you find later like Spears wooden yo yo more early game magic items. It used to be a much less enjoyable slower grind to get to mid game content where the pace picks up.There were at least a couple times where the development with the game was supposedly going to halt and I was satisfied with it then. I'd gotten more content and enjoyment out of Terraria than most games I'd bought for $30 or more. Yet somehow maybe a year after hearing nothing a new content update would surprisingly be pushed out. This happened at least twice when I thought it would be laid to rest as is. I spent $10 on this.

review: You feel an evil presence watching you... This is the sort of game that you boot up thinking you'll spend an hour or two on only to one day wake up face down on your keyboard surrounded by bottles and plates wondering where the past 3 weeks went. 100 hours in and I've still not defeated the current 'final' boss something that's a mixture of the games' excellent difficulty curve and a melancholy realisation that once I defeat him my time with the game will naturally come to an end. Primarily Terraria is a sandbox game. You appear in a new world with some basic equipment and no real instruction eventually you will build a small house to survive the monsters that surface during the night discover some form of corruption eating away at the world encounter new NPCs and face off against powerful Boss enemies. Despite all this you are given little direction these are merely facets of a larger game that allows players to do as they wish encountering all the world has to offer at mostly their own pace. Part of the great design behind the title is in the difficulty curve I mentioned earlier meaning challenges pitted against a player start easy and steadily increase at a rate easy to handle. Although traditional RPG elements are largely absent a discrete levelling system is present in the form of Bosses that have been defeated meaning if you don't progress through these enemies then the gameplay doesn't become more difficult. In fact the first boss doesn't spawn until you're suitably equipped with armour and health. My hours in the game are split roughly equally between single and multiplayer. Single player stands up on its own perfectly fine but in my opinion the game is much more rewarding gathering some friends and working together to tackle the bosses as the feeling of reaching new goals is shared and the ammount of 'grinding' for materials is spread across multiple people. It also helps to appreciate the brilliant soundtrack as if you voice chat with your group then spontaneous humming along loudly is to be expected. Enemy design is exciting and unique with floating eyes possessed suits of armour giant robotic worms and a ninja suspended in a giant ball of slime all making appearances. That being said whoever on the design team is responsible for 'hellbats' has earned a special sort of hatred from myself...All in all Terraria is an amazing experience from beginning to end its tone is humourous at times whist still provoking a feeling of wonderment and mystery in its exploration and fearful excitement at its combat. It's a game I will come back to time and time again looking to recapture the memories I've made and to forge new ones. It is a rare game in that with no shred of a doubt these hours I have spent were not wasted. I heartily recommend that you purchase this game. Fortune and glory kid...
title: Terraria

review: This review applies to Terraria 1.3.0.8 and earlier.The essence of Terraria is that it prioritizes fun! It's not a game where players must fear losing progress due to forgetting safety measures or manage breakable tools. The game knows how to bring out a sense of enjoyment and achievement. Grinding is an option not a requirement or an excuse to drag out game time. Besides there is much to discover and do in the game. Clocking in at 1 000+ hours having all 88 achievements and introducing multiple friends to the game should be indicative of that. With that being said I'll list some pros/cons I've found memorable.Pros Customization There is a staggering amount of customization available in game. You not only can choose from several basic character designs but also have a plethora of armors costumes accessories and pets for your character. You can also color/dye any of your equipment and get all sorts of flashy effects. Dyes aren't consumable so you have few restrictions on perfecting your assemblage. Exploration The Terraria world may be finite but it is incredibly diverse. Each biome has its own personality and houses many unique elements. It takes a minimum of three worlds to discover everything and that's only with absurd luck (see "The Creation of the Guide" painting). The game additionally has an impressive number of flavor. That rubble on the ground can be dug up and a Worm might pop out from it. You can reignite the burnt out Campfire in that small cavern. You didn't think that NPCs could fend for themselves during a Blood Moon or invasion did you? Just when you think you've learned everything about the Terraria world you discover something surprising. Creativity Terraria is as much as about creating your world as it is exploring it. Blocks and furniture are not just for aesthetics but they also introduce some neat mechanics. Players looking to engineer stuff will enjoy the contraptions possible by the wiring mechanic and designers will love being able to paint the overworld with a wide spectrum of colors. Terraria features innovative design at its finest. Progression options Like any good RPG there's a great sense of progress made in a playthrough. You mine or slay enemies for the materials needed to upgrade equipment and the world is bountiful enough that this progress never feels linear or constrained. Even the achievements flow nicely never feeling too easy cheap or absurdly difficult. You never need to rely crutch items to make progress. Rather in my experience my friends and I frequently had too many options and had to reluctantly store away some of our neat loot. There is always something to switch to if a playstyle becomes easy or repetitive. Balance A game can become boring if there is a certain playstyle players fall into. Terraria manages to find the right balance so that all playstyles have a fair shot at completing the game. There is no bottleneck or singular Infinity+1 Sword needed for progress. Diversity Terraria promotes itself as a game for any type of player and that claim certainly has truth in it. The game has gameplay suited for battlers explorers and builders and I can also tack on several options that appeal to other types of players. Collectors will balk at the quantity of items and achievements offered and players can challenge themselves to make progress with nearly any conduct. Play with only melee/ranged/magic/summoning weapons? Sure. A yo yo only run? That's popular! No crafting/mining? Certainly. Play the entire game upside down? Of course and that's bug free! If that's not enough you can fire up a world in Expert Mode for the extra challenge. There's something for everyone. I've had a friend who would ask on his first playthrough 'Can I do ____ in the game?' and I could answer in the positive the majority of the time. Just for starters you can teleport build trap filled dungeons set up PVP minigames and record the soundtrack. The game's breadth is incredible. Automation Terraria would be daunting without any form of automation. You have thousands of items hundreds of monsters dozens of mechanics and an expansive world to build on or dig through. The game offers much to ease the burden of management. Auto select picks the right tool rather than requiring manual selection. The smart cursor allows for one click digging. Quick stacking is much more convenient than depositing items one by one chest by chest. Farming is not only feasible but easy. Making measured builds is simplified with items like the Ruler. The game naturally provides the player ease of use tools so a playthrough can be focused on the fun stuff rather than on chores. Performance Many games fall off a prospective player's wishlist due to system requirements. Terraria is a game that features a crazy amount of sprites particle effects physics lighting and entity interaction. Being a 2 D game only nets you that much speed before optimizations come into play *cough*Starbound*cough*. The game's requirements are reasonable and the gameplay is optimized such that it doesn't require a bulky system to run on. I was able to run it decently on a 2007 year old desktop on Windows XP with low end specifications. The performance of the game to medium and some low end systems makes it accessible to a broad demographic of players. On the other hand if you have a high end system go ahead and fire up that Color lighting mode and enjoy Terraria in its full glory. Quality of life Many games have little quirks that people have to accept to enjoy. Not only is Terraria's gameplay mainly devoid of bugs but it also buffs out these quirks. Players are separated from worlds allowing for easy singleplayer to multiplayer transfer. Characters can ascend blocks without needing to jump. Chests containing items don't explode if you try to harvest them. Keys are easily remappable for those familiar with alternate control schemes. Quick stacking skips 'favorite' items. You can use the in game system for taking wide screenshots for giant builds. You can set player configurations to ease the smallest of annoyances. In general you never feel you're fighting the game's controls and interface. Continued updates It would be very easy for Terraria as popular as it is to offer game expansions as paid DLC. The developers instead make their continued updates absolutely free to owners of the game. The developer community relationship is superb.Cons New player friendliness The in game help system is stunted and players can easily become overwhelmed by the ever growing number of toys in Terraria's sandbox. Many people resort to a guide to help them through the game. Grinding While the game does not require noticeable grinding to progress several tangents in the game require patience and luck. That fancy teleportation item pretty much necessitates a farm in the Hallow. The last component of a PDA could be hundreds of monster drops or fishing quests away. At a rate of one quest per in game day the 200 fishing quests achievement would require 4 800 minutes (3 1/3 days) to complete without resorting to tricks. It can be frustrating to have an achievement be left incomplete as a stretch yet Terraria is not above this issue. Moddability Terraria is extensive enough that it doesn't need additional features but people have been able to decode the game and develop external software and mods for a better game experience. It would be a boon if the game was open to the modding community for extended gameplay.

review: One of the best RPG of all times!Lots of possibilities for roleplay and building schematics.You want a big castle? Gather resources and build!Feeling an urge to be a pirate? Dress like one and construct a ship!Always wanted to be a mad scientist? Design an underground lab and pretend to keep NPCs as test subjects!Terraria gives us a lot of fun time a lot of hit&amp dodge fights and generally an infinite patterns for building your own town only limited by your imagination. Your efficiency in fighting depends on time spent on gathering resources but mainly on your own skill + instinct + unique tactics.There are basically 4 hero classes melee fighter marksman mage and summoner all depending on your choice of equipment.Boss fights require enormous focus and audacity as well as (usually) many tries to resolve what kind of tactics you should pick.Developers still keep on updating the game providing players with new stuff to toy with. Summary You need a game limited only by your imagination which requires lots of time to become the ultimate master? THIS GAME IS FOR YOU!

review: With a wealth of existing content dedicated developers who periodically release free updates and a bustling mod community steadily churning out high quality mods Terraria is one of the best value for money purchases you can make on Steam. The game itself is a 2D side scrolling action adventure with a strong emphisis on spelunking looting monster slaying mining crafting and character progression and a secondary emphisis on base construction. The character progression itself is a minor marvel of game design with almost everything being tied not to your character or an arbitrary level but to the weapons armor and tools you have built for yourself and the way the world around you reacts to your gear with progressively tougher enemies and harder to mine materials intuitively informing the player when it is time to upgrade to new gear and with hundreds of weapons/tools and dozens of armor sets to create thousands of materials to gather and dozens of environments enemies and boss monsters to extract them from there is indeed nearly always something new to create.Its tempting to dub Terraria as just "2D Minecraft" but dont be fooled its similarities are purely superficial this game perfects everything that minecraft merely conceptualized and has since outgrown and outclassed its distant voxel based cousin in almost every regard.Simply put one of the best video games on PC.

review: I d only wish I had played this game sooner!Terraria if a fascinating game that introduces players to an open 2D world that features adventure building crafting boss battles and much more. As a player who had experienced the vanilla and the mod variant I ll be commenting for both game experiences.The vanilla original game present you with the basic components of how to play. While it can be a grind at the start to gather materials to build in the later game you ll be introduced to more content new areas enemies and NPCs. The game is hugely focused on progression which makes it quite an addiction to play. My favorite aspects of the game are the weapons and gear plus the boss battles. No item is ever the same as well as the monsters that we face. The aesthetics are also nice the Plantera mask and kimono were one of my personal favorites to dress for my character. Lots of items in the game are customizable including colour changes to upgrades for bonus stats.Now for the mod version there were even more available content for players. The mods my friends and I played with on his server were namely the Thorium Mod and Calamity mod. These mods added features such as more boss monsters items NPC and more. Some players will frown at mods and call it cheats and whatnot. However this is not the case as it brings more complexity to the original game and it's not intended for new players anyways. We played on Expert/Revengeance mode and fought additional bosses like Astrium Deus and the Siren and Leviathan. In my experience the modded variation provided and even more thrilling challenge than the Vanilla version. I recommend trying it after you ve completed the original game.In general Terraria is a must play for anyone who hasn t done so.

review: Don't let the Minecraft comparisons put you off. Whilst Terraria is based on collecting materials and crafting this is a very different game. There is a very definate path to follow and campaign to progress through with increasingly powerful gear. You can play as a melee ranged magic or summoning based warrior and defeat over a dozen bosses. In addition to building yourself up it pays to build you own town/settlement and attract other characters. These additions offer many different invaluable skills and items to help you along.Everything is very well balanced and when you get stuck there is always more items and equipment to work towards. If I had one complaint it would be that progressing through the game isn't very intuitive. Unless you plan on a lot of experimenting and trial and error with the crafting guide I would recommend keeping the Terraria Wiki to hand.

review: Ah yes... Terraria the game that is oftenly called a "2D Minecraft" even though it is much better than the one it's supposedly copying. Terraria is a fantastic game made by a team of developers who really love their job and actually care about their game as a real game and not as a product or a money making machine. It is hard to put on words why Terraria is so great and why it can keep you playing for as long as i did. First things first let's start the breakdown. Do note that this review was written when Terraria was in it's version 1.3.5.3.GRAPHICS Excellent.For a 2D pixel game the graphics on it are Fantastically made everything looks incredibly detailed and splendid it's hard to find stuff in it that stands out as being particularly ugly although some enemies come close not because of bad art but because the enemies themselves are ugly as all bloody hell. Although you probably won't have enough time to enjoy the graphics when you're shooting stuff up. SOUNDTRACK Great.The soundtrack in this game is unique and charming every piece of it is a work of art in and of itself everything in the game has some music to go along it although.... when you've played the same game for over 500 hours listening to the same songs you're gonna get tired because of the strongness that the soundtrack comes in it enchances the experience in a very delightful way but after playing for so long you grow tired of it because it's the same music over and over again.So for the first few hundred hours it's awesome but after that it starts getting repetitive so i just reccomend that you go on the internet and find some remixes which are easy to do since the entire soundtrack is conveniently packed into one simple file that you can replace at any time (Except when the game is open of course) and it will change all the musics with the game being tasked of playing the tracks as it needs to.GAMEPLAY Nailed It.The gameplay is fenomenal and there's so much you can do in this game that you'll easily lose weeks of your life trying to do all the stuff you can do. Of course everytime you start a new save file it is the same thing but it's never exactly the same thing there's always a difference even though almost everything stays the same. But don't expect that just because everything stays the same that your is not gonna get kicked let me tell you this game holds your hand less than dark souls this game is un forgiving and ruthless at the same time it's gonna kick your and once you're down on the ground stomp on your balls a couple of times it will only do it if you let it. This game requires a lot of skill in fast reflexes and critical thinking but there are still a lot of things you can use to make your life much easier. And once you start getting tired of the same old just grab yourself a backpack and go explore the forums for some mods. Some mods that i particularly reccomend are Thorium JoostMod AlchemistNPC and More Pets Mod. VARIETY Plentiful.This game oozes variety theres a really expansive assortment of weapons accessories and armors that you can use but also a giant ammount of possibilities in building furnituring and even the enemies have a lot of variations specially the zombies and the demon eyes those two combined togheter have over 30 variations! That's a f*ck ton of them! Every thing you can do has at least 4 ways about doing it the possibilities are endless and you will never get tired if you keep exploring them all. STORY What story?There is no story.... well at least not as much of a story as "Just shoot whatever you see" so i can't rate this part. MULTIPLAYER Perfect.If you know me you know that on my circles i praise and praise and praise Terraria's Multiplayer to no end it's the quintessential "Best Designed Multiplayer" for me There is very little that the game actually changes about multiplayer but what it lacks in differences it more than makes up by your own options you can choose to join one of 6 teams (Might have been expanded in the future) And get this every player has their own setting about PvP the PvP aspect isn't a focus of terraria anyway but having the ability to toggle PvP on and off at will without losing your offensive capabilities (Looking at you GTA Online) or anything for that matter is a big plus for me which i hope many survival games out there would adopt it although i know Terraria is a Sandbox and not a Survival per se but it really brings my to a boil in survivals when people just kill eachother instead of.. you know trying to actually survive anyway This system is f*cking wonderful not only that but some weapons behave differently when used in PvP for balance pourposes like every homing weapon that do not home on players. Bottom line Multiplayer is a guranteed Certificate of Quality.CONCLUSION 12/13This game is impeccable and undescribably good if you haven't played it yet go and play it you won't regret it.I can't say anything else about this game because what else can i say that hasn't already be said if you are reading this you haven't bought the game yet and if you haven't bought the game yet GO DO SO ALREADY FOR F*CKS SAKE!

review: Now see some people don't like this game. Most of these people swear by minecraft. Terraria however is a totally different game. Do people refer to it as a 2D version of Minecraft? Well yes and in some ways that's exactly what it is. Let's do a compare/contrast though. Minecraft Terraria 3D 2D Randomly generated open world environment Randomly generated limited linear environment Crafting system with limitless building capabilities Crafting system with limitless building capabilites The occasional village or randomly generated dungeon Various NPCs that are unlocked through the game each with specific capabilities Open roaming with loose storyline with abstractly located dungeons temples etc. Open roaming with a definate goal multiple quests and dungeons temples and more 26 mobs in 1.3.1 Over a hundred mobs One world one character Characters can be taken from one world and ported to any other world you have made with any items on them One or two bosses throughout the game Triggerable boss battles hard mode and events such as 'Goblin army' and 'blood moon' A basic monetary system based on trading in villages based around mineable emeralds A complex monetary system with shops coins in mobs and unique items And more than I could ever put in my piddly little review. I love the game and recommend it to anyone who A. Gets lost ALL THE TIME in minecraftB. Has a computer which can't quite handle the graphics of minecraftC. Loves crafting survival games like MinecraftD. Wants to buy the gameE. Everyone else.

title: Terraria

review: Terraria at first glance can be called a "2D Minecraft" from some viewers but it surprisingly has a lot of differences.For starters while Terraria is indeed a 2D sandbox game the main highlight of the game isn't just creating whatever you want but working your way up from basic equipment up to fighting space invaders and SQUIDLORD. ..er excuse me the "Moon Lord".Speaking of equipment at no point what so ever do your tools or armor ever break. There's also currency in the form of bronze silver gold and platinum coins which can be used to buy goods from friendly NPCs. Said friendly NPCs can appear if you fufill certain conditions and have a vacent room for them. So on and so forth there are many differences between this and Minecraft that makes the whole comparison silly to bring up.Though I won't be praising everything about the game as it does have some flaws. For starters while the PC version has no tutorial every other version of the game has one. There are console and mobile exclusive events items and even music which was a personal pet peeve for me. Some accessories made from combining others together end up being less useful than if you were to use the two seperately or create an entirely different accessory the fishing achievements are quite a nightmare to go after and the beginning can be VERY tedious especially in Expert Mode. Throwing weapons are also useless past the Wall of Flesh with a majority of items involving throwing capabilities being thrown out of the window by the time Skeletron comes around.Do these gripes of mine hinder the experience as a whole?I don't think so and I still think the game is worth checking out if you're into games such as this.An additional bonus there's also a pretty awesome modding community for the game too which adds even more things you can do with the game long after you taken care of the vanilla game's final boss. Some recommended mods to check out would be Leveled Thorium and Calamity.I'd highly recommend getting Terraria if you haven't yet especially if it's on sale. Though I would also recommend playing the game with friends as it's muuuuuuch more fun and also not as tedious. ..maybe.

review: My hours of playtime should more than likely speak for themselves but I feel as though with how much I love this game it deserves a review and recommendation. What can I say about Terraria? Regardless of how often I have played it I find myself coming back to this game time and time again drawn in by its charm and sense of adventure. Everything about this game from the catchy music and friendly characters to the sheer variety of creatures items and locations all there to help or hinder you is a treat. Each new world that is generated holds its own feeling of excitement as you dive into the unknown. Even though I have put so many hours into this game I still manage to find something new even recently. If you enjoy tense battles building cities or simply exploring a strange and dangerous wold I can not begin to recommend Terraria to you enough. The devs have added so much new content over the years that I would not even attempt to explain to you what is in store you will just have to see for yourself and discover the wonderful quirky ever changing world that is Terraria.

review: Hard to understand at the beginning but you very quickly get used to the different fighting styles loot drops and rarities of items and ores around the world. Getting to the final boss of Normal mode takes about 2 hours if i rush for him. However you cant call him a final boss considering he is the boss you fight when you have encountered about 15% of the total game. Killing this final boss (Wall of flesh is its name btw) sets your world into "Hard Mode" which can spawn many MANY different ores for different kinds of weapons never before seen in normal mode. This game has hours upon hours of constant fun and exploration. Building is very well designed and easy to get used to. Fighting is extremely varied depending on what you fight with what weapon you fight with what armor you wear what buffs you get from drinking your potions and where you fight the enemies at. Combat feels natural and keeps a steady flow of increasing difficulty throughout your exploration. This is not a game you can "Beat" and always has something you have never explored before. Worlds can be massive filled with many different biomes both above and below the surface. Deep mines and dungeons are extremely fun and lets coop players have tons of fun.And don't even get me started on mods...
title: Terraria

review: Best non japanese rpg I've ever played. Played this game on android first then on pc before 1.3. I've done a playthrough for every class. The game just keeps giving. Free updates 7+ years after release with no dlc. A thriving community. The best modding API for any game I've seen and it's not even made by the publishers. Used to run 80+ fps on max settings 4k but with recent visual and physic overhauls I just don't hit that anymore. The engine could really use an overhaul which I've heard is coming. 10/10 would skip hard mode ores again.(I have no worlds with hard mode ore fishing OP)

review: A 2D sidescrolling sandbox you dig conquer and tame your environment and build whatever you want. As you progress you unlock / discover more content events and encounters. Vast replayability. You can fight as melee ranged magic summons or any combination. Each world you create is different. You may never find that diving helmet or nazar you dream of but you may need an extra chest for your extensive Yo Yo collection.This game has only gotten better through the years. The many many updates have increased content functionality enjoyment and my OCD. I've spent over 1500 hours on this gem and enjoyed every minute of it. Alone or with friends (or strangers) it's beyond amazing.
title: Terraria

review: Terraria is a Sandbox Adventure RPG and an openworld game. it throws you in with a guide and several pieces of equipment to get you started. after several nights you will have a fairly desent house some fairly desent gear and some fairly desent NPC's around your establishment if you have made them houses. this world is filled with deadly creatures from the top of the world to the deaphs of hell. and hundreds of items to match your play style be you a wooden archer or a futuristic sniper there heaps of playthroughs for you.Although behind the amazing gear and creatures there is a down side if you choose to take it the Wiki. i found that once i went on the wiki all of the enjoyment in finding more gear was gone. i knew what to expect behind every chest and what i would get from every boss and i found that i stopped playing the game all together. just to sit in my steam account next to 200 other games. luckily after a year or so i returned and i had forgotten most of what the wiki taught me and i play the game once more.Don't make the same mistake I did only take the infomation the game gives you not what a web page gives you. 8/10

review: It's easy to write Terraria off as a 2D Minecraft clone but it's far from it. It's expansive it has depth and despite the hundreds of hours I've spent in this game I've barely scratched the surface of what this game has to offer. It's definitely a game that you can easily come back to time and time again. It's got a big community around it that has produced hoards of mods that expand this replayability even more and the community has created an extensive wiki to assist new players. I wholeheartedly recommend this game to anyone! Except people who hate spiders because jesus christ the spiders in this game are creepy as Update This is now my most played game. I have still never completed this game despite numerous playthroughs. I come back to this game time and time again and I will continue to do so even after I complete it.

review: Terraria is quite the fun sandbox game and in my opinion has created a unique genre of games in the sense that while it's still a sandbox game it's inspired many other 2D sanbox games like it such as Starbound. In any case I love the fast paced action that tends to happen when you face a boss or event. I always love the serene way of how you can just relax and build or just sit down by a lake and fish. Terraria allows many different play styles. Some people are more laid back and tend to just enjoy the game slowly while other charge straight into the fray. All and all this game is very versatile in the sense of going at your own pace. Granted it certainly ranks up in difficulty once you enter hardmode but that's besides the point. I enjoy the constant adventures and finds. There is always something I've missed that I didn't notice before. It would take a lot more than 100 hours to truly explore just one single large map on this game.In the end Terraria is a grand example of the sandbox genre and I would recommend this to anyone looking for an action packed adventure that doesn't just toss you straight into it but more so let's you ease in.10/10 Pop tarts.

Get wood build a house since mobs spawn at night then go and mine. But once you start to play after the basics it gets serious. Giant eyeballs Burning bats shadow armor Giant skeletons Magical items Wepons Corruption Hallow Giant worns. I can go on all day! The gameplay is so much longer compared to minecraft! In my opinion Terraria beats minecraft regardless with minecraft mods! And for such a little price it's worth it!10/10BUY NOW!

review: This Game is Breath TakingAny 10 year old would say this is a rip off of minecraft but no its much morePros There are a order of bosses to fight in order to up your game Items progressively get better with a wider varity There are 4 main classes you can go off of instead of uses items for it The Music is awesome and i think it matches perfectly with the boss (My Favorite is boss music 2) There are many different ways of obtaining sertain items (Etc. Fishing) The Game Is Seperated In Two Modes Hardmode And PreHardmode Has a "Expert Mode" That allowed a harder difficulty along with a higher chance for loot Basic Yet Complex Combat that allows for a more advanced gameplay Npc's so you acually have a point to build seperate houses (Or a mega house like i do) Content still being added (Active developers) Different biomes with unquie ways of needing 2 Dungeons and along with that you have to come back to one Multiplayer to have fun with friends (I like to play multiplayer) Along with multiplayer there is a easy way of creating a server (Just click join multiplayer and invite steam friends) Many other pros I haven't listedCons Honestly its not much of a con but an infident world would be nice There are no more consThis Game is a must buy if you like sandbox games adventure games or rpg games

review: The game has tons of content and by the sounds of it an impending Linux port. It's quite addicting and fun. There are various issues I do have with it though.The game goes to classic 1 armor 1 less damage route. This is a system that keeps items relevant in the early game as well as the end game. However because of this and the game's scaling early game items quickly become worthless. Pre hardmode items even of the highest tier feel rather low tier when hardmode hits. This can be a bit discouraging. While the game has added various superior versions of weapons it still promotes linear gameplay where you unlock the highest accessible weapons and makes all the work you did beforehand feel a little wasted.Despite all this the game is still a blast to play. Some people may think what I described as a flaw as a good thing to me if the former issue were addressed (more than likely in a sequel) it would be perfect.

review: This is one of the games I thought that are not worth even trying to play.But once again I was wrong.I didn t spend a lot of time playing it but I can already see a lot of options how I can change the world around me and what to do there.The graphics are simple but I like them.And I like sounds and music either.Sometimes I got stuck with controls and how to command my avatar the way I want to but I think it is just because I m not used to it yet.I created a character and entered a randomly generated world. There's a day/night cycle and during night I was attacked by zombies and floating eyeballs.I played single player but there was one NPC with me and he helped me fight them.Suprisingly I was not afraid of those zombies because they were funny and kind of cute. ) So after this first night I immediately sarted to harvest copper wood and stone to build house and some gear and weapons.Then I went to explore the world which means that I digged deep to find iron caverns chests with loot and fought more bad guys.I constructed layered workstations to forge my harvest into better weapons and gear. I built more houses that attracted new NPCs who sold me exotic items or offered fresh haircuts.Once I thought I am invincible and uderestimated my enemy.And i was almost killed by pink slime. )Terraria is very much focused on combat than building. The dungeons presents new challenges and new enemies the lower I go.Sometimes the pure act of digging can get a little grindy but there is a lot to explore and I think that I am just on the peak of an iceberk.I hope this game will stay entertaining for a long time because I think it s worth spending my time playing it.

review: This game is heavily popular for a very good reason. I've followed/played this game for a very long time and i can easily say it is a very fun game. The game offers plenty of challenge that is if you don't know what you're doing. The game has plenty of bosses some of which you need to fight to progress and some that you don't need to fight. The game has mounts allowing you to get around your world much faster. The game has an expert mode for those who a massively experinced when playing Terraria. I reccomend this game for the amount of content within this 2D Pixel Survival game. If it's your first time playing I reccomend you gather some friends and play together and take time. The grind to the end is much more fun that way! To add on the game isn't very expensive and especially with the content in account.Have fun playing this game! It's quite enjoyable. Trust me.

review: Were you a fan of the previous God Eater titles? If so you'll most likely like this entry even if you end up scratching your head at some of the changes.If you were never a fan this game most likely won't change your mind as it's still God Eater but with a lot more polish and better keyboard and mouse controls. Changes compared to God Eater 2 Rage Burst The Blast Gun has been removed. It has been replaced by the Ray Gun. Customized Bullets are limited use now but can be used on any gun. Burst Arts take the place of Blood Arts from GE2. There are other bonuses and mechanics to fit the AGE theme and aesthetic. The Bullet Editor has been rebalanced. Because this is not GE2 Blood Bullets are not a part of the game. Multiple weapons have been buffed up for better usability such as the Buster Blade and Variant Scythe. Aragami "feeding" has been changed. Aragami will now go to specific points on the map where 'feeding grounds' are located. Standing on top of a feeding ground while it is active replenishes HP and OP for your character as well. You can quick devour without leading with a normal attack now. The practice range is no longer restricted to bullet testing. You can now test melee weapons. Shield Charging is a new maneuver which closes gaps much faster than Steps. Verdict Without spoiling the story gameplay has received a lot of polish to the formula. The game is also considerably harder than Rage Burst was as everything in this game is sped up. For those who want to enjoy the story the story is there and it's easy to follow without prior knowledge of other God Eater titles though prior knowledge does help. As of this review the Online features are functioning with minimal latency issues. There's plenty of incentive to play Assault Missions as well which are online 'raid' missions.
title: GOD EATER 3

review: God Eater 3 is the latest entry in the high octane action hunting God Eater series the story setting in this game takes place some years after the events of GE2RB but instead you start off in a Fenrir branch based in Europe where they treat their God Eaters like prisoners forcing them to hunt down Aragami while killing off any that don't perform to their expectations.Gameplay in God Eater 3 is faster than it's ever been before adding new features such as burst arts that enhance aerial and ground combat and shield charges for chasing down fast Aragami or using it to dodge or set up for aerial combos. Three New weapons have been added to the game which include the Dual Wield God Arc which can be transformed into a Double Bladed weapon the Heavy moon axe which is a chakram type weapon that can be transform into a massive axe and the Ray gun that can shoot concentrated laser beams that increase in size and power as you maintain it in battle. The new Ash Aragami are pretty tough as well since they can chase you down and use devour attacks to transform in battle. Also the 8 player co op assault missions are also pretty fun and intense.The port was surprisingly good with almost no issues on my end very good performance even on my crappy gtx 960 build lol and controller support working pretty well too. Also another good thing to note is God Eater 3 will be getting FREE post launch content updates over time that includes new missions additional story more types of aragami new npc ai characters to join you additional fashion and cosmetics options quality of life changes new assault missions new gameplay modes such as time attack and more. God Eater 3 also includes Dual Audio so you can change the voices to Japanese if you want!Information on the Post game updates here https //www.siliconera.com/2019/02/04/post launch god eater 3 updates will make keith a party member add costumes and bring post game missions/
title: GOD EATER 3

title: GOD EATER 3

review: Well having played for a bit now I am pleased to say being a fan of the other two God Eaters this one has not disappointed. Mouse and Keyboard works perfectly for me I've had no problems with either one. It has better graphics and runs perfectly.My computer doesn't meet all the minimum requirements but I've had no problems with it running smooth on high graphic settings. My graphics card is only a GTX 745 and the minimum suggested one is GTX 760. So there is something for those who meet the requirements but have problems. Your computer is the issue not the game.The camera is a bit sensitive though but you can make it a slower in settings. Even then it is still a little sensitive but not as bad. So just a little thing there for those who don't like the camera moving too fast.This is one of the best things They brought back the fast devour from the first one with the shift + right click. That was one of the main things I hated not having in the second one.Unfortunately they have the crappy upgrade system from the second one. Where you have to find materials before you know what you need to upgrade your God Arc. So that was a little disappointing but something I can live with.A good thing they brought in from the second one is the abandoned God Arcs to enhance your current ones. There are two new types of God Arcs specific to this one along with a new gun that replaces the blaster and the old favourites from the other two.They basically have blood arts though they are called something different. You even have a new team combat skill to use with your companions. I won't go into many details on that though you can play it to find out anyway. It unlocks early in the game. Better ones unlock later as well.The character customisation is great. I've checked both male and female customisation options and you can create cool and attractive characters. Most accessories from the other two are also in this one though there are some which aren't like the horns.To unlock new outfits you need to buy or find schematics. The same can be said about making new God Arcs guns and a few other things you unlock later. These you can get through the basic combat missions or buy from a merchant that is unlocked when you get further into the storyline.Like the other two games they still make your character feel special and unique with having a high resonance and being skilled in combat. The storyline is also interesting. I am always curious about what is going to happen next and what caused the 'Ash Storms' in this one after the other two.For first time players of the God Arc series though I would suggest playing the other two first. They have a whole tutorial to help with controls in this one but playing the other two will give you a good idea of how combat plays out. Plus introduce you to some great characters. One you actually meet again in this one.Added Bonus Your character actually has a past. You aren't just that unknown skilled rookie that becomes the heart of your party. You were with your port which is like a branch in the other two but smaller since you were a child. You even have a childhood friend and he is your groups leader. Mature and down to earth. Plus he looks nice so that's always good.They even have a Kota/Romeo combined character who becomes obsessed with that damn 'Bugarally' like Kota in the first one. Though that comes a bit later in the story.Fans of Shio may love this. There is a Shio like character guys. She is a lot cuter than Shio was and you get to spend more time with her. That in itself is a good enough reason to get the game and play through the story if you really adored lil Shio. That little cutie has stolen my heart.Oh something I forgot to mention. You can respond the way you want in certain situations. More so then in either of the other two. It makes you feel more in control of your own character and brings with it more immersion. Talking with everyone in between missions is also quite interesting. You have some fun convo's.All in all if you are a fan of the other two God Eater games I am sure you will enjoy this one. Though that is just my opinion on the matter. c P.s. I'm gonna say stop comparing this to Monster Hunter. It isn't the same only similar in some ways. Besides this game is way better then Monster Hunter as far as I am concerned.Latest Update So I finished it. It's a bit too short especially compared to the other two games. I dunno if anything extra is meant to happen when doing those other optional missions but I have no desire to grind through them. They'll be handy if I ever need to let off steam though. w Another downside. They didn't even explain how the Ash came to be same as when they didn't explain the Blood Rain from the second one. They were just there no explanation or anything.It was worth buying but neither the second or third games can even compare to the first game story wise.
title: GOD EATER 3

title: GOD EATER 3

review: The game is simply amazing. It has taken the best of both GE2RB and GER and combined them while fixing several issues with the previous games. Examples of this is GER's quick devours GE2RB's Blood Arts now called Burst Arts and nerfing of the custom bullet system by removing the infinite supply (so get working bullet makers find me a bullet that will take out a target in one shot). They also added color changing for accessories which I love because now the extensions are actually useful on non blonde characters.You will see several reviews complaining about the Keyboard and Mouse being impossible to play with. This is completely false outside of the mouse acceleration (which isn't that bad it just takes getting used to) the controls are no different from GE2RB and GER. Do not trust the system requirements my specs are supposedly below minimum but it feels as smooth as butter on my PC on high settings. If you can run GE2RB you can probably run GE3 as outside of environment graphics nothing has changed majorly.Tthe game hits a major difficulty spike when you enter Rank 4 missions so I suggest a lot of practicing before you hit this point this way dodging and blocking become almost second nature. The new aragami do tend to have attacks that you cannot dodge so get used to using Shift+E more often than just E. There has also been an improvement on the bond break system as breaking bonds results in a visual effect that you can't miss so people like me who end up with the aragami morphing into a ball of screen effects will know when a bond break happens.
