title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: An absolutely joyful chapter in the Civilization franchise.Everything seems familiar yet still fresh. The artwork (which I love) might be dividing the fanbase but overall the game runs even smoother than Civ V. I see no reason to stick to the old game since all mechanics are included in the new base game.Be aware though most old strategies don't work anymore. For instance going "tall" (a few large cities) is basically no longer a viability. I think this is a good thing since the game feels a lot more varied now. Combat tactics are also much more refined. Cities are harder to capture after they get walls.Can't wait to see what future expansions add to the already great package.
title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: The game is very nice I had to get used to the new interface but the district system is absolutely fantastic in my opinion.Religion victories are a bit hard in this game though and they should lower the infantry production cost or make their strenght slightly better because right now AT Crew has the same strenght is cheaper to produce and has a bonus versus horses. I would give this game a 8.5/10
title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: One of The best game of 2016
title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: I have played the civ series for a long time so my perspective comes with a heavy pro civ bias. I think this game reverse the dumbing down trend in mechanics by giving players more detailed control over their cities and empires. I love the new civics and religion mechanics and feel that almost every change in mechanics was for the better.That said diplomacy is practically a pointless mechanic and will be ignored 99% of the game unless major fixes come. The religious ui seems buggy or thrown in. The ai also is lacking any skill aside from yield bonuses. I hope this is improved or this game will not see the thousands of hours played that it's predecessors earned.In conclusion I still enjoy the game thoroughly but I worry for its longevity with these issues present. And longevity is civs bread and butter. The weak ai and diplomacy make this game feel a little isolated and more of a civ builder than a competitive civ game.
title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: Pros Amazing gameplay Improved AI more strategic building within land (District bonuses etc).Cons Graphics are just okay it's detailed but it's a bit cartoonish. However it doesnt take much from the incredible gameplay.
title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: Can't say i would recommend this game to anyone unless they got a serious Civ itch that needs scratching.Even then i would wait for the game to go on sale not to mention the ridiculously overpriced DLC that the game have. CIVILIZATIONS The Civ's are rather poorly balanced some are way stronger then others. Personaly i don't have a problem with it since i only play it solo. If you are into the multiplayer part it might be something to keep in mind.The personalities that comes with each Civ is rather frustrating i can see what they went for by giving them agends of things they like/dislike but in the end it just turns out the AI hate you no matter what. Trying to get friendly relations with other civs is almost impossible with the AI's agendas stupidly high warmonger penalties (that apply whatever you started a war or not). RELIGION Religion is one thing i could have done without in this game. I just hate the way it is implemented. The investment you have to make to found a religion and spread it isn't really worth it as the religions tend to be rather lackluster and having to fend off an endless stream of rival religious units is just a headache to deal with. MAPS/WORLD BUILDER I also find the maps rather underwhelming not so many to pick from and they tend to be rather dull. One can always hope they add more and better map scripts eventually. Other map related issues is that you tend to spawn really close to other players. It usually ends with a super early war and an AI player knocked out as a because of it. The lack of a proper worldbuilder isn't helping either. You can access one with some modifications but it's super buggy unstable and not very good. The fact that you more or less have to use mods to be able to use the maps you painstakingly created doesn't really make it worth it. CITY MANAGEMENT At first i loved the districts but now i rather hate it. In order to get good adjacency bonuses you have to micromanage the placement of them and it's is only fun that many times. It can get frustrating to plan out things so you don't block future placements and to plan ahead for districts not yet researched.The fact that you can't remove districts kinda sucks so if you missclick when you are about to place your district or wonder... well you are stuck with it for the rest of the game. Not to mention when you conquer cities with bad district placements. I don't mind that wonders take a hex slot around the city since it's a unique building. Tho it can be a bit frustrating that some wonders have really specific placement requirements.Maybe i'm old fashioned but i miss the old city management screens. This new one is bad just like the rest of the UI. UNITS/COMBAT Not much to say really i like the new worker charges and combat isn't that different from Civ V.Some of the unit promotions are a bit lackluster and super situational. Despite the talk/hype about cities taking up more then one square (districts) you pretty much still only fight over the city center. Well sometimes you have to take down the military district. BARBARIANS Well what can i say. The barbarians are actually a legit threat now. I have come to rather like the new barbarian mechanic where they spawn scouts to look for cities that once located (and the scout returns to the camp) they will start to spawn units to attack you with. Some people hate it and i can understand them. But you can always turn it off if you wish. The thing Civ VI really needs is More map types More rule options when making a game (plz i want to turn off religion p ) Better UI seriously.. it's super bad. DLC that is actually worth the asking price. Improvements to the Diplomacy. Seriously would be nice to have a game where every Civ didn't hate you even when you don't wage any wars. The Civics cards needs a little work? Alot of them are so weak that i never use them.. If it weren't for the mods that "fix" some of the issues with the game i would probably have tried to get a refund long ago. But as it stands there are mods that fix some of the gamebreakers for me so now it's a game i take out for a spin every now and then when i get the urge to play a Civ game.oh btw i LOVE the building the greatwall of china. It's not very good but it's really satisfying to build a stupidly large wall.

title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: The more you play it the more you realize that there's little going on behind the pretty facade and new additions compared to Civ V. The AI just can't play this game anywhere near the level required for a fun challenge the only way it'll win is by churning out units and bumrushing your capital in the first thirty or so turns aided by huge starting &amp production bonuses on medium and higher difficulties. After that initial bumrush unless you basically stop playing the game yourself the AI will just shuffle around units offer you silly trade deals and literally hate you for playing the game.And then there's the patching strategy even if you ignore that basic quality of life functionality (restart button build queue decent trade overview etc.) wasn't in the game on launch and it took them months to add modding support the fact remains that they only push out updates every few months when they have new DLC (basically stuff that modders make for free) to sell. New bugs that are introduced (game breaking or not and there's a lot of them) don't get addressed until the next time they want your cash.From what it looks like this game was rushed out by the publisher and left with a small skeleton crew to churn out DLC and the absolute minimum of bugfixes. The official forums are dead (one or two posts a day) recent reviews on Steam are basically putting it at a 5/10 and for all we know the current broken state will remain until they announce an expansion to trick people into giving the game and this publisher another shot.And yes I know I played almost 300 hours by now I loved the Civ franchise and I really wanted to discover ways to play this game in a way that's challenging and fun but most of my playing time was spent wondering where the fun I knew from earlier Civ iterations went.

review: Great game. Just one outsanding problem that I truly cannot believe has not ever been addressed in the previous games or this one. It is incredibly annoying that if you tell a unit (such as a scout) to move into a tile that is in the fog of war and a unit happens to be there that you couldn't see before (such as a barbarian or player you are at war with) your unit automatically attacks that unit. If your unit is a scout this usually results in its death. This is incredibly annoying. It forces you to have to inch your unit along one tile at a time to make sure you don't accidently attack something you can't see. This is especially annoying in online matches when you are trying to play quickly. If you move a unit into a fog of war tile and there is an enemy unit there the game should simply stop your unit 1 tile before so that you can quickly decide if you still want to move into that tile and attack that enemy unit that you can now see. PLEASE update this dear devs.Otherswise spectacular addition to the series.

review: I really enjoyed the game right up until it just stopped working. I'm a console player by nature. I used to play PC games back in the old days of original Doom and Command and Conquer but crashes and bugs that destory the experience are all too common place in the PC world. At least glitches and bugs on the console versions can be reverted with a simple re load without having to spend hours on possible solutions. I wanted to spend this space talking about how fun the game is how good it looks how it makes strategy accessible to intermediate level gamers how with a little trial and error it became one of the most addicting games I've played in years. But none of that matters when after a week and a half I just can't play the game. I launch it it starts and while still in black screen it crashes and asks if I want to submit the report. I spent 30 minutes trying to solve it and thought "this is ridiculous I'm not doing this". I've changed nothing on my computer. From what research I've done it's happened to enough people that it's a known issue with no universal solution. Unaccetpable. Guess I'll go back to consoles which is a huge shame.

Barbarians are way too aggressive. I find it better just to turn them off. It makes life less fustrating. I do like how they added the stacking/army feature from Civ Revolutions but it seems like a function that I rarely got to use. Other than that this is a copy and paste of Civ 5 with Civ 5 being the better of the 2 IMO.

review: WARNING This game will take your free time (and time that you should have spent accomplishing something) and MURDER it.That being said WOW. Just wow. After much insistance from my friends I picked this game up and it is the first Civ game that I've ever played. I didn't expect to like it because it just didn't seem like my style of game but I fell in love with it instantly. After a crushing defeat to my friends I was compelled to experiment in single player with all the different leaders and win conditions. I was blown away by just how deep this game is. It's very easy to pick up and play but you're always learning something new and honing your strategy(s). There's so much nuance and subtlety I love it. ALSO you learn how to play the game by PLAYING THE GAME! Yes! I hate tutorials I hate button prompts I hate spoon fed exposition. Fantastic game 9/10.

title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: tl dr Just play Civ V instead.Well I've been trying to love this game for 642 hours now (as opposed to 3532 hours wasted/enjoyed in Civ V). Some observations about this game as it stands alone now that the adjustment period from Civ V is out of the way AI's military tactics are still extremely weak. It does not assemble its units for advantage attack when it has the advantage or defend its cities effectively. You'd think a fundamental goal for any game like this would be to have fronts naturally develop as in a real life war. Nope. Scattered random skirmishes that the AI always loses. You can run the map with 1 2 infantry or cavalry units plus 1 artillery. Diplomacy mechanics bring nothing to the game. If you so much as defend yourself or retaliate against an aggressor as one does in war you're branded a warmonger. Were the Allies warmongers in WWII for conquering Germany? Leaders relentlessly spam you with their disapproval consuming ridiculous numbers of UI animation seconds before you can esc/cancel with each one. Despite claims that leaders approve of certain things it seems to be an either/or all or nothing hair trigger mechanism. A leader will love you one turn and denounce you the next because they expected you to have one more military unit that turn or something. There is no nuance spectrum or "scoring" to this system as far as I can tell contrary to the claim that there are several levels between "friendly" and "denounced." It's a waste of effort to try to get along with everyone while trying to win a science or cultural victory. Just let them inevitably declare war and fight them off. Firaxis has figured out how to make leader interactions annoy you further and waste even more of your time. Clearly you want to be spammed with an inconsequential 30 second message for "good job" "or "I hate you" several times each turn often interrupting your next click and wait an additional several seconds for it to respond to multiple Esc presses. The AI engine is SLOW. I've played on an i7 5930k and an i7 6850k and on both it takes up to a minute to process AI turns in late game. I think most hours spent playing this game are for the "please wait" stage. Why Firaxis cannot take advantage of parallel processing or cache possible scenarios in advance while you're taking your turn I do not know. There should at least be an option (or default) where other player moves have faster animations so that you can see what's happening without losing time without making all the animations bizarrely short like in quick combat. The lack of automated builders brings more tedium to the game than it does craftsmanship. In late game I really no longer care about the details of each city there are no real mistakes to be made and I do not want to micromanage every single tile of every single city on a standard to huge map. Keeping the charge mechanic on builders but adding an option to automate (or making it a technology like a "self reliance" civic) would probably still encourage early game caretaking while removing late game tedium. The game in general just feels slow and tedious. This is in no small part due to terrain penalties and weak road bonuses for unit movement. (And the fact you essentially can't deliberately construct roads military engineer roads are too expensive.) Even in the middle ages no it didn't take 20 years for a unit to cross a civilization. It takes a lot of the oomph and fun out of army mobilization when it's far more practical to move single powerful units against the weak AI than to assemble melee and archer units into a tactically appropriate formation. There's simply no reason to bother with a combined arms / blitzkrieg approach in this game. I like the districts mechanic in principle but it's not flexible enough. Districts should be removable at a cost or at the VERY least there should be more information displayed in early game about the future optimal options for each tile. It's really not fun to try to wing it and guess where it will be best to place an industrial commercial or theater district in the future before you can select those districts to see the adjacency bonuses. (Or for placing future wonders each of which have strict arbitrary requirements.) At the very least there should be some sort of filter (a lens?) to display all adjacency bonuses on a tile. Tile info popovers are slow and unreliable. Just show the dang info when I mouse over. I'm not afraid. At least make it so that mousing over a resource icon by accident doesn't prevent tile info from displaying until I leave the tile and reenter. Personally I think the air unit mechanics in this game feel awkward and unnatural. Why not just emulate real life instead? Carriers in real life can project power farther and to more places at once than allowed by the 2 short range aircraft as can air bases. Jet fighters intercept attacks like in Civ V. They don't sit there and take it. No cruise missiles or ballistic conventional weapons in this game? They do exist in real life... Also by the time you can build aerodromes and project significant air power you could far more easily have created 3 times as many land units of greater power. The air game seems to be rather pointless and is placed too late in the game in terms of military advancement. Air units are too weak for the time they take to acquire. Minor note you'd also think cheap surveillance or attack drones would be making an appearance by now. Nuclear weapons are thankfully a little more realistic in this game since they really ruin whatever land you'd like to conquer but at the same time you've got to ask of what use are they in the game? The AI never has a powerful enough conventional army where you'd need nukes to defend yourself. Since you can conquer all other civs with 3 army units it's foolish to nuke them first and ruin your takings. Best guess if you're trying to win a science or cultural victory you'd like to ruin everyone else's day? If you're in the mood to go for one of those victories initiating nuclear war doesn't really fit the bill. In my experience all games devolve into domination matches. As soon as someone attacks you (inevitable) you will have an army and be branded a warmonger for defending yourself. So you might as well remove the nuisance of neighboring civs who like to attack you. Nature then takes its course. Maybe this is a bit realistic but it doesn't exactly meet the 4x varied experience Firaxis is trying to accomplish. City state and liberation mechanics are flawed. There is no real way to defend an allied city state or even just to play peacekeeper. You're not notified that they are attacked and you are not given any casus belli for declaring war. War of liberation (after the fact) also doesn't seem to become available when it should. If you do liberate a city all your units are immediately expelled from that territory bizarrely and unnaturally disrupting your advance in a way that just wouldn't happen in real life. Takes the fun out of liberating that neighboring continent that had been conquered by a single civ liberating France as in WWII is literally impossible. So tired of hearing "best not to aid that city state" from other leaders. What are you talking about? I didn't aid any city state. Which one??? The tech/civic boost mechanic is neat but it makes games far too uneven. Either I hit all the boosts by the luck of the map and launch a moon landing or accidentally win a culture victory in 1700 or I'm tied up in a war for 500 years (in which I can't go on the offensive to end it or else become a warmonger) miss a lot of the boosts and discover petroleum in 1960.I fired up this game this morning on a sick day to pass the time and found that it's more fun to write this review than to sit through any more hours with the game. That should tell you something.
title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: I will be comparing this to past Civilization games.Lets Start off with how the game runs. The graphics are tuned down and given a more artistic style rather than the realistic style that Civilization V had. I get a Civlization Revolution feel when playing this game. With the dumbed down graphics the game runs smoother. The turns and movements run really seemlessly and its hard to even tell when it's your turn. That being said the game suffers from random crashes. Everytime I start a game an online game my friend crashes at least once due to a different problem each time. I even felt the wrath of crashing before I wrote this review. All this being said the game starts up quicker than past civ games but still rapes your ears with extremely loud music. If you can deal with the occasional crashes and the simpler art style then Civilization VI is your game.Next lets talk about the Content in the game. Civilization VI has 18 civilizations in total with the Aztecs being a preorder civ but available after the 90 day launch for free to play. Now to compare this to Civilization V after all its dlc was released there was 43 civs. Now obviously we can't compare an at launch game to a game that has gone through many dlcs and game updates. I expect Civilization VI to have th same amount of Civs after all its dlc has been released or maybe even more. 18 Civs is a good number and offers a wide variety of replayability since every civ plays differently. Whether you want to go to the conquest route that Germany offers you or the Cultural route France offers you every single one of your play styles is there.What did they add? So a lot of things have changed from past civ games. Civilization VI now has 2 trees to go down a Science and a Culture tree. With the addition of the Culture tree you know can specifically select which play style you want rather than rushing Science in order to get a cultural victory like in past Civ games. Tech such as Civil Service is now in the cultural tree. It now makes more sense. Another thing that was added was Amnenities and Housing. Amnenities has now replaced Happiness and works the same way. If your Amnitity is too low your production will slow down and your population can revolt. It seems though it's not as big of a concern as happiness was in Civilization V. Many a times did I have revolutions on my hand because my happiness was too low. There is also housing. Housing can affect how your population grows. If you don't have enough housing your population will slow to a halt and will not expand. Near mid game housing tends not be an issue due to the new Housing District which I will now talk about. One of the coolest things that has been added that was not in previous civ games is Districts. Districts can be built in a city and take the place of one tile and allow you to build specific buildlings. A Campus (Science) allows you to build universities and libraries. It also allows you to use a Great Scientist on it. Almost each resourse has a district. There is one for Housing Amenities Science Culture Gold Military and even production. The districts allow your city to look more diverse and be beautiful rather than the lands just be farms. Lastly I just want to talk about the AI. This is the thing that really drove me to make this review. The AI suck... They almost always hate you and will turn on you in a second. Civilizations have 2 traits that a player can try to appeal to and it determines whether or not they like you. I will use Rome as an example. Rome has 2 traits one is a set trait that he will alwyas have and one is a random trait. The set trait is Rome likes civlizations that expand. The unkown can be anything. It is the most difficult thing to appeal to more than one Civ because their traits all vary largely. There was a time that I become friends with a civ and then they denounced me the next turn. The AI are very unstable and Ghandi is stil a warmongering If you want a guarenteed win in Civilization VI go down the Militaristic path beacuse you will go to war with atleast 6 nations whether you are friendly or not. After reading all of this you're probably wondering if I recommend you buy it. Yes. I do recommend you pick this game up...when it's a cheaper price. The game isn't the $60 price tag for the issues it has. Maybe if the price goes down or they fix the issues that are present will I then recommend you go out and buy it now. But if you have Civilization V just stick with playing it.
title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: I like many other reviewers have played all versions of civ and a huge fan. I was not disappointed by Civ VI. The DLC is overpriced but i did buy it and i do like Australia. so you know i did buy it... it did cost as much as a coffee... so i skipped coffee that day. Government choices seem rather boring and has clear winners Builder +2 builds +2 to 4 More money for trade. who cares about the others.

review: So I've be playing all the civilization games since the first and was really looking forward to this latest installation in the series. Unfortunately this game is unfinished to the point where it's just not enjoyable. There are a lot of good things and good ideas but I'll just list what I think has be changed to make this a worthwhile game.1. AIThe main reason why the game is not enjoyable is the AI. Or rather the lack of it. And in a single player strategy game AI is everything. Some people complain about the diplomatic part of it (why did it declare war on me) but the big problem is on the unit tactical scale. It seems almost as if there is no tactical AI or coordination at all but instead the units just move one by one not really caring what the other units in the army does. The effect is comical and breaks the game. The AI will embark the army without protection of a navy and just wander around as cannonfodder. It will wander around cities without attacking because god knows why. It will get stuck in chokepoints and attack you with just one unit at a time. The missionaries will wander around in hordes of 10 or more because they all do the same calculation of which city to convert next. Etc. Etc. Basically the AI is at the level of a football team with 7 year olds where they all just run for the ball. The solution at the higher difficulties is to give ridiculous bonuses so that the AI can build neverending masses of 7 year olds but wheres the fun in that? You would be insulted if someone suggested that your football team should play a bunch of 7 year olds and you should be insulted by this.2. UIThe user interface feels unfinished and is lacking crucial features. There is for example no strategic list of all your units to get an overview where is the good old F3 screen? Or the F2 screen? And why can't I zoom out more? I pretty much always play at maximum zoom out because I can only fit like three cities in the window even then. And the part of the map that's been discovered but not visible is all virtually the same color good luck telling plains from desert. The mouse over time to get the tooltips on terrain etc. are ridiculously long. When people declare war there are no longer little icons so you can immediately see who declared on who. No they are bunched together so you have to view them one by one. Combine that with the mouse over time and combine again with a bug that forces you to redo the mouse over once you read a declaration and you've got yourself a nightmare. (You can fix this by pressing shift but that's not mentioned anywhere and why would I even have to press it to begin with)3. Cultural and religious victories...are just boring. Cultural is basically a competition of who can amass the most culture and tourism points. Religious is a competition of who can amass the most faith (and spam missionaries with it). It's too simple. At least add some more features like using faith and cultural influence to control enemy units or stage revolts and take cities or do espionage. Just something to make it feel like I can actually do something actively with my influence more than just add point after point.4. BuildersI always automated workers once my empire grew in the old games because micro managing them was boring. In civ 6 there is no automation of builders so you have to spend way to much of your precious game time building farms and mines. 5. CivilopediaIs lacking so much information that you need. There are not even any back and forward buttons. I find myself tabbing out and looking up stuff on the internet instead.6. Build times versus research timesFor me this has been an issue in many civ games but in civ 6 more than ever the build times are way too long compared to the research times. You may find yourself with AT infantry before you've even built your first crossbowman. The idea of the new heureka system is great but you'll never have time to actively pursue the boosts as you are steaming through the tech tree. 7. The tech treeLike I said the heureka system is great but sometimes the links are weird like building privateers to get boost for electricity or power plant to get ballistics? More of a problem is that there are much fewer links now so you can for example get to infantry without knowing about stuff like rifling or gunpowder. I mean come on.8. All the bugsThere also still quite a few bugs in the game. Every few hours the game just crashes and exits for no reason. The "Last built" text that you get in a city that just finished production is always wrong. I liberated a city state and now it's called "City state name" instead of Hong Kong. The list goes on.What the game doesn't necessarily need at this moment is more units and civilizations. Unfortunately that's what's going to come because that's how you sell DLC's I guess.(I know a bunch of these can be fixed by modding but my point is that I shouldn't have to resort to that)
title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: Civilization 6 is a masterpiece of systems. You think you hate it coming over from Civilization 5 but if you just let go of your preconceptions and expectations you'll find a great game.Pros + Many systems interacting together in interesting ways (e.g. Great People Housing Cities Amentities Eurekas City State bonuses/quests etc).+ Performs significantly better than Civ5 turn to turn.+ Civilizations/Leaders have more unique abilities/traits/buildings/etc.+ With the introduction of Eurekas and Increased requirement to build city projects the Science victory is not (always) a tedious wait machine.+ With the changes to the movement system having a scout actually feels necessary.+ Barbarians present a challenge if left unchecked/ignored but are easily dealt with (usually) once you learn how to deal with them (kill the scout).+ Civilizations seem less geared for a specific victory and more capable of taking on multiple victory conditions (usually).Cons UI is on the opposite side of Civ 5. The previously mentioned systems that make the game great also make the game more complex (but still not EU4 level complex at least). Religious bonuses feel very weak and in turn religion feels very weak. And therefore civilizations who have religious focused traits feel like they have worthless aspects to their traits (but don't necessarily feel worthless themselves). AI is still stupid.
title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: After putting in about 1500 hours at the time of writing this I think it's safe to say I can write a somehwat informed review (because I have opinions and I like to share them that's why). I'm no veteran Civ player I've only played 5 and 6 though I'm aware that 3 and 4 are still good games. However even coming from 5 which had it's own disappointing launch 6 is a massive drop in depth and quality. No matter how hard I try I cannot lose myself in this game the way I did in 5. I'm never on edge wondering what will happen next because I know what'll happen next. War. War for settling wrong. War for being the wrong religion. War for governing wrong. War for being too strong and too week (at the same time). War for not trading. War for simply existing in a manner that doesn't quite suit somebody else. What seems to be an attempt to inject some personality to diplomacy with "agendas" results in predictable games where everyone hates you or everyone loves you (until they don't). There's never a middle ground.On agendas certain civs simply don't play themselves as they should. Hey Brazil I see you've denounced literally everyone on Earth for making more great people than you. Would you like to change that? Maybe build a campus or theater square? No? Just gonna build another encampment? Thought so. Nice to meet you China. No I didn't realize you were the preemminent builder of wonders in the world. Do you know why? It's because you never built one China that's why. Ah Cleopatra I see you're now chronically indecisive as you simultaneously hate and love large militaries and simply can't make your mind up. These agendas will override everything else you do with/to another civ. If you are friends with America and watch helpless as the Aztecs burn and pillage their way across the continent you might be inclined to pitch in on good ol' America's behalf. But more fool you because you see America hates people who declare war on his neighbours even if those neighbours are currently enslaving his own people and turning his cities to ash. A man's got to have a code after all. Now you're a warmonger. Why? Good question but it's ok Alexander the Great still loves you.The next part of my rant jamboree is the design of the game such as unit scaling and modelling and such. Before the game was launched there were many people who expressed concern over a "mobile game" aesthetic justly concerned that 2K might be trying to grant their next installment with some more mass appeal at the expense of anyone being able to take this seriously. Thankfully the gameplay hasn't been dumbed down so much as screwed up (see agendas). I am not terrified of this army of strangely proportioned stretch armstrong figures marching towards me because I'm too distracted by the trader whose cart is 2 or 3 times taller than my palace. In Civ 5 when the Mongol horde was at my borders it stretched on and on like well a horde. Now it appears to be maybe 20 horses all together each being roughly the size of an entire building and altogether looking rather silly. If course there's another reason not to be intimidated by the Mongol horde or anyone else's horde for that matter. The entire combined forces of all other AI civs could be beaten back with a damp rag and a can do attitude.The AI in Civ 6 cannot war which is particularly damning in a game that always ends in a war. Alexander the Great of Macedon may command the most fearsome force known to man but rest assured it'll be soundly defeated by simply doing the following ranged units + garrion promotion place in city centres and encampments. Or just wait them out when you think the enemy has gained the advantage they'll just sit there and contemplate life or throw themselves away on fortified units with ranged support. It's worth pointing out that at launch the AI did not even know how to use boats or planes so I wouldn't hold your breath or anyone elses for any of this to change any time soon.I will now try to think of some nice things to say about Civ 6. You can use mods in multiplayer games fairly easily. See that overpowered civ from your favorite TV show that was obviously made by a fan with no thought to game balance? Yup you can bring that into a game with your friends and make them regret basking in your presence. The most fun I've managed to have in this game has been with friends where the only real competition in science culture faith and of course war are the other human players. The AI might aswell be so many other city states. Oh and the music. While I miss wartime music (listening to the cheerful Kongo theme while nuclear hellfire engulfs the planet is a bit jarring) the whole idea of music evolving with eras is just fantastic. Entering the industrial era to "Scotland the Brave" blaring in your ears while you agressively bagpipe the inferior nations of the world into submission is satisfying to say the least. But then you realize that you're building the same cities all over the map and that the last game you tried to get into was the same as this one and that enemy you've been contending with isn't really contending so much as falling behind because he decided to give up on winning. And then everyone denounces you for being close to winning yourself. And then I get tired of this and try and get Civ 5 to work again with a bagillion mods.(oh yeah and districts aren't that special I always end up building the same 2 or 3 different cities with no variation)(I'll stop typing now I am very tired)EDIT I have so many hours played in this game because of friends who used to enjoy playing it. As they lost interest I lost interest. There were other mods I used that also made it fun which are no longer usable since the summer patch (I think it might have been the spring one I can't remember). I cannot reccomend this game because it does not stand up on it's own as a civ game should. Time and time again the modding community has found and fixed bugs that should have been dealt with before release. Maybe the next big dlc will make Civ6 a game worthy of the franchise I don't know. Until such a time I do not think anyone should buy this game. That is my opinion and I am entitled to it no matter how many hours I have played or whether or not I "got my money's worth".(While I understand where some people are coming from with the "you played a bunch but didn't like it so why did you play it" mentality I would not take any review seriously with few hours played regardless of wether they reccomended it or not. If my friends came with the game in a sort of package deal then sure I'd reccomend it but I got them elsewhere)
title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: The Game would be amazing without so many bugs. There has been a problem with saved games your money being stolen to a negative number and cant go back to positive unproportionate amount of oils just to name a few.To have bought this for 105 CAD im a bit disappointed.
title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: Base game only 164.6 hours at time of review.If you really loved Civ 5 you'll probably love Civ 6. With the last few Civ games they have been somewhat lacking upon release only becoming complete when all of the DLC is released. Civ 6 feels pretty well polished at release though there are some problems. The AI needs to be tweaked it feels seemingly random some of the decisions the AI makes. Diplomacy is a shambles though it has improved a little in the fall patch. There is a lack of playable civ's compared to the post DLC number of civ's in Civ 5. If you didn't pre order you don't get the Aztec civ which is a really bad move by the developers/publishers. One can only hope they release the Aztecs for free later on down the line. This is all sounding a bit negative but as with the last few games the game has gotten a lot better and more complete with DLC so I have great hope the flaws will get fixed. That said I really like Civ 6 even now.It has another great soundtrack. The art style I was a bit dubious about from watching the trailers but it looks and feels great.Gameplay wise I've played 164 hours in about 3 4 weeks. The unique units/buildings for the different civ's are great you could say they could use a bit more balancing but I disagree. Germany has amazing industrial capacity Greece has really good cultural buffs Russia has good religeon buffs. It all depends on what style of victory you want to aim for. Even so some civs feel a bit too powerful at times.Overall I give this 8/10. If you love Civ I highly recommend you pick up the digital deluxe version and you will get the soundtrack and the next few DLC will be free.

title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: It's seems like Firaxis knew what they were doing here they took everything great about Civ V and polished it. Then they took mechanics that were good and completely revamped them making them more detailed nuanced and intuitive. Finally they just threw in a whole bunch of new crap that resulted in a reborn fully realized Civ that is WAY beyond what I was hoping for.That said there are a few sticking points and not all of the new strategies and mechanics are explained well. Some are a complete mystery though I wonder if that's intentional. But my issues are tiny compared to the quality of the game and an hour into my first game I found myself even preferring the vibrant art style to Civ V. (An acquired taste that took a blessedly short time to acquire.)Way to step up Firaxis. You guys could have rebranded 5 and made a buttload of money but instead you raised the bar and made something completely worthy of the series. Many sleepless nights ahead for me I can tell.
title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: Good.
title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: This is bittersweet for me. I'm sure the new features and game mechanics will prove to be excellent additions to the Civ Legacy I have faith in the development team to move the series forward in these areas. The only reason I have for not reccomending it is admittedly a pretty shallow one (especially for a 4X title) but one that has left me currently unable to enjoy the game...The art style.It is im my opinion horrific. It's farily obvious that the style is evocative of Clash of Clans et al and an attempt to tap into the popularity of these games to attract a new demographic of potential players (and to make mobile and console ports much easier and quicker). The rights or wrongs of this approach are an interesting area of debate however from my own point of view it leaves a game that in its current visual state I have no interest in playing.I am fully aware that I have not played nearly enough of the game to comment on its mechanics or improvements and equally aware that criticising a game only because of its visuals is considered unfair in the extreme. This does not change the fact that as it stands I will not be playing Civ VI and without a major overhall or excellent mod I won't be playing it for a long time.

title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: I rarely review a game but I think Civ VI deserves it. It's a very good Civ genre representative (kind of back to Civ II with all the props of newer Civs). There is almost nothing not to love about it whether you are a newcomer or an old veteran.Pros + Fast Paced game+ Strategic choices (unless you play as that get all type of guy)+ Economy and Tourism+ It's a Civ! )Pros/Cons+/ You cannot close borders on those pesky apostles and prophets which gives the game another dimension next to military and economy but is annoying when you don't care about religion that much. (Luckily mods can change this).Cons AI when you learn to play well you will end up at war with rest of the world in first 50 100 turns ) AI makes a lot of dumb moves like settling near you or moving troops near you but penalizes you for same moves (so let it be War!)
title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: Product received for free. I hate reading big blocks of text so I'm not gonna waste your time by belaboring any specific point. The AI is very badI don't care how many catapults and knights you have you're not competing with my modern armors. The AI seems to be bad at upgrading their units among many other things. (Perhaps there needs to be a change in how overall army strength is calculated.)Expanded diplomacy is goodThe AI is better about letting you know how they feel about you why and when these changes take place. Being able to flat out ignore requests is nice compared to being forced to respond. "Hey move your troops" "I'm going to pretend I never got that message" One thing the AI was good at was dencouncing me for constantly ignoring their demands to move my troops.Eureka/inspirations are very goodThey give constantly keep you engaged by giving you objectives to speed things along. They encourage you to explore many of the game's features.Expanded spying is very goodPeeking as someone's city screen and taking their techs was nice but stealing great works and money recruiting rebels sabotaging production and more? Not only that but expanded promotions for spies? COUNT ME IN!!!Interchangeable social policies is very goodOne thing I disliked in Civ V was that your early choice of starting social policies had super long lasting effects and you sometimes had to adpot them before you were certain about how you wanted to play. The ability to switch out policies gives you flexibility letting you respond to the events of the game.Information era needs expansionNo death robots? Seriously?No progress notifications for culture victoriesI beat a friend in a multiplayer game because he didn't see my culture victory sneak up on the world. There are notifications for science victory steps and captured capitals but no indication of culture victory progress unless you check the menu yourself.I'm recommending this game because it's pretty darn fun despite the flaws and I hope these issues get fixed. Sure the AI sucks but playing with a few friends makes games more interesting.

title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: My friends and I consider Civ V to be something of a modern classic. The game was just close to perfect and we were waiting for Civ VI for the series to truly come into perfection or at least come closer to it. The results are mixed. The graphics and the UI have been improved for example. Religion and culture are now easier to digest because of it. More importantly new mechanics like districts and agendas have been added to add complexity to the game and these new features mostly succeed. Civ VI is familiar but fresh an interesting new iteration to a franchise with trademark mechanics. But certain flaws have been amplified as well. The AI are all delusional psychopaths. Winning in singleplayer at Prince difficulty is an absolute joke. Usually a nearby civ will declare war on you when he or she is clearly unprepared and will then dubious tactics in fighting you. You will more or less inevitably win their cities and the rest of the game will be too easy to bother with. Diplomacy is also very limited. You cannot take out loans for example an action which is basic in real life diplomacy between state actors and has the potential to make things very interesting. The diplomacy has also now become very opaque. They are trying to make interactions with AI more realistic but they have only succeeded in making diplomacy with psycopaths somehow harder than it already is. The fact that the AI is terrible makes any kind of interaction with them ridiculous in nature and trying to approach them rationally is a waste of time. It is better to ignore them or harass them at your advantage. Trying to gain their favor is nearly useless especially when they're so bad that you can take them over at any time.However the story is very different in terms of diplomacy with city states. It has been streamlined and a screen pops up whenever you can send envoys (which you use instead of money to influence city states) so you don't have to go up and down the map looking for them. Several improvements like this along with innovations such as the civics tree keep this offering from being completely a waste. You have a separate "technology tree" that deals with policies which are cards that you can use to give several kinds of benefits. These cards are put in slots. The number of slots for military economic and diplomatic cards (as well as a wildcard slot) depend on the type of government you lead and the types of government are also unlocked through the civ tree. I thought this addition along with the districts is the most compelling and the best evidence that the series has advanced. Civs can now be more tailor made to your playstyle and preferences as well as according to your current needs.Several annoyances have made it here as well. Reports your spies and merchants make block the screen when you start your turn and there is no way to remove them manually. You have to wait for them to disappear. There's an excessive lag between when you read a message from another civ and the appearance of the button to exit. Unit scrolling is literally the worst thing ever. God forbid someone try to join your multiplayer game because you will have a bad time.Civ VI is certainly not a "triumph." Not yet. I am hopeful for the future through updates and DLCs. For now this is a solid foundation and a nice and interesting game. And one more thing Teddy Roosevelt did not have such a whiny voice.

title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: I have played this game for 5 hours nonstop now so here's my two cents. The game is really good in comparison to some of the other civilization installments. Beyond Earth for example doesn't even compare to this. The new mechanics are really pleasing. Now when you want to build something you have to build the specific district which will have a list of building options. This is in contrast to the earlier civilization games where you could just build your buildings. Districts also take up space so you need to manage the land a little bit more. The biggest difference in this game is for me is the technology. Now there are Eurekas in the game that speed up your research. So what do you have to do to get these Eurekas you ask? Well... You have to complete the specific task prior to or during researching the specific technology. For people like me who try to build science buildings to rush a science victory it really makes them have to allocate resources differently. I was behind in science in my game even when focusing on science only because I didn't do the Eureka boosts. Overall very good game and with a few dlcs and mods it will be a masterpiece.

title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: Great game really enjoying playing this version. Districts add a new level of depth and strategy as you cant just build every thing you want. The same with wonders you have to prioritse what your city needs.There is lots of complaints about the AI and i do agree to some extent that it needs slight improvement as the AI does not attack or defend well. Hopefully this will be fixed.The new restrictions on growth through housing and amenities as recieved alot of stick but i think this is a great feature because again it brings a new level of strategy to your city planning utilising every tile to its maximum potential to ensure steady growth.Builders now only have 3 improvements before disappearing again brings another level of strategy.The AI seems more aggressive in the early and mid game which again seems to be taking alot of stick however this is more a true representation of what it took to build a great civilization at that point of time. Wars where always inevitable and if you go into the lead on this game the AI is coming after you.The negatives for me are the fog of war which is very bland AI needs fine tuning to help make them a greater threat.Overall 9/10 This game is great for civ veterans but for newcomers its gonna be a steep learning curve cant wait too see what they do with dlc's in the future
title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: A brilliant addition to the Civ collection. Compared to previous games the general gameplay means that strategy is more important than ever before. The AI has improved from Civ 5 and the music is epic.
title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: Needs work not worth buying yet.Civ V veteran here at least 1K hours in to Civ5 plus expansions. This game doesn't feel fully baked barbarians are frankly way over tuned the game forces a large military on you which is costly in gold and you don't have time to even learn the game ( I set this to chieftain and no less than 4 Units harrassing my territories repeatedly. ) before barbarians on easy mode come knocking down your tile and district improvements. You can't learn the new game mechanics before some assload of barbarians come ing up your life and to boot your borders mean all to barbarians there is no early city defense that you can use so tough if you are an expansionist or wanted to explore the map you are going to constantly be spending early game resources on ing barbarians. 1.) Bring back earlt game city defense (So that your borders aren't crossed like they don't even exist. 2.) Barbarian units are way to strong early and too numerous even on easy settings. 3.) review: Over all I think Civ 6 is a nice addition to the franchise. I am a huge fan of the districts and eureka moments they make the over game play feel more meaningful and requiring more thought than previous installations where you end up doing the same thing repeatedly. Initially I was taken aback by the new artwork more cartoon like and bright vivid colors. In the end I m pretty happy with the choice and really enjoy how the terrain mixes and forms a developed landscape as the game goes on. The city states are a little more beneficial compared to civ V and worth keeping around even if they can t seem to take their military out of the stoneage. There are however some issues with the game. Over all it seems easier than Civ 5. This might be in part because of the AI. As many people have mentioned the AI is rather sluggish in later era s with its military often fielding units from several eras prior. The AI also seems to be very lazy with improving its territory leaving several lucrative bonus resources unimproved late into the game. The AI also can t seem to handle the district bonuses very well building districts in poor locations when there are far superior locations within the city limits. These issues might make the game seem easier than Civ V since it benefits the player who can plan long term handsomely. Overall I still enjoy playing the game and hopefully they can get the AI working more efficiently with the new game mechanics introduced.

Overall I am confident that upcoming patches dlc and mods will complete the experience! Think of it as a really thick frame with only room for a small picture but the picture is missing.

title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: I have played Civ from version I to the present so I start as a fan. Every new version has annoyed me a little because it changed the game. Having said that with 2k hours on Civ V it seems the changes are something I get used to then adapt to over time then come to enjoy. Civ VI is no different for me. Is this your old Civ V game with updated graphics? No it is a complete redo of the overall game engine in many ways. It is truly fun though. Great gaphics new ways to accomplish things and overall a good time. I like the fact it is different because I can still go back to Civ V when I want. Winning via domination is harder but do able. War is downplayed a bit in this version and I do miss the giant death robots what can I say. Culture seems a bit easier to win and science I have not achieved. I like to make my own religion B.A.M brothers from another mother that is pretty cool. My first victory was cultural even though I was just a few cities away from domination. Another area I really enjoy is new natural wonders. I have looked up many of the locations I have found and learned some new beatiful places I would like to visit some day. Kudos for the geography lesson. What needs to be fixed is the AI. The denouncing you for no reason gets very annoying. Begging for the riduculous trades is a pain. At this point the game still need a little tweaking in that area alone. but is still very very fun and I will work to go through all the achievments as I have done with Civ V. Honestly though who cares I am not trying to be their buddy I am going for world domination. No matter what you do your going to make them mad because they figure your winning. Even in Civ V the whole blue jeans denouncment comes from a peaceful cultural victory. In Civ V you got denounced for spreading religion as well so I don't find it to be all that big of a deal. I am not here to make buddies but do be the most dominate civilization so yes I am going to break some eggs and they are going to be moody.

title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: Consider this a luke warm recommendation with strong cautions. If you enjoy battling it out down to the last min/maxed resource against a capable AI this game is not for you. Why? Because the AI is sloppy and clueless. If you enjoy developing an empire building your cities calculating the risks and rewards of build and expansionn strategies and having neighbors that get in your way and wage futile war against you you'll enjoy this game. Why? Because city building requires attention districts adjacencies terrain perks amenities and city state systems all work well. But and it's a doosy there's no diplomacy to speak of in the game so you're better with Europa Universalis if that's your thing. There are some really fabulous annoyances in Civ 6 that mean you have to have patience with developers who ignore important QoL things. Prime example? The "create game" option doesn't remember your settings. Which means if you have a highly ideal set of parameters and you're looking for a good start be prepared to input those settings over and over again. Otherwise create game will give you a completely vanilla set up. The AI is really clueless. Example. You have just discovered aluminum. Every single Civ that has anything to trade you will ask you to give it this rare resource. That's okay on the face of it. But if you are leading the tech race they will still ask you for it even if they are an age or two behind you and can't build a single unit with it and wouldn't be able to withiin the 30 turns it is available to them since resources do not stockpile. Then there's the dreaded warmongering penalty. The warmongering penalty is a hideous mind game the devs put into the game to torture you. What is this penalty? Having every single civ pop up frequently and lay hate on you. Imagine a game repeatedly telling you "I hate hate hate you!" That's Civ 6. There is no way to avoid this penalty except not playing the game. As a consequence of the warmongering penalty diplomacy is futile. There's no point in trading with civs gifting them stuff they need being nice to them in any way or forming alliances with them. There is literally no diplomacy at all in the game worth engaging in. The vaunted "hidden agenda" of a civ is just that they have a sneaky way of being able to denounce you and pop up routinely to hate you. Civs will turn against you on a dime declare war and remain angry for an extended time and there is no cure for that. And just so we're clear about how useless diplomacy is in the game there is no diplomatic victory condition. But you say being an experienced 4x gamer there must be a penalty against your civ to this warmongering penalty? Hahaha. No. There isn't. Except the aforementioned hate torture. If you don't mind it (and can't escape it anyway) you can gleefully wage war against the AI and predictably win. They aren't going to like you no matter what you do. There's also the religious scrum. When the AI sends a gazillion religious units against you flooding your tiles relentlessly. This is extremely annoying. You can get a good laugh out of it though by turning off Religious Victory. As you can see there are some strong reasons to not buy this game particularly if you are an experienced 4Xer who enjoys diplomacy or an able AI contest. But if you're just interested in spending a good many hours exploring building and expanding then Civ 6 will fit the bill. It's a pleasant game with enough intricate systems to grasp to be enjoyable for a number of games. At the point where it is no longer a challenge then you're ready to graduate to Civ 5.

review: Fantastic! Civ VI is everything Civ V should of been and much much more. When it was first announced I was like many a bit skeptical. Civ V broke a few hearts and it took me a long time and two major updates to really enjoy it. So with the coming of Civ VI I was dreading the prospect of another dissapointing sequal. However once I started watching a few pre release gameplay vids on Youtube I knew that this looked very promising. Then on the day of release my first game proved that it was a stunner! I love all the changes espcialy the district system so inspired by Endless Legends. The game feels almost perfect and has had plenty of playtesting. When the biggest dissapointment in the game is that I couldnt rename cities (which has now been fixed) then you know the game is a winner!There are a few tiny things that I dont like but these are very minor and I feel like a nitpicker for mentioning them so I wont P All in all a great game and a great sequal to one of the best games of all time. Just buy it already.

title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: Hey guys! I've been scrolling through the reviews lately and have found a mixed amount of comments which argue about the pros and cons of Civ VI. Be warned though! The following are my thoughts and my thoughts alone in regards to the Civ series after playing many multiplayer and single player games. Also not going to mention expansions because they don't bother me. Like what kind of expansion do you want? I am almost tempted to say that the base game has everything I need... Oooooo actually I wish for the choice of doing colony management!! Like how if I'm settling too far and they become sick of me they can ask for independence!! Perhaps even enslavement of people from other civs ) Sorry that's just my wish not actually part of the review ) MwahahahaBack on track now.I've played both Civ V and Civ VI for a while now and have loved it for as long as I remember playing games. Civ V was the first game that I ever bought and played with my money. I loved it but also hated it. Civ V became too dull predictable and repetitive extremely quickly. Although I say this I'm still one of the people who always wish for one more turn. Civ V had a problem where it involved a lot of wonder spamming and the civs that build the first few wonders tend to be the ones that manage to push on quickly enough to win the game. Civ V beginning strategies involve finding a place next to the river mountain and probably a coast. Then it proceeds to build a monument and locking your production on food. This happened every game and it doesn't matter which civ you choose as long as you follow this path. It made it especially frustrating during multiplayer games where everyone is following the same strategy. Multiplayer aside the world congress mechanic was broken. In single player veteran players would simply have to buy out the city states and voila the world is essentially yours. In multiplayer this mechanic works slightly better. However you can easily get destroyed the moment someone like Venice/Greece decides to buy out all the city states and have complete control over world religion and world ideology. This can be devastating for your civ and I've had friends who would fight over a game either due to the wonder spree jealousy or world congress mechanics.When I first played Civ VI I had my doubts. The graphics looked different and weird. The way culture science and so one worked completely differently. I like how you can gain extra science and culture through discovery and completing specific projects rather than just beelining for the specific techs which you know will give you an advantage even though it's completely useless in your scenario (Such as getting advances in boat tech because you live on the coast.) It was better than Civ V where you discover how to sail even though there's no water on the map and city states would like the great lighthouse too. With time I developed a real liking and respect for the game. With the new district system the Civ game allowed me to plan how to build my empire how to specialise and at times how to make money... Gold can sometimes be a big pain in the bum... As you play the game you even learn a lot about real life civilizations and society where everything is interconnected to a certain extent and you can't have one without another. You learn how to work with the AI and not be a pain in the bum. These simple changes to me made the game feel much more balanced unpredictable and different each time both in single player and especially in multiplayer. Housing and Amenities VS Global happiness and No Growth Limit. Mmmm this is a fascinating one. I felt that global happiness sucked... I hated it... Global happiness is too uncontrollable/manageable/reasonable/predictable/(Not)understandable. You can have two cities with luxury resources and all happiness buildings and still be unhappy... WHY!?!? Housing and Amenities in Civ VI were VERY tough to enjoy at the very beginning but it did become easier to enjoy and love in the end because it was understandable and manageable. Next!!! The AI system can be improved as many people have stated already. AI in Civ VI especially at higher difficulties would occasionally forward settle you and be angry whenever you try to settle another city. This of course has annoyed me for quite a bit throughout many games. However I do remember the same happening in Civ V. People say that the Civ VI AI is unpredictable and chaotic in comparison to the Civ V AI which is predictable to a certain extent... Where's the challenge if I can just predict the AI anyway?? Civ VI AI is more chaotic and sporadic but once you understand the mechanics of the AIs having two individual agendas they become easy to comprehend and just be a good friend (Not being an and sending troops near their borders. Civ V AI in general has a lot less to do in comparison to the Civ VI AI. One has to hate the world and anyone who settles near him/her and the other has some hidden variables which you can exploit and see results in time. All in all the developers can DEFINITELY improve on the AI which we have to be mindful is a challenging project. I've studied programming before and understand that building an AI isn't just saying "Is he cool? Yes? Cool friends. Did he just shoot me? War please )" Finally! Nah I'm done. Feel free to comment on my first review ever XD. I hope this helps you. Like I said before I used to be the biggest Civ V lover but it's safe to say that I've converted over to Civ VI. There's a lot to love about both games but I felt that Civ VI is more balanced and advanced both in single and multiplayer. I know there are definitely players out there who have played the series longer than I have and have a different understanding from me. These are what I felt when I played in single and multiplayer of both games. I feel that if you are on the fence about this game watch some games on youtube and perhaps ask to play on your friend's copy for a bit. Reviews are useful but in the end you know what you like only after you try it. I'm much happier with Civ VI than V and these reviews wouldn't have helped me make my decision. P.s. If you developers are reading this my ideas about colonies and enslavement isn't a must ') I actually had this interest because I played a game called Stellaris and thought that Civ would become an extremely interesting game with this mechanic. I've followed your Civ VI development from beginning to now and keep up the good work! I love the game!

title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: As it currently stands CiVI is a game with well crafted gameplay mechanics numerous minor bugs / brainfarts and an AI that disappoints.Absolutely loved the way the game handles its economical side this is a definite upgrade from what I experienced with CiV the civic government and amenity housing systems keep the decisionmaking surprisingly fresh all the way to the end. Great persons tailored to different timings and victory conditions are an interesting twist which adds to the game planning in a good way. Stacking more than 1 military unit to corps / armies work fine although the increased military strength from stacking feels currently a bit weak the major reason to do it at the moment is upkeep cost.The AI left me with a half disgusted feeling with "why you do dis". You know that feeling when the only positive modifier ally with no other friends in the game turn insane and backstab me with classical era units vs tanks just because I'm about to snatch a science victory or when Roosevelt first agrees to pay me for a joint war and then nags me about declaring wars on his continent or when they talk their personal agenda related things that just feel.. unrealistic. Why would England suddenly tell me I tread dangerous waters with their colonies when they a) have 0 colonies and b) we have had 0 interaction except sending a trader and opening borders. Also why the f*** does Rome still declare holy wars to me for converting all his cities over thousand years ago? I don't think modern day Iran declares holy wars because someone converted them from majority Zoroastrianism over 10 generations ago.I guess the way AI remembers history or plays to win and not to preserve itself is not an actual issue if you consider CiVI as a board game with permanent players rather than leaders that evolve along with the history of the world. To me this is disappointing.I did not even start to speak about the way AI manages wars. The unit management is a tough part for even human players to optimize but the AI seems to be utterly incapable of conquering cities vs civs that should be overran in terms of pure military strength. In one out of 6 games did I see an AI actually overrun another and never did they manage to grab a city from me if I had even a minor defensive army around. Also a valid offensive strategy for human players vs AI is to declare a war from defensive positions and wait for the AI to waste all its units against your fortresses.After trying out all different victory types on Emperor difficulty racking in 90hrs of gameplay I can say that I won't be returning back to the game until the AI or diplomacy is improved or the SDK released.Nevertheless the game deserves a 4/5 grade for its gameplay mechanics alone. Worth the money and fun but the lack of meaningful AI starts to hurt after a while. Also a plethora of minor annoyance things (such as traderoute and spy micromanagement) could drop the rating to 3/5 if you're feeling unforgiving.
title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: I recommend any game that make me play 20+ hours and so I ofc recommend Civ 6. One major improvement is how it handle mods they are easily imported and activated by default and it seems to be easier to make stable mods in Civ 6 than Civ 5. However there are flaws there are several ways to victory one that defeated me in my first game on the easiest difficult lvl on the smallest map vs one opponent Egypt was religious victory. Before I had even made a swordsman I was suddenly swarmed by missionaries and lost becuse the Egypt religion became dominating. So be careful with open borders...But the BIG flaw I really saw when it comes to war I did see when I had AI only game with all starter Civs (no Aztecs) on the biggest World map out there. Starting Age Renassaince true starting locations domination victory only. I followed it from 1500 to year 1750 before I got to bed. Greece was a dominating force in Europe Egypt and Kongo split Africa with Spain in one corner. Brasil was better at expanding than USA China and India all nations with plenty of room to expand and barbarians to fight. So when I checked the game again it was 1932 and to my... annoyance? there seemed to have been very little progress. More citys had been added but no borders had been moved because of war and it was not because of lack of war the AI is simply incompetent of doing sustained war at the moment it seems even the smallest nations were still around. And first I thought the science had been screwed up because there were a lot of units around but the land units were mostly crossbowman and muskeeters and the sea units were frigattes. But looking around I found units like infantery and ironclads but they were few indeed. A Civ 5 game would never have turned out like this and I think it comes down to how ranged attack has been nerfed and that stacking is back because what I saw was these old units stacked in armies with 3 musketeers forming a unit that could go to toe with far progressed single units. And upgrading armies are costly because you need money to upgrade three units at once so the AI doesn t bother. In Civ 1 4 games you had artillery and bombers to deal with stack of units because such attack could weaken several units in the stack at once that isn t the case here because it count as one big unit.Put this togheter and you have a pretty stale war game there science progress isn t nearly as important as it was in Civ 5. Production is the King and religion is much more important now.
title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: If you enjoyed Civilization V you will enjoy this game although you should expect quite a bit of a learning curve for the first few plays. This is because the game's mechanics are significantly altered compared Civ V to the point that they may be outright confusing if you go in expecting this to just be the same old game. Having said that there is so much to love because of all the changes that make the game so much more fun and challenging from start to finish.The only downside was the AI being a bit simple and a whole bunch of minor annoyances like the inability to name cities and UI issues but the latest update is a hefty one and fixes pretty much all of these even shakes those up AI behaviour issues. With these kind of updates the outlook is incredibly good for Civ VIHighly recommeded!

review: Although one of the strongest base Civ games I've played (playing since IV) there are many downright silly omissions. The biggest for me is the lack of a "restart" button to reroll for map generation you have to manually input ALL setting over again from the main menu if you don't like your start location. The result is you spending 30 60 minutes just trying to get a decent map. Further there are fewer map options than Civ 5 like the mostly Artic mostly Desert or other more niche maps are gone. The interface takes some getting used to compared to Civ 5 and barbs definitely need tweaking as they're overpowered but overall a good game. If they don't fix the reroll feature and bring back the map customization I think this will be a shortlived game for me
title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: Civilization IV 6 is more than 5.++ Culture has been revamped its now retooled into a branching tree much like science. Advancing in culture means unlocking new government types policies and certain wonders and buildings its a big improvement over the way culture is handled in 5.++ The new districts system allows you build towards the way you want to play with a bunch of positioning and adjacency bonuses. If you do a little planning ahead you can get some very optimized outputs. Its an improvement. ++ The way wonders are handled is arguably alot fairer now. You have to give up a tile per wonder built so you can't just stack wonders all into a single city like you could in prior games (you can still do it but you're probably going to have to plan growth a bit more carefully)++ The city states system is a total improvement no longer will you have to keep throwing gold at them just so they'll like you.+ There's a day/night cycle which you can enable in the options menu which is very easy on the eyes.+ Each AI civ has particular likes Trajan of Rome likes expansive empires that fight barbarians Harald Hardrata of Norway likes civs who have a strong navy and high cultural output etc. This allows you to make naturally aligned alliances with other civs (Or know how exactly to antagonize or provoke a war with other civs.) You can make national parks in the later half of the game a four tile area of un improved land that creates tourism and provides amenities. (They replaced "happiness" with "amenities".) There's different critical kill animations and the animation for the infantry crit killing an opponent is him jumping behind the opponent while turning mid air and shooting them in the head mid air no scope.+/ Transitional units like the longswordsman are no more.+/ Stacks are back (sort of) combine ships to make 'fleets' infantry 'corps' etc.( ) I don't think the music is quite as good as in 5. Its not bad but its more generic.( ) You're going to have to adjust to the UI a bit. There needs to be more natural wonders I'm tired of seeing the dead sea. Mvemba a Nzinga of the Kongo is almost always mad at you.I was wary of Civ 6 but after playing it I feel its a big step up from Civ 5.(Also they fixed the crazed AI in a patch just recently they're less blood thirsty now.)The only thing left now is to wait for the game to be opened up to the steam modding community.
title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: Innovative changes have been made throughout large areas of the game to create the best CIV launch experience we've ever seen.
