review: Really like what they were attempting to do with all of the mechanics but it falls so flat on it face due to the combat system being so simple and so easy. I should not be able to beat the game on the hardest difficulty on the first try within the first 15 hours of playing the game.That being said with a few tweaks and patches it has the bones to be decent game the civic vs science trade routes and new districts are very interesting although the diplomacy system also leaves something to be desired. Not worth full price just wait to pick it up in 6 7 months when it goes to 10 bucks and they have had the time to work out all of the kinks.
title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: This game really is a pure display how die hard fans of franchises are hard to accept any change in some franchise. I personaly have played Civilization games since first one and I find these changes applied to Civ VI great. I have no problems with graphics of a game who are rather pleasent to eye I especialy like how fog of war is done in style of old sea maps. Really is sad thing that this game had so much thumbs down and I really cant understand why. Main change in this Civilization it that one that you dont build cities in one hex but now you build districts so you cities expand and some new buildings are build in specific districts (militiary academy is built in solider district) and plus some districts can have bonuses depending where they are placed and also some had to be posinitoned on proper position (aquadact has to be placed near water source)Al in all this game really is one of best edition in Civilization franchise and I am only sad that I see lot of die hard fans of franchise giving it thumbs down from all wrong reasons.Plus we all forget on all new players who never played civ game before I do find this game is really great welcoming game for new comers to the franchise too.
title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: Let's look at the most talked about topics of the game ContentIs Civ 6 more fleshed out than Civ 5? No. Of course not. Do you remember how long it took for Civ 5 to actually become good? But does that mean it's bare bones? Far from it. This feels like a Civ that's already had expansions added to it. Something that I think needs to be said is this When Civ 5 released I didn't enjoy it at all. I went back to Civ 4 almost immediately. Now that Civ 6 is released I honestly can't go back to Civ 5. The improvements to the city building system midgame pace and simple but effective art style have drawn me in and I can't go back now.Short answer The features &amp improvements Civ 6 provides outshine it's faults.AIIs the AI bad? Mostly. Basically what it comes down to is that there's this new thing called agendas. Every civilization has 2. One that is constant for that particular civ and one that randomizes each game. The idea is good it helps to portray not only the character of the leaders but give them a goal/playstyle. But it's what most people are currently complaining about because the execution is faulty. Fine Cleopatra likes civilizations with large armies and dislikes civilizations with no armies but let's say theoretically you don't have an army and she currently hates your guts. The next turn you somehow manage to create let's say 6 military units... She will begin to worship the ground you walk on. The system manages to instead of giving these leaders personality give them a multiple personality disorder. As amusing as it is in the beginning it becomes exhausting trying to keep up with who hates and who loves you turn by turn. Short answer The AI is bearable needs a rework.User InterfaceNot much I can say here all this really comes down to is personal preference. Civ 6 is a lot more complex than Civ 5 and so it makes sense that they simplified the design and art style of the UI to make things easier to interpret and understand at a glance. I personally do like it.The PricingOh boy. As much as I love the out of this game the price is honestly ridiculous. The fact that I bought this after playing through the demo twice on seperate accounts should be an indication of how much I really enjoy it. But honestly Firaxis please lower your prices. The game is wonderful and that's why I'm not giving it a downvote this review is based solely on the gameplay and not on the price. Is it worth the current price? No I don't think so. Wait for a sale. P.S Still not certain/convinced? Play the demo. Decide for yourself. Don't take any reviewer's words at face value.
title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: So I really love this game. Its so addictive and it gets a thumbs up from me!However I've seen so many negative posts and reviews about this game. So many of which are unfair. Yes on release the AI wasn't great but it has improved and is continuously being tuned. The support by Firaxis is superb and they continue to listen to suggestions and the civ community.Some of the balancing done since release has improved the game a lot and made the gameplay much more fun. Every game is different you never know what mix of map placement and civs will provide you with challenges in each game.So I do get frustrated when people say the game is broken or unplayable which in my mind is pure garbage. the game works well the UI is superb and its a greatly polished game.That's not to say some negative posts do have good points. for example the DLCs provided are expensive for what they are and although the Civs they add are very good they do charge to much. But you dont have to buy them. And yes sometimes the AI some stupid things but its a game I just play it for what it is.Now whether you enjoy the game is personal preference and also Whether you can adapt from civ5 (which took me a while!) in fact i played the game like civ5 when it came out which is totally wrong and i stopped playing for a while. Whether you understand the new game mechanics and how they all join together to make this wonderful thing of beauty. Again it took me some time to learn them there is a steep learning curve to this game it took me 50hrs of game play just to understand the basics plus numerous you tube videos but once it clicked and i got it ive never looked back and the game is actually quite complicated in the way its systems all interconnect and affect one another.Overall I really enjoy the game now and I can't put it down. I did enjoy civ5 but no where near as much as this one. I enjoy placing the districts and city planning i enjoy the military side ive even learnt how to use holy sites apostles and to spend Faith on units to!9/10 from PC gamer was just the right score.
title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: There are lots of negative reviews about Civ VI. Most of the problems listed are real there are still little bugs and glitches some mechanics are not clear the UI is poor the AI and diplomacy have strange behavior sometimes.However coming from Civ V is a refreshing experience new art style new dynamics while most of the mechanics from Civ V are here unchanged or improved. The district system is a huge change and adds a completely new layer of strategy. Those who like city planning will enjoy this a lot.In conclusion the game is far from perfect but still very entertaining. The last patch already fixed the most annoying issues and I'm sure that Firaxis will be able to "build a Civilization that will stand the test of time".

But I know one day it will be cheaper and worth to play.

title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: So have played nearly 60 hours of this game now and have played a few different civs (Rome Japan and Germany) on a number of difficulties and i have concluded that i enjoy the game and do not regret buying it. Now typically if i invest 10 hours into a game that means i got my enjoyment from it i got 6 times that and will probaly triple my current game time like i have with Civ 5 4 3 and 2. Now this game does have faults but considering the fact that this game has everything Civ 5 has after Vannila and 2 DLCs minus the civs plus extras id say its worth the money. Pros Pretty graphics i love how its stylized and i love the classic map style. Has an improved diplomacy system so now i can declare war on those ers that keep converting my cities are not get as bad of a warmonger statues. About time. 2 tech trees one for culture and one for science which i think is a good feature. Districts i believe make the game feel more alive making your empire a little more interesting also making it more important to protect your borders. Governments are kinda 50/50 for me. I like how you can choose a government type through out the ages and choose your own policies to customize your government to your needs. Though the policies feel underwhelming with only a few being truly useful. Cons AI is ing stupid below difficulty 5. You need to play at 5 or higher to get a real challenge. You will blow them away in tech and culture if you play in 4 or below. Not only will you be much more advanced but they will constantly demand things from you even though they have no leverage against you. Policies feel underwhelming AI is war happy. A story about the AI is that Norway declared war on me (Difficulty 5) invaded my civ destroyed my districts. I destroy his army push him back to his nearest city i take his city as payment he begs for peace i accept it and keep his city. 10 turns later he denounces me calling me a warmonger. What the ? A story about the AI from a friend is that Teddy asked him if he would join him a joint war against England since they settled on their continent. He accepts they go to war and then the next turn Teddy declares war on him because Teddy hates it when other civs declare war on civs on the same continent as him. Lol what? Conclusion.Basically my cons are to do with the AI which most issues are solved with playing on 5 or above which any higher and the AI cheats like in all civ games. So far i love the game and find it as an improvement. It has tons of potential and i am excited to see the DLCs.
title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: So disappointed. Pre ordered the Deluxe Edition and this is what I get.Diplomacy makes no sense. AI does not act in a realistic way at all.No multiplayer teams.Mod workshop still missing 3 months after release. Civ 5 had one in 8 days.Already pumping out the DLC.If you're too lazy to fix your game's problems at least put out an SDK so people can do it for you.The amount of salt in me could fill another ocean.
title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: The more I think about it and the more analysis of Civ 6 I read the less I am liking this game. In large part because they've made a game where war is always the right answer. Everything you can do in the game you can do quicker and easier through war. Civ 6 isn't about building a civilization to stand the test of time it's about building a machine to cynically crush everyone around you. Civs can't meaningfully interact in any way besides war. There's no point in maintaining friends or alliances since the buffs they give you are minor compared to what you could get through conquest and the lack of penalty for conquest or growing across the map like a cancer means that defeating literally the entire world is objectively the best way to play. Despite some of their buffs and agendas the AI knows this and can t get a grip on international cooperation as war will help it accomplish all its goals quicker and easier.If this is a simulation of human civilization then clearly war is the only meaningful thing humans do it is the culmination of our evolution. I wonder what Carl Sagan would say about that? This makes the idea of cooperation between nations merely cynical exploitation. Since every civ always views itself in competition with everyone else there is no real trust or friendship despite minor differences each Civ is playing the same game with the same attitude. There is no actual variation in beliefs or cultures you will always be an imperialist in Civ the AI will always hate you and always be an imperialist towards you. Also no one seems to have told the devs that the nation state model of society is only applicable from the 16th century onwards and really not until the 18th century tbh. This is compared to a game like Stellaris where the complex ethics and government systems mean you can have truly diverse nations which have actual meaningful relationships have different goals and different play styles. While not without its own shortcomings at least Stellaris makes you feel like nations in the universe are unique and interact with you in different ways and the war is not always the answer.Civ 6's AI is incredibly bad. I've tried to appreciate it but there's no more lying to myself the AI can't play this game or understand its rules. The fact that each AI has an agenda breaks the by design the AI won't react to realities on the map but rather around what it is pre programmed to love. Not that it matters because it's trivial to deal with. In 245 hours played I've never been defeated or seriously threatened by the AI. Increasing the difficulty only makes the AI cheat more aggressively further breaking the game. I'm also really starting to dislike Civ 6's digital board game approach to video games. It isn't trying to use a computer to simulate a planet and society it s just a board game. For example to manage your government you literally shuffle cards. To a degree all Civ games have been board games but in this iteration the developers specifically draw attention to this. Rather than abstracting the variances of life through simulation the abstractions are based in board game design. This isn't surprising considering the lead developer was a board game designer rather than a video game designer. Through its UI and heaps of flavor text Stellaris manages to feel like your managing a living empire rather than playing Complex Catan.And Civ 6's user interface is.And the tech &amp culture quotes are unbelievably bad. Sean Bean did a great job with the trash he was had to read. For the first 245 hours I sunk into Civ 6 I enjoyed the game for what it was trying to be despite how fundamentally broken it is. When I evaluate the game based on what I think a Civ game should be Civ 6 might actually be one of the worst entries in the series. I'm going to shelf it for a while and play Stellaris as well as revisit Civ 5.Districts are cool though.
title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: I decided not to write a reveiw for this game until I played at least 10 hours...Graphics They do seem a bit cartoonish but the more I play the game the more I like themMusic Changes with the level of development with your cities and sounds goodReligion New religous warfare mechanic adds a whole new layer of depth and the new religous victoryWar Complex AI interactions and Cassus BeliTrading Now builds roads between cities an interesting change for sureDistricts Areas where special building are built take up a tileWonders Take up a tile in your cityBuilders Have limited number of builds and can not be automated due to the higher value of each tile in the game and all of the adjacencey bonuses the player has to considerSocial Polices Unlocked in the style of the tech tree and polices are placed in slots that the kind of government you choose providesBarbarians Much more aggresive go away natrualy through timeMultiplayer Finally a Civ game with working multiplayer! Civ VI also includes different multiplayer scenarios and modesAnd the game hasn't even gotten any DLCs released yet
title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: Best Civilization game since Civ IV.
title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: Beutiful interface and smooth gameplay. Problem is no matter what victory condition you select you always end up stuck with religious war. That or you let the missionaries suck you dry. Clearly religion has a big role here but it is being leveraged under every victory condition and all civilizations perhaps too much no matter your setup choice. It becomes tiresome after a while and takes out the longer term replayability factor.The other thing is that all civilizations react pretty much the same. You get a couple of diplomacy moves and then you end up with religious war again. Perhaps the AI needs to be refined? That is not to say this is not a good game but the classic choices that marked the series from the start are not there any more and that has probably alienated some of the players who were there at the very beginning.
title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: This game wasn't just review bombed it was review nuked

review: Stick to Civ 5 until this game has recieved more updates/dlc and gets more/better mods. It has a lot potential but I cannot recommend buying it in its current state.
title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: I've played every Civ game since the first and this is the first time I've ever had a problem getting a game to run. The game crashes to start every time I click on the start check the forums and you will see that hundreds perhaps thousands of users are having the same issue. A triple A title should not have such a terrible kickoff with no communication from Firaxis about possible solutions. I expect a wobbly start from a small shop in a Beta or Alpha opening but not from a company as big as this. Absolutely pathetic I would not buy it until you know that they can fix the issues that so many are having.
title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: Very good! Beautiful and clever!

review: If you dont mind dumb &amp unreasonable AI on single player.If you dont mind long turns &amp managing many things on your own.Just buy it then. Last Civ I played was 5 long time ago with all DLCs it was fun. I checked only single player content for that it was great. Coming up Civ 6 is price'y but... it simply gives alot in that package. Many fractions many things to test I have 18 hours and I didn't finish any game from start to end because I am still learning things. How to be efficient in that game. I play on King difficulty I play multi with a friend and we simply have fun. Game is well explained and probably the most friendly 4X series on Steam. I wouldn't recommend it for only singleplayer purpose... it is rather boring comparing to civ 5 scenarios.Soo anyway I paid a good money for Civ 6. I am happy from what I've got. Day and night system is gorgeous along with graphics and music. City districts are fun and give our country a nice individual look. This game feels diffrent with each fraction as a result it is fun for at least 100 hours. But only if you have time for at least 2 hour sessions. Loading screens are long.

review: very bad Civ game. 1 misonaries and any other religious unit can walk right in your teritorry even without open borders2 AI clearly Cheats3 districts are built by city contruction and not builders really? (civil engineers design district not the city state. 4 AI clearly cheat. builds like 4 warriors and building in like 10 turns BS5 civil research and civil outlay is not realistic. 6 barbarians are cheating and unrealistic in AI behavior &amp grouping. barbarians from more than one camp send units to my cities and coordinate attack. all barbarians rebels etc under one flag. even total war droped that since Rome 1. really? dude make the game realistic PLS.7 maps sucks. no earth and fog of war is a bummer. i prefered the shadows over no map intel 8 no roads really as if civilisations like rome monglian empire or german autobahn or even the great British empires maritine routes didnt affect civs historicaly. and bs trade system much like Civ 6 trade routes have nothing to do with resources but with gold culture and science really? didnt great britian manipulate india and china with opium spices silk and tea? resources are exchanged through diplomacy really!9 great people are generated faster but are extremely limited one great act and usually tied to thier respective districts for me that is pathetic. i have to build culture districts just to get rid of writer musician and painters. three great people for one district! big balancing issue. stick with 6 much better7 is by far the worse civ i have played and i know sid colonization that came out for IMB 486 in the 90s
title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: I see folks regularly whining that the AI is too warlike. However I am finding the AI is just as docile as in V. THE PROBLEM is that the AI is NOT WARLIKE ENOUGH!I dont get it. I played a game on a small map for about 70 120 turns. I got to late Classical my nearest neighbor to early medieval. I even encroached on my nearest neighbor's turf and he responded with a warning. In the end he offered me deals to exchange a luxury for open borders and a little bit of gold then traded with me. The other nearest AI player was expanding with territories and had a large army of 4 7 units. That player sniffed around my borders early on made no aggressive moves then attacked barbs instead pretty far off and out of the way.I will admit I did have a ton of resources and was rich compared to everyone else with my nearest neighbor having 50 gold compared to my 400. But I had barely any army units just one roaming warrior and archers guarding my handful of walled cities. My closest neighbor had some better improvements and at lesat his capital was a little better than my best city. The second closest neighbor had at least double my army.I forget the exact difficulty I played on but it was the one in the middle. Before folks comment I do not want to hike it up which also gives teh AI lots of buffs. I want an aggressive AI THEN i'll increase the difficulty till it's a nice challenge but not stupid hard.I will not be getting this game exactly due to it not being exciting enough lacking war focus. I will not be getting the next civ unless there is an option to make the AI aggressive again like there was in 4.
title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: watching the intro to this game i find myself watching a preview of the story of mankind. great game all the mechanics are improved and expanded upon. if you are into turned based strategy games this is a must have.

Better start mastering it now so that you're ready to play when the game is fully fleshed out. The game has many flaws and the endgame can turn into a bit of a slog but you could say the exact same thing about Civ V vanilla. Does anyone even remember the old Civ 5 Cultural Victory condition and how absolutely vomitous it was? Overall this is exactly what I wanted and I can't wait to have even more of it.

review: 20/10 Probably one of the best Civ game I've ever played and I have played 3 4 5 and now 6.

review: Best game in the series even with some of the launch issues will be even better once the issues are fixed!

review: Best version of Civilization yet. New graphics and UI look amazing and the new mechanics are integrated well with the classic Civ mechanics. Fog of war districts and housing all make the game more interesting.
title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: "As our protests are in vain we hereby declare war"Civ 6 is for the most part a very fun game it is more engaging than previous Civilization Games its unique blend of realism and cartoonism is done extremely well and the district system is one of the most welcoming additions to the game. The game encourages a much more aggressive player you can't just hide away in your fort of solitude but instead must explore the world.My main two gripes with this game are war and production. Production feels like it just takes too long I wouldn't mind if there was a slight decrease to the production time of everything in the different game speeds. Although what I think is more of a problem is war the AI in this game is remarkably aggressive and stupid I haven't had a single instance where just one AI declares war on me it's always two in addition it's extremely frequent. I have been declared war because I've gone against an AI's Secret Agenda the problem is I can never find out what that Agenda is since they keep declaring war on me. I don't think Agendas should provoke war instead they should just stop friendship it shouldn't be unless the player is overtly aggressive that war should be declared. Also I suspect France is to blame for this.
title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: Have you noticed that most people that have given this game a bad review have very few hours on it?Civ VI isn't a game you get down in the first playthrough. I quit the first three games because I was getting overwhelmed even on the easiest mode! The thing about this game that Civ V and the others don't have is a good layering of how you can be attacked pretty much right from the start and unlike Civ V every AI is batsh*t crazy so you aren't being singled out by AI every game. That said this is also far more fast paced in several ways than Civ 5 so if you don't get everything about the game be prepared ot be disappointed your first few playthroughs.Things I liked The AI is crazy but not stupid. You really have to watch your back on this one DISTRICTS! Set down a bowl then put in some fruit. Districts are that easy but it helps you form what kind of city you want to build. In Civ V you pretty much felt obligated to put in every building just becuase it was there to build. Now you can specialize. You have to earn trust and that trust has levels. I've never had anyone on friendly terms with me yet (my fault entirely) but when I do I know I'll have some awesome insider info because they have little secrets they won't tell anyone they aren't bffs with. NO WAITNG TO MAKE CITIES! Civ V the first 1000 turns Must wait with two cities until all city counted wonders are completed...Civ VI "Ain t nobody got time for that!" Build like mad they'll accomodate. I hated the game the first 10 hours or so of play but now I love the heck out of it. I figured out how to do religious wars against other religions without actually going to war and they actually throw lightning at each other as they fight! Sweet stuff! And while I was learning this and beating Rome to bits for sneak attacking me after offering friendship and open borders Spain and England were using their spies to syphon off a good hunk of my gold. Is the game worth $60? Meh not yet. Will you be sad you spent it on this compared to the other games on here? Doubtful. It's fun and has great replay value as long as you didn't by it with your head already deep up your butt. lol
title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: A solid step forward for the franchise in almost every way. Exciting improvements to many of the core systems make for the best gameplay experience in a Civ game. I don't like the cartoony leader aesthetic the confusing fog of war or the soporific music score but everything else is so good that I do recommend it to all fans of the series or genre. If you're new to Civilization or 4x games in general you should really check this one out.
title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: What more can you say it's Civ!The game feels very fresh you can't simply automate your workers and forget anymore instead you need to manage your builders and direct their limited uses wisely. You have to think of the trade off between creating a district or keeping the improvements around your city. Combat feels fresh with a good upgrade system experience and unit combining mechanics. The graphical style is awesome and although I don't spend a load of time using it the strategic view is beautiful.If I pointed out a few faults there are a few day 1 bugs and issues the notification system is not amazing too small and dismisses inconsistently. AI still does some weird things especially with its religious units. The government choices allow a lot of freedom but like the aforementioned builders / districts can feel a little micromanagey.All said a super strong entry into the franchise with lots of great things. A few bugs that will iron out over the next weeks and space for an expansion at some stage I'm sure. Please bring back custom city names!90% w
title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: If you dream of micromanaging a civilization then Civ VI is for you! Be nagged about lack of housing and ammenities have surprise wars declared on you for attracting more great people and watch another civ win a religious victory before you've gotten out of the BC era all while on Settler difficulty!Jokes aside Civilization VI took everything good about V and threw it out the window. Sean Bean narrating cannot possibly make up for the fact that even on Settler it is rather difficult to beat the AI especially considering the AI will declare surprise wars on you constantly. Building city districts around the city center is an interesting concept though it does deter you from building near bonus resources as putting a district or wonder on it takes away the resource. They also made builders have a set number of improvements before they disappear (default was 3 improvements when I played). As mentioned above wonders are also built on tiles outside the city center. Research is separated into science and civil trees with science being technology based (obviously) and civil being used for such things as drama &amp poetry and foreign policy. I really wanted to like this game as I spent many hours playing Civ V but I just couldn't. Though the changes I listed were good or at least tolerable the fact that I lost my first game to a cultural victory before the 1700s because in a cultural victory you only need tourists not influence made me rather unhappy. The next loss was to a religious victory because you only need to have your religion in half of each oppenent civ's cities to win. After turning those two off I had a surprise war declared on me over the next 3 games with no hopes of defending myself due to lack of funds to buy or maintain military units.TLDR version This game is fine if you are fond of micromanaging housing and amenities and don't mind losing a lot but if you just want a fun Civilization game to kill hours on just stick with V.

review: I've been playing this series since Civilization 1 in 1997 and I must say this is the best installment to date. Overall the gameplay is a lot more seamless. Much more new additions including researching civics and traders who run a continuous string of trade routes creating roads between cities. I only have a couple of small complaints like that it's a little inconvenient to have to create more and more builders because their actions are limited but that adds to the dynamic of the game. Also I'm a little disappointed that they haven't fixed the fact that when you declare war on someone early in the game your warmonger penalty lasts literally for like 1000 years! The other leaders just keep denouncing you and denouncing you it's frustrating. Plus their trading skills suck. They rarely offer you what a resource is actually worth... But other than that this game is freaking amazing! I'm hooked!

title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: I only started playing an entry into the Civilization franchise a couple months ago when I picked up Civ 4 on disc from a local charity shop so judge my review knowing that. Yet in those few months Civilization has easily become my favourite and most beloved game series I have ever had the pleasure of playing I was obsessed with destroying other Civlizations spreading my religion throughout the world and building that extra wonder so it would get me a little closer to a cultural victory. I then moved on to Civilization V and I have to admit I was rather disapointed a fair few features I had loved from the previous entry had been removed aswell as the overall presentation of the game being clunky and seemingly unfinished. So as I bought the latest entry into the series Civ 6 I was hoping that it would return to the more simplier fun and in my opinion more flexable Civ 4.And after having a long singleplayer session in the game. Aswell as being half way through a multiplayer session I can saftely say I believe Civ 6 has captured me in a way that Civ 4 did all those months ago That isn't to say I dont have my problems with it though. I'll start of with my issues with the game as I always like to end on a high after reading through some of the other reviews here it seems most people agree that they find the art style far inferior to the art styles of previous entries and although I believe it does have some redeeming factors I have to agree that I overall prefer the more realistic art style of the entries that came before. Like I said though I do like some aspects of it one of my biggest and only problems with Civ 4 was that I sometimes struggled to read some text as the background art style is somewhat dark and gritty. Luckily though this art style takes on a much more bright and vibrant look aswell as being more soothing and pleasing on the eyes therefore I had no to very little trouble at reading the text on screen. Next I want to talk about the leader screens what I considered one of my main reedeeming factors of Civ 5 is the leader screens which I found very alive and said a lot about the nation in just one short animation. That aspect has been seemingly lost in this entry the leaders are certainly very 3D and look more real and active in Civ 6 but unfortunatily I found myself unable to learn anything about a certain leaders personality beyond a small line of text telling me that they had denouced me within 5 turns of meeting them. The backgrounds of the leaders are very stiff and are usually very similiar to one another unlike in Civ 5 when they all had they own look style and feel that really showed what kind of person you were talking to. My thrid complaint strays away from the art style and instead is an issue with the game mechanics itself. The fact is the AI is still severly broken even after a couple updates that promised to fix the issue. The AI do seem to like to declare suprise wars on you i'm fine with that but what i'm not fine with is there units incircling your cities for 5 turns without actually attacking i've heard from a few people that this problem has been since fixed but this has problem has confronted me recently so if they did try to fix it they clearly didn't do a good enough job. This is rather game breaking in a way as if it occurs it means that you are easily in a position to fight of there invasion and i've found after a couple turns they simply get bored and leave. And my final problem with the game as it is now is having to pay to recieve certain Civ's. I've already payed 50 for the game which I think is more than enough for a game of this size so I find having to pay extra for something that I don't think is outragous to include for 50 is unacceptable in my eyes.Alright my rant is now over so i'll start to list the things I like about the game for which there is many. First of all the general presentation of the screen is much improved when compared to earlier entries Civ 5 in particular the layout no longer seems cluttered untidy and generally inconvient to use but everthing has it's own place various important information regarding your nation is never more than one click away and even at the start of the game where I hadn't watched or played any tutorial as I though I may be able to pick the game up with my experiance of Civ games in the past when I was looking for a certain option or something that would tell me a certain something it never took more than 30 seconds at most to find it. I know just earlier I was complaining about the AI but that doesn't mean it's all bad I found throughout the game the AI would make deals that weren't ludicrous like the deals that i'd sometimes see coming from them in Civ 5 but instead were genuine deals and I found myself accepting more than a few of them throughout my time playing in singleplayer. The map looks no less than beautiful aswell I think it makes a lot more sense to have the places you currently don't have a unit or city or an ally's unit's or cities appear as an old timey map. I found this fog of war as you might call it made the game almost have a scare factor to it as you continued on an example would be when I was playing a multiplayer game I had just taken three of anothers players cities via my navy and then agreed to not take any more so we made peace. The guy I took the city from had an alliance with another player so he could see his units and I could hear him laughing slightly sometimes and saying RIP me which clearly meant that the units he was seeing convinced him of my defeat. But because of the fog of war I had no idea where these crazy units were so I had no idea where this attack might come from. Right up until he declared war and I could finally see his units I had absolutley no idea how big or where his force was and let me tell you his force was certainly large I lost two of the cities I had taken from him within 5 turns and I signed a peace treaty with him soon after when we realised how big of a threat the Aztects were when it came to winning the game. Overall although I have some problems with the game I still believe it to be miles above the rather disapointing in my eyes Civ 5 and almost next to Civ 4 as my favourite in the franchise I recommend this game
title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: Okay so I don't usually write reviews but with this game frustrating me to no end I feel as though I have to say something. So I cannot beat this game. I know I know get good scrub but here's the thing I was pretty okay at Civ 5. I'm not saying I was hardcore good or anything (I could only get up to level 4 or whatever) but I could at least freakin win sometimes. With Civ 6 it's just not happening. Moreover when I tried googling how to win this game the pages I was reading made very little sense to me. So I thought to myself "Okay maybe I can't just go in level 4 (Prince?) on this one let's start at level 1 that will be easier." Oh pity the fool friends for it was I. No matter what flipping level I play this game on I cannot win! I have no idea how the other civs get so far ahead of me in science and culture immediately and what I could be doing to kick more butt. It is endlessly frustrating because I love the graphics and the creative new characters but this game makes me want to throw my laptop out the window. I really want to play it as much as I did Civ 5 but I don't think I can because I keep losing from the very beginning of the game and it makes me sad.

review: Product received for free. In single player I don't find the game engaging enough (maybe that is just personal preference) so I only play this game in multiplayer (online private matches). You would think by now they would have fixed game breaking bugs but nope. So many different bugs. Even simple things like the turn timer and the pause feature don't work properly. And you never know which player will be the lucky winner of the "broken Civ" lottery as it is always someone different each time. Even putting the bugs aside the game itself just does not feel as engaging as Civ V did (although Civ V was not perfeect there were a lot of problems with that game too). Maybe it is because the districts feel a bit too much like micromanagement. Again personal preference. There were some memorable Civ V games that I really enjoyed I can't say the same about Civ Vi. I have been patient for a while and tried to give it a chance but I am now uninstalling it and might go back to Civ V.

title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: I love the majority of the civ series. This one is not the worst nor is it the best.This one is better than Civ 5 but not as good as Civ 3 or 4. I haven't played 1 or 2 in so long I can't compare since I remember how much I loved the games but I'm not sure if my recollection is accurate enough of those two to compare.Over all the best of the breed remains Civ3 with Civ4 being a close 2nd.There are several game design flaws in this game. Not just "Oh I wish they'd done 'this' or 'that'.The game is just full of changes. Most of which are very obviously change for the sake of change rather then change to make it a better game.Diplomacy does not work at all. It is never rational or reasonable. And it progresses fairly quickly to everyone hates everyone so it is not just broken in the human v. AI. An example you crush a foe they are down to their last city and they beg for peace but the only terms they will accept is with you giving them all your cash on hand and all the cash you earn every turn and give them back a couple of the cities you captured. What you can ask for in diplomacy is broken. I was at war with Sumeria. Russia and India hated Sumeria and had "denounced them". But I could not ask them to join in the war I could only ask them to start a new war against each other. You can't even do basic things like share maps. Declarations of war have nothing to do with their ability to win the war or even their preparedness to wage a war. The chinese declared war with only 4 military units not a single one of which was close to current tech. Also the AI declaring love or hate based on nonsensical things is just plain stupid. Why in the world would any nation declare affection for another because the other built a factory a sailboat or hate one because they built a fancy light house? it is random nonsense in the place of actual logic based diplomacy. Economics does not work at all. A 6 city empire can make just as much or more cash as a 40 city one. Trade routes are more important than any thing else. In fact most everything else (economically) can be ignored until your trade routes are full and then only build it when you don't have anything more important to build. In a game I recently played a 6 city empire had a larger military and more cash on hand than mine with close to 40 cities.Road build "works" but is done in the most annoying way they could devise. Workers can not build roads only military engineers can but should have been called "Combat engineers". "Combat engineers" can only be built in cities with a "barracks" (now called an encampment). They can only build 2 roads (or other items) and then disappears. "Caravans" (now called Traders) will sometimes build roads (and will other times decide to go over water). So you are stuck using one of your cities to nearly constantly build "road builders" since these units take about as long to build as most actual military units.The tech tree is short and completed rather quickly. At which point everyone is equal for however long the game lasts. Boring.City management is cumbersome. There are no build ques. Unlike previous versions you can't simply drag a city "worker" to the new task. You must lock all the citizens in place except for the only one you want to move. Well now that makes perfect sense to no one. click on and Lock 20 rather than just click on the one you want to move.City state is a cute idea done badly. You surround a city state. A rival can send enough envoys to become their "Suzerain" and the city state will then follow that empire to war. The equivalent of this occurred. Kansas city decided that Taiwan was their most favorite place in the world. For some reason Taiwan declared war on the USA. So Kansas City followed their lead. They send out half a dozen spearmen to face down the american tanks. Sending envoys leads to that city state granting your civilization their magic power um ok??Naval power is a joke. Most of the ships of previous games have been removed. Even cargo ships are non existent since just moving a unit in to the water turns them in to a transport ship.Air power is poorly and awkwardly done as well. Even the AI seems to know it since I played to 2096 and never did see an enemy plane.Military power in general is going to disappoint. If you play to for a domination victory you'll hate this the most of all. The AI uses no logic at all. Units are just randomly sent your direction. A few "artillery" units but not escorted. Unit combat strength make no sense. APC's can destroy a max tech tank. A tank can attack and destroy a helicopter so even the old rock paper scissors part of the old combat logic is broken. Cavemen damage tanks with their sticks. There are game imbalancing things which can not be undone. For example one AI had a tank "base" strength of 107. While in my case they had a base strength of 90. I compared policies government bonuses religions and so forth. So far as I can tell I had all the stuff which gives you a bonus and he had none. It was not one unit which happened to be high level but all this units had a 17 point "head start" within nothing in the game giving it to him. This 17 point head start translates in to needing a 3 1 advantage in number to prevail. Not impossible but given the way units work in game (limited stack possibilities 1 unit per tile) it was vexing. The only thing equalizer was the AI's lack of tactics or logic beyond drive our stuff towards the nearest city in an unorganized mob.The game over all feels half baked (as in they took it out of the oven before it was done).The nations and leaders bonuses and such are not at all equal. I doubt much attention was payed to game balancing.The load times turn lengths responsiveness are all bad. Even on very high end computers. Scrolling the map up to move a unit for example is very time consuming as it is hit or miss if the map will scroll at all.There are more issues but for me these are the high lights. Your love/hate of the game will depend on how much control you want (the more you want the less you'll like this game). If you have played and enjoyed the previous versions (other than 5) this may well impact your ability to enjoy this one. If you like a 'war' game this one will drive you nuts.

review: Having played civ 1 6 this is by far the worst entry in the series. The AI "agendas" alone are enough reason not to recommend it. As even on a basis level many contradict each other so nation a hates you for spreading your religion and nation b hates you for NOT spreading your religion. You get attacked for building a wonder because nation c feels entiteld to be the only wonder builders in the game but if you counterattack and take their cities you get a woping 99 diplo modifier for beeing a warmonger...... And it's best not to talk about complete bs wars by proxy because nation d (who now hates you for killing nation c) just had enough envoys to get three neutral cities to do their fighting for them with absurd amounts of units these states can somehow field. Overall a BIG step in the wrong direction and the expansion doesn't seem to improve this mess in any way. Just install civ 5 again and spare yourself the disapointement.

Civ 6 is garbage.The Humble Bundle is still worth it because at least you'll get other games in the bundle for $12 but I'm not sure I could justify buying this game separately for $12 on its own. title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: I was always expecting this game to be good I trust Firaxis and any other developers working on Civilization to make it a good game although normally you have to wait for the inevitable DLC to be released that fixes 90% of the game by adding some new mechanics etc. (Civ 5 being the primary example as most waited for Brave New World before they could enjoy it).This game however has been completely different. I have played this for 30 hours (as of 24th October) and I started and finished multiple games of Civilization and each game that I have played has felt different from the last in some way. The victory types feel quite balanced science victory and religious victory are probably the easiest I have done so far the most challenging being domination due to the warmonger system declaring war on Civilizations make it a challenge to invade and take the enemy city. The religious victory is fun to play with because you still need to have high science to get faith buildings to allow Apostles and Missionaries to be mass produced to spread around the world. I have found that the religious victory is more fun in large player games (8+ players) otherwise it feels a little easy. The science victory feels quite balanced as their are a lot of steps to the space race which allows other civilizations to work on other victories so it can get quite clutch towards the end of a game.Cultural victory can be fun although it feels quite slow for a large part of the game then towards the end when you can farm antiquities for your theatrical district then you start to make a lot of progress.As for the games performance I can run it on my laptop (Lenovo Thinkpad X220 so if you want a comparison check that) it also runs on my PC although it has a GTX1080 so I won't write much about the performace as that quite honestly is pointless sorry. As for the games options and things like that the settings can be altered to get it to run on nearly any system from what I can tell. Overall I recommend the game to anyone even those who aren't 'good' at strategy games as it is easy to learn. Also the game has Sean Bean who makes the narration ING AMAZING.Pros Easy to learn Has Sean Bean on narration Multiple and actually working victory types Graphically pleasing Great Performance Beautiful UI Each civ feels different and plays completely different from othersCons A few more civs could be nice although these have already been confirmed as coming soon There are currently a few exploits (Near infinite units by selling them when nearly dead Trading needs a workover the AI you trade with refuses 1 extra gold but you can glitch them into handing over everything they own Discussion system is poor you can't tell people not to settle close to you until they already have8.5/10 would recommend.
title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: Epic simply epic there's nothing else I can say.
title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: Everyone has forgotten that Civ V base game launch was also badly received and had a lot of problems and oversimplification of the game. Seems people nowadays complaining about the AI being dumb... I have played Civ games since Civ II and do not experience any sort of downgrade in Civ VI AI. The AI seems to be on par with Civ V even... There could be some improvements in AI but that can be said for all previous Civ games and I don't think it deserves the harsh negativity.My personal experience with Civ VI is generally positive there are lots of improvements that can be done which they probably will add in DLCs/expacs in the future. I had a lot more fun with Civ VI than Civ V base game the game is now not as oversimplified and the graphic and sound is a lot better and some new systems were added which added some needed depth into the game.So don't let all the negative comments dissuade you if you're a Civ fan that did not enjoy Civ V base game.

review: SO I had hoped Rise and Fall would make the game better and while it has very nice mechanics the base game is just really bad. I like the Tech trees and such like that but the map generation is really bad and you're lucky if you can get full movement out of your warriors and scouts. There's literally no penalty to spamming cities and the loyalty system kinda encourages it. The AI build nothing but warriors basically and they wind up just being able to storm cities with waves of them. I like the idea of districts but the Wonders have basically been destroyed and are nowhere near as worth they were in Civ V. I know I'm bias to Civ V but it's just so much better of a game. I can literally sit there and play Civ V all day. I can BARELY get over 100 turns into Civ 6. I heavily regret this game and until some serious balances are made I will not be playing it further. It's literally watered down and there's no strategic way to play.

review: This review is for Digital Deluxe Extras and all DLC's to date as I've read pre and release date reviews and decided to wait before buying the next game in my favorite of all time series as well as previous experience with Civ5 where DLC's changed the gaming experience as you wouldn't believe it. Of course I hate this DLC approach ****.I'm chipping in my 2 cents here as I feel that this game does not deserve all the way negative reviews. Though in all fairness maybe all those things need changing or improved are going to be done by DLC's .. sicUntil DLC approach will vanish which I doubt I'm not buying first release Civ game but wait for discounted Deluxe or whatever name package will be that has initial "issues" "solved" by it's DLC contents.All in all after a somewhat bumpy start on Civ6 I end up enjoying it quite a bit as it's different but not too much so and it's no way near as bad as a sequel as it's any of the Heroes of Might and Magic games after HMMO3... Think of it Civ4 was way different than Civ3 (!) so was Civ5 to Civ4 so yeah Civ6 is none of the previous.Thank God Civ series is not dead but boy do I hate DLC heh
title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: Civ VI Modernizing a ClassicAfter playing every Civ game (and even replaying 2 of them recently) I can only say one word about Civ VI...WOW! the new features are amazingly well thought out and put together. I've only noticed one small problem with the AI so far and that is an AI will sometimes ask you to be friends 1 turn and then denounce you or declare war you on 2 3 turns later. That being said the game is excellent and by far the best in the series so far. I am looking forward to see what they do with future DLCs and/or expansions.

review: Product received for free. I recieved this game as a gift but would have happily paid for it if it came down to it as a fan of previous Sid Meier's games. That being said I would advise you to grab it from humble bundle for $12 while you can (just a few days from this post) and if not grab it on sale if possible. It will make the few problems seem much smaller. ANYWAYS..I have only 1 official game under my belt but seeing as I'm almost at 40 hours of gameplay I feel it's a good time for my initial review. There is much to appreciate from the developers this time around as they deffinately tried to up the ante so to speak on the Civ to Civ interaction and diplomacy. Was a bit hit and miss with a very loose cannon minded A.I behind nearly every cpu Civ you meet. But on to the meat and potatoes PROs + I like the new district mechanics though I wish there were more (quantity and variety of effects) buildings for each district+ I like the new builder mechanics (Having only 3 uses is a welcomed change as I no longer have 15+ builders sitting around taking up space)+ City states are more interesting and play a more needed role than prior games.+ Split research and civics trees is more good than bad. Still clunky but I like the direction they took it.+ Better than Civ 5 was pre expansions but with seemingly drunk A.ICONs Religion is painful No diplomatic victory option. It was janky in Civ 5 but it enabled some gameplay options that are missing from this game (like focusing on economy with mostly peaceful intentions). The AI is as bad as all the reviews say The start location scripting/city placement issues are as bad as the reviews say (rumors of another civ spawning directly next to people leading to turn one domination) I appreciate what the devs attempted to do with the AI agendas to give them some diversity but it turned the AI civs into loose cannons. With almost non existant diplomacy it's a bad combonation. No penalties for building wide no benefit to building tall.I would say pick it up through Humble Bundle while you can (just a few days left!) or get it on sale elsewhere.(Shoutout to igmatto I borrowed their Pro/Con list as a starting point &lt 3)
title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: Nice strategy game
title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: I love Civ games and playing this on single player was a joy but I have to cite similar issues with weird AI behaviour as being a problem but the worst part for me is the unplayable multi player. We spent two hours trying to set up a game between three players we tried turning all the DLC off and we'd repeatedly be hit with 'cannot connect' error or driver errors despite everything being up to date. I've never known anything like it. Given the price I'd urge Firaxis to fix their buggy multi player before messing about with DLC and expansions. With the above in mind I've no choice but to 'down vote' Civ 6.
title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: Pros *Beautiful presentation*Innovative in very good ways like unstacking cities and changing how many units work*Presentation is beautiful*"One more turn" (then plays another 2 hours)*Soundtrack is unbelievably good best in the series *Gameplay feels fluent*The removal of policies and the adoption of civics is one of the best changes Cons *The Ai's decision making is iffy at best*The difficulty increases simply give the other civs more units and spawn more barbarians instead of making the other civ's ai better*Units look a little fremium mobile gamey*few bugs here and there ex city strike used crossbowman while everyone was in the classical era*Suprise wars are to be expected ( ing norway.....)*HUD is going to be VERY confusing for new players*Not very "noob friendly*All in all it's the best in the series and i highly reccomend it to anyone even if they are a little interested just take the time to learn it and you'll have a great time!
title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: Certainly some AI issues still and some improvements that I would like to see (like Civ remembering the settings I put on my last single player game so I wouldn't have to reset them every time I'd like to start a new game) but overall a definite improvement even over V (vanilla). With some Gods and Kings and BNW like expansions VI has the potential to be the best yet!Widening cities into districts is a really neat new feature and city state mechanics are better in VI already than in V. The religious victory is boring but all other victories are fun to pursue. Some Civs (Norway) are just awful and need some buffing but most civs offer a lot of unique abilities and units/infrastructure to make each game you play new and exciting. The soundtrack is also amazing!It does seem like the civs bias towards culture victories and I'd love to see some more science focused civs!

review: I have spent literally thousands of hours playing Civilivation games starting with the first release. I really like the progression of the game through the decades but I feel the latest installment lost a few "lessons learned" from past games.Likes. The split trees of advancement for social and education. Brilliant. How it affects units buildings governments is "spot on". The fact that certain "prerequisite" are required for wonders. Awesome the only thing I like to see is a bonus build percentage for the actual civilivation who built it (to give the civilization histrical credit) Ex. Pyramids (2x build speed for Eqyptions). Theological combat. Still gives the thrill of battle without losing all of your advances in diplomacy as long as you don't take it too far that is.Dislikes. The Tech tree. Having to scroll through it is a pain. The previous trees were way better in this regard. Theology overlays. Way too hard to see what is underneath when moving clergymen. Graphics. Interesting. I wonder what the actual target demographic for this game is now. Info panels. Not having the columns "sort" the information from low to high high to low is a pain. My biggest "pet peeve" is doing away with the initial location "reboot" and having to reload everything in the main menu until I don't get Montazuma starting his civilization in the middle of the desert. Also having to rechoose EVERY aspect of starting a game (ex. difficulty leader map size etc.). Also why can't "chained" units "auto explore" together? It seems a natural fit to have a land combat unit linked with a exploring sea vessel. Historically this is accurate as well. Remember the Conquistadors? Units. It took me forever where to find the unit list without the Military Advisor. For those who never have found it click on a unit's name. Not showing a unit's move length in other player's territory. Not showing an artilliary or air units attack range. Overall I recommend this game. Realistically I am thinking of returning to Civ V for my Civ "fix".
title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: What a disappointment!So many of the little annoying things that were resolved or less of an issue in Civ 5 are issues in Civ 6. If you take the time to do an advanced setup to a game and it starts you off in the jungle at a total disadvantage there's no quick restart. So you'll have to back all the way out the game DOESN'T save your previous settings so you have to create it all over again before rolling the dice. Civ 5 had a great quick restart button that resolved this. Takes so much more time to get started and you have fewer options to choose from makes NO sense. What happened to raging barbarians or the other extras you could add to the world you create? I'm sure there will be some additional add on I'll have to pay extra for to get it in the future. I logged over 1 000 hours in Civ 5 and I doubt I'll do 1/10th of that with the way the game is now. If you're new to Civ download 3 or 5 but avoid 6 too expensive for a step back in a franchise.

review: If you want to play with friends don't buy this game. Chances are one of your friends plays on a Mac system or a Linux. You will not be able to play with your Mac or Linux friend at all. At all. Cross platform gameplay between Mac and PC is not supported.Aspyr said there won't be cross platform gameplay 'until our first patch ' which 'probably won't be for another 50days' after launch. Almost 2 years later still no cross platform multiplayer patches. Moreover the Mac and Linux versions are simply unplayable receving updates such as DLC and patches weeks and months after the PC version. This is one factor in the lack of cross platform gameplay mismatched versions.If this is the kind of company Civ 6 (at least on Mac) is run by I have little hope in the future of this game.Just buy Civ 5.

title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: Bottom line A buggy unbalanced disappointment. Wait for patches at best the first expansion at worst.To put things in perspective I've had it for eight hours and have beaten the AI on 'Deity' level already. Having played all of the series since Civ 2 I know they all have their own exploitable/broken elements but not to this degree.If this were an early access version it'd be one thing but it's not this is a full price game. There's not a lot of point in re treading the same complaints as everyone else but I may as well run off a few of the worst elements for the sake of it (i) Awful UI missing loads of important information e.g. where your city will next expand its borders. (ii) I hope you liked having to re confirm all of your trade routes every thirty seconds in Civ 5 because it's back and now you have to do it for spies as well! It very much feels like any 'improvement' in the amount of mid game peacetime activity the player has to engage in is more down to this sort of busy work than any fundamental shift in the game's focus or depth. (iii) Even the main menu seems to be broken having forced me to log out of my machine both times I've quit the game to get it to terminate properly.On the plus side the new districts model is nice and culture has been reined back in so that it now requires actual effort to win a cultural victory rather than more or less receiving it by default. On the down side (iv) Religious victories are broken as hell at the moment.I know Civ 5 took a lot of flak when it first launched but having played through vanilla Civ 5 recently to satisfy my curiosity after so many years with the expansions it was fun in its own sparse way. Eight hours into Civ 6 and I'm probably going to head back to Endless Legend and Stellaris for my 4X fix until some balance patches (or even the first expansion) arrive.
title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: This game is garbage just like Civ 5 was. If like me Civ 4 was for you the highpoint of this series then avoid this rubbish at all costs. "One unit per tile" completely ruined the game. The limit of one unit per tile seems to have broken the AI entirely which you'll notice is one of the main complaints you hear even from people who enjoy the game. Not to mention that it's totally immersion breaking (a rare achievement for something as abstract as a strategy game) tedious to manage (like playing a board game with too many peices) and entirely misplaced in a 4X If you don't like doomstacks then don't play 4X. This is a strategy game strategy games are about resource management and so the combat in a 4X should refelct that. It's about managing the composition of your armies like any other resource in the game and doomstacks are the natural expression of that. If you want real fighting in your game go play Total War or any tactics game. What a stinker!
title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: I will start by saying that by no means is this a perfect game and that there are things that can be improved upon however in saying that the release of this game is very satisfying as a whole and the game as it is exists far from a bad state in the same way Civilization BE was.These are my issues with the game Fresh Water This is a cool concept but it's very tedious in my opinion and cripples cities that don't have good tiles around them further. You can only spend so many turns wandering around and Aquaducts come in quite late. Neighbourhoods come in even later which only makes it worse. This amongst other issues makes Coastal cities kind of not that good unless you start next to a river.Tile Occupation This is a general term I'm going to use to regard districts and wonders which both devour the yields of a tile as far as I'm aware which can mean you well obviously lose yields. This is doubly an issue in water rich/coastal areas where all you have in countless empty water tiles and water doesn't yield a whole lot or has any wonders or buildings that act like Petra it seems. You do get a few buildings but they only provide so much. You could make the argument that you don't need to put a city adjacent to the coast now with the Harbor district though that's not always an option with water accesibility as mentioned before and especially early on you don't have your aquaducts.Some minor issues off the top of my head Lack of ability to restart the game in the pause menu. The game "forgets" settings you put for a map (resource amount map type etc) which needs to be redone every time. Aside from that however I do like almost everything else about the game. The district system as a whole is amazing and allows a lot of design and town planning for players. The changes to great people is really really good and makes them as useful as Wonders in most cases. The Civics Culture and Tourism changes are also 10/10 in my opinion. Before Tourism felt like it was a tacked on thing that you could only really do in the midgame if you weren't lucky with Wonders. Now it feels like something you can work towards much better if you put the effort in from the get go.Overall I feel Civ 6 is an improvement. I would however wait a patch to have everything ironed out as the game in itself is in a state where its problems are only really patch demanding issues and aren't really all that game breaking as a whole. Someone might argue there are bugs and exploits but even bigger games have those about and if they're fixed soon enough it won't matter anyway.
title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: Worth the wait. Still learning the changes but Civ 6 has yet to dissappoint. The addition of districts and seperate Civics Gov't and Tech trees is awesome more wonders smarter barbs etc. They certainly did a great job adding to the many changes people wanted from Civ 5.

title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: Yet another Civilization game. Is it worth it? Short answer yes. It does feel like an advancement over Civ V (with DLCs!).I didn't like the graphics when I saw the first trailer but in game it looks gorgeous! Sadly optimisation isn't the best. My PC with i5 6600k and R9 390 struggles on highest details in the end game when most of the map is uncovered and there are lots of units on the screen. DX12 patch fixed it a little bit but it still makes my PC hot like a Mount Doom. Also I love Sean Bean as a narrator the quotes get old after couple playthroughs but I cannot complain.They made many little changes which in my opinion are brilliant. I will write about some of them.You have districts! Your city is no longer a one tile with improvements around but a real metropolis! You need build them to prosper but it is also devastaing when foreign army will destroy one of them. Wonders are built on a tile as well! It does feel much better to have it like that. Also you need a specific tile to build it. You want to build Pyramids? Well do you have a desert tile...? No? You are on Tundra what did you expect!The builders have only a couple uses and then they disappear. They also don't build roads the roads will spawn naturally when the trade routes are established. You remember that wonderful road between you and your neighbour? He is now using that road to transport that huge cannon just to your doorstep I love it.You now generate envoys for city states no longer buying them back with loads of money. But I don't feel that they matter as much as they did in Civ V there is no United Nations.There is a religion victory but it isn't fleshed out enough. Are you playing on a small map with Brazil and try to go for a domination victory? Well watch out because missionaries and apostles don't sleep. Also now there is theological combat and it isn't the best thing to win those fights everytime because when a religion units dies it can create a relic. Also everytime I try to win with religion I win with culture.Online speed in game. I'm one of those people that jsut can't play on standard speed it is so slow. I appreciate that you can choose from online speed to marathon speed.AI isn't the best it never was. Atleast I know why I was denounced and can do something about it. I could go on and on but the bottom line is this game is really good. It's not cheap but believe me you will spend countless hours playing it.If you're not familiar with the series maybe wait for a discount but I think this game it's a great starting point much better than Civ V with DLCs.
title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: 137.8 hours on record. I usually play this when I'm bored and just want some alone time from friends playing PUBG or BF4. I can't really put my finger on it but this game lacks a certain charm that previous iterations of Civilization have had. Whether it's the diplomacy feature (where everyone hates me because I went to war to defend my territory) or the fact that I have a different policies the diplomacy feature feels very hallow and predictable. That being said it's still a fun game. It's good for challenging my strategies good for mental acuity and excellent killing time. It's a fun game despite the shallow diplomacy feature. Hopefully they fix it down the road.

I've done all the checks my PC specs are fine but it still happens.I've played Civ since Civ 3 i even bought the god awful beyond earth game and i do enjoy them for the most part but this game is so annoying i can't recommend it as it's so buggy which is a shame because the potential for a good game is there but until they pull their finger out and get the basics right I can't say it's worth buying even with discount

review: My complaint with this game has nothing to do with the gameplay. It's a new Civ game somethings are better other things worse and all in all a great time sink to play with my family. Well it was anyway. They forced an update to all players for the new expansion pack cash grab DLC and it stops my offline "hotseat" data from loadimg because it has a few mid civs in it. Nothing crazy just some civs. With the idea that was the problem being so ludicrous to me I hit google. There I saw the ILS bug (Infinite Load Screen) sounded a lot like my problem and with solutions! Well I spent all day running through each option and installing and reinstalling the game. Disabling any process that might be in the way and finally I thought I'd just check if my mods could be messing it up and that is the problem.My perfectly working mods from two nights ago don't work with the DLC I don't want. So now the save data I have played for 30 hours is unusable and my game has less functionality from the update.I am more than a little mad at this pretty lazy bit of coding but you know who else is more than a little upset at this lazy bit of coding? My mom.Seriously I have to explain over and over again why it doesn't work and why I can't fix our data.I picked up Civ 6 because I was in the mood to play one of the best strategy game series ever made and part of the reason I bought my first computer (Civ 3 Complete) I just feel kinda bad that this might be the last one I ever play. It was fun while it lasted.
title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: Being a long time fan of the series and lots of hours on the game I must say I have a love/hate relationship with Civ 6. Lots of good ideas went into this game with the strategical placing of the districts but the AI either makes it too easy or too hard. There is never this good balance to enjoy the game until the end. Diplomacy is really getting on your nerve all the time and is dumb as you wont believe. Civs that are getting crushed should at least be looking for alliances with same sized civs. AI is a bit too much one minded/ideological and not enough realistic/realpolitik to make it believable.Those fixed agendas are simply simple minded stupid. Result is you will often realize too late one civ has crushed its neighbors and become an unstoppable giant on the other continent you have not met yet most often the Mali for some reason. The handicap on harder difficulties should come on a continuous path during the game and not as much at the start. You will often find at the start your nearest competitor with two more military units one more settler and some workers. This is simply too much while you get only a warrior and a settler.And then the AI is not quite opportunistic with its units. For instance a troop inside a city will never attack one of your injured unit at the wall. And then this tendency of AI of putting its first city just outside your border even before meeting you is just plain cheating on its part. Your first city act as a magnet for unmet scouts and settlers while you won't have the slightest idea where your opponents are. And the fact you don't get any compensation for failed wonder is so annoying and unrealistic.It just disappears out of thin air often without even any indication why. Previous civs managed wonders better. All in all this could be so much better and less frustrating.
title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: Full disclosure been playing Civ since the very first Civ. Didn't hate on Civ 5 and easily played 800+ hours with each an every version until this one. After playing this for 5 6 hours I finally think I can qualify why I don't like this game. 1. Civ 6 is too slow. Civ games always had a pace to them and for the most part I would get into a rhythm playing them and stuff would just click. Civ 6 on the other hand has two issues. First the turn time taken by the AI is far too long longer even than the too long times of Civ 5. Second the pace of the game is simply too slow. I don't know if there's just too much going on too much to attend to or what but it just doesn't work for me. The individual components (districts/spread out cities new barbians builder) seem to do ok on their own but the combination is what appears to make the game drag.2. Information is pretty much hidden. There's a lot going on under the covers in the game but the game does a terrible job of explaining much of it. The advisor priorities make very little sense much of the time unless there's still a ton of information I need to discover. Thumbing through the Civlopedia is a joke it's thoroughly lacking in good information.The graphics don't really bother me. Maps appear smaller which also helps diminish the grand scale of the game. All in all the game isn't horrid but it sure seems to lack the magic Civ experience so prevalent in previous iterations.Maybe like Civ 5 it'll come into its own in another year or so. One can hope.
title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI
