title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: Overall I enjoy this installment and it offers several new mechanisms that differentiate it from Civ V (my first civ game). The district placement prevents every city form being a Jack of all trades and makes land even more valuable. Restricting movement onto/off of cliffs and requiring the actual movement cost to move onto terrain (i.e. moving on flat ground having one movement point remaining then moving on a hill that requires two is no longer allowed) creates new considerations that need to be made when planning troop movement for battles as well as new options for defending cities. A new diplomatic screen that shows why the AI likes or hates you can be extreamly helpful. Religion and espionage are included in the base game again and not an expansion (although a world congress type organization is still missing). Several other changes also help to change up gameplay but you can read the description to know if they are things that interest you. This does not mean it has no flaws. Far from it. The AI as I m sure you have read in countless other reviews is extremely underwhelming and relies on stat boosts on the highest difficulties to remain competitive. This is not unique to Civ VI but it is a bit more obvious with things like preplanning out the best spot for future districts optimal city placement troop movement that protects more venerable units and better overall placement of units leading up to and during warfare all being things the AI struggles a great deal with. The game also has no way for you to remove districts in cities without razing the city itself to the ground. This can cost a fortune in gold science culture and production in the long run as population directly correlates to the number of districts you are allowed to have. So a city that would be perfect to produce tons of science can t build a campus because the previous owner wanted gold and culture and it doesn t produce enough food on its own to raise the population to unlock the next district in a reasonable time without redirecting countless trade routes. The option to raze a city is only available on the turn you capture it and increases the warmonger penalty. Furthermore even on marathon the game goes by a bit faster than I would like. Some of the reviews I have seen point out that even on Epic speed the eras pass before you can construct units and your army is almost immediately obsolete. This has not been my experience but I generally keep a relatively small force compared to my empire s size through the early stages (exploiting the difficulties the AI has with troop movement and misunderstanding of siege mechanics to save money and build up some infrastructure) and have enough high production cities by the mid game to make it a none issue to create new troops quickly. Those are the primary issues that I still have with the game with most of the other problems being patched out (not being able to create melee units if you researched swordsman with no access to iron balance issues and GUI errors). Some smaller things include builders having a limited number of charges (and the ridiculous amount of time it can take to make one on some speeds compared to the improvements they create) and the penalties for warmongering in the late game (including retaliatory strikes when an enemy half your strength declares war on you and you capture a few of their cities before signing a peace treaty to give you a better buffer zone in the future). I don t believe it s game breaking and I understand the concept (even if Mexico attached the U.S. most of the world would still be mad if the top third of Mexico was annexed as a result). If you play online with friends most of this will not apply to you and the difference form previous incarnations will offer a unique 4X experience.

review: Civ series no matter how many bugs there will be it's always the same always entertainmenting and always the pure gold. I spent already over 300 hours in Civ VI and I must say this series is never too old.Civilization VI took my heart by new engine. It's really different than Civ V or Civ BE. After 2 months I didn't remember a lot of things in Civ V this is how the game changed.Districts. I totally loved districts. Unique districts for some civilizations is also great idea. Wonders are taking tiles cities aren't farms anymore. Now when you are creating a city you need to think a lot. Mountains aren't useless they are providing yields for districts. This might be overpowered but it's beautiful how they used just useless tiles. Amenities and housings totally great solution. River giving extra housing luxuries giving extra amenities. I could talk about new things for hours but we don't have time.Art style completely beautiful. I really enjoyed it. I really enjoyed new animations and the day/night cycle on the map. Strategic view is nice for eye.Technology tree absolutely no problems it's set nice.Civics tree and cards with policies this is great solution. You are discovering parts of the culture and you're not getting every policy one by one you are choosing some of them. You are well limited and also this extra cards for some civs are great.Trading system it's ok and finally it is showing nice and clearly.Buildings/wonders/units Only one thing here wonders are just awesome.AI That's true that AI is a bit weird. Also some civs are overpowered. Really overpowered. The game can't go normal with such strong civs. I think as soon as Workshop will be alive people will improve all civs on their own way. Anyway Barbarians are smarter that's for sure. It's not like in Civ V and the only one bad thing about AI is probably this I sometimes feel like Barbarians and Civilizations changed places Barbarians are like a normal Civs and Civs are like Barbarians. Just noticing.IN TOTAL Gameplay 19/20Graphics 18/20Engine 15/15AI 9/15Diplomacy and Trading 10/10Technologies civics and cities systems 10/10Minor systems (buildings wonders etc.) 10/10TOTAL RATE 91/100 It's great game!DLC upcoming I'll update it later.
title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: After a fair amount of gameplay in Civilization VI I can say I'm thouroghly satisfied.I grew up on the Civ series I remember sitting as a kid watching my dad play Civ III. I've played every part of the series from III forward Civ IV Civ V that awful console launch Civ Revolution and a number of DLC and expansions.Civ VI offers extremely interesting new innovations and ideas to the series that I love personally. To start let me say that this game has increased difficulty I've been used to being able to win game after game of Civ V without thought but Civ VI requires thinking through your plan and strategy. It took me by surprise and still in most games I catch myself in suspense not actually knowing if I will or can win the game I'm playing.The new features in gameplay such as Great People Districts and the Culture tech tree make this lanch an engaging and interesting launch as well as they force gameplay in new and unusual ways. I find the districts idea fun entertaining and simple to understand and as an urban planner myself I love the nod to my profession even if it is subtle and simple. Planning out cities has become much more involved than in previous games encouraging thinking about the future of each settler after you found. Considerng the need for space the cover of borders and the need for district bonuses drives a much more in depth process for determining where to found.Great person competition is extremely useful and much more compelling and has become a very competent and competitive gameplay feature. Each great person has specific bonuses as an individual for example Darwin a great scientist grants 500 science for every tile of a great wonder he is adjacent to while Carl Sagan grants 3 000 production toward a space race victory project and Galileo constructs a university and a library in a campus district. Each person has specific benefits that you may want to compete for with other players by gaining Great Person Points which you get from districts. There are a limited number of great persons which makes it all the more competitive. For example Great Prophets are usually all claimed quickly and only a limited number of religions can be founded because of this.Religion has had a welcome and compelling overhaul being transformed into a mechanic similiar to combat but without war. Missionaries and Apostles debate and duel each other and make the religion gameplay into a possible victory condition. This has made what was an afterthought in previous games to me a key consideration in this game.There are numerous other new changes that I won't bother detailing but the point stands this is a great game. You'll get your moneys worth.
title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: What in the what is deal with the soundtrack? I can't keep my eyes open trying to play this game. If I hear any more of this painfully slow music I'm gonna jump out a window. Holy crap this might be a game breaker for me.Edit Civ 4 level barbarians check. Irrational leaders that all end up hating you check. No leader animations check. Espionage is pointless and needless check. Will you lose a battle where it tells you that you're going to win a major victory check.All that and more as they mash 4 &amp 5 together while everyone calls it the best new cake they've ever taste.Second Edit 30 dollars of DLC that equates to a few new skins. They're taking Paradox's strategy to the extreme. At least they give you gameplay changes.Third Edit I'm a sucker. I broke down and bought the big DLC. Let me put it this way. There is nothing that this game does better than it's predecessors. Can't wait until they throw out the space version of this for an additional 100 dollars. That's it Civ. I've been with you from the start. We done.

review: I've enjoyed every hour I've put into this game so far. The game has some problems and some bugs to be sure but it's still fantastic. For someone who's been playing games from this series since Civ III (with some dabbling in Alpha Centauri and Call to Power) this game is fantastic. It combines some of the mechanics that I loved from previous games that were removed in Civ V while introducing some brand new mechanics that I love as well (such as districts). The UI has some problems at time but in my opnion it isn't game breaking. If you've played more than just Civ V I think you'll love this game. Otherwise it isn't for everyone just yet I suppose.

review: If you look through the honest reviews the only complaints about the game you'll see are about the AI. While the AI is certainly the weak spot of this game AI has never been Civilization's strong suit and people tend to not realize that writing a fair and balanced AI is incredibly difficult (hence why not even mods have been able to fix it in any Civ game.Civ VI has several other minor flaws to be sure but overall it's a very solid Civ game and a vast improvement over V.

review: The best core CIV game I have played and with this recent patch 95% of the issues I had have been resolved. I only hope to see more content and more balance as time goes on. Small note that online multiplayer still tends to be unstable and any desyncs connects or disconnects can cause the game to freeze up and not recover. Play online at your own risk and be prepared to put effort in staying with a group.

review: Please note this review is a citique of the game's payment model and error with AI if you want a legitimate review of the game go elsewhere. But if you want info on the pricing and abosultley horrendous AI I HIGHLY reccomend reading this review.How about you fix the stupid AI and make an expansion pack?Civ 5 release sept 21 2010in the FIRST year we got exactly 12 DLCs. And how many DLCs have we gotten in the first year for 6? 7. That's nearly half the amount of DLCs. And mind you all the Civ 6 DLCs will run you FIVE dollars sometimes up to 10 for dual packs!!! Civ 5? The SINGLE DLC double pack will run you 8 dollars. The rest are either 5 or 3 dollars. Oh wait? 3 dollars for a DLC? Madness that's making it so we get less money.Not only is the DLC for civ 6 slower than 5 it is more expensive and for a far worse product when you count in map size (trust me it is smaller just go on to a random gen map in civ 5 and look at the ocean then go to civ 6 and look at the ocean they might as well make it to that every map has the distance of russia to alaska). Now if the DLC roadmap from 5 has something to go off of we can pobably get an expansion pack this coming year. But the unnamed expansion better have the rework level of a blizzard RTS expansion to make it worthwhile at all as the base game is bland IMO comapared to civ 5.And the AI DONT GET ME STARTED!!! To keep it simple here is a list of scenarios that happened in ONE PLAYTHROUGH Takes away 1 item on your end from a trade AI takes all items off trade and charges you all of your gold income. Take down a civilazation all the AI will think you are a warmonger. 3 Civs declare war then declare war on themselves (Not even ing kidding) and will never send troops to attack you. When you attempt to declare peace they will ask you for gold gems war resources EVERYTHING to declare peace. Then when they ask to declare peace they will give you EVERYTHING they have the NEXT ING TURN. I think you get the point.Get to work Firaxis cause civ 6 is going down the drain (IMO) with the AI and dlc.

review: Sad to say this is probably the last Civ I play after playing them all from Sid's first (after playing civ for 25+ years it maybe time to look elsewhere for something new so I maybe jaded). The new mechanic of districts and builders in my opinion adds little to the game. It does make you plan you cities ahead and reduces the worker spam but in the end it just becomes tedious micromanagement. But the one thing that ruins this game is the subpar AI. It has no idea what it is doing and makes single play boring. If you have a group of friends interested in playing multiplay then go for it but don't buy if you plan to play single player. Hopefully they do some major patching on the AI. I don't mind the change having two research trees and the card system. Sadly I can't recommend this game in the state it was shipped .
title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: Civ6 inherits most elements from BNW and succesfully introduced new concepts and systems to make this franchise more strategically complex and mentally entertaining. New city system Tiles are more precious since each District or wonder occupies one. Terrain and construction on adjacent tiles also lead to bonuses or punishments.Housing affects population growth besides food and amenity. Appeal decides how much housing and tourism a tile could generate. New research system Civic tree is added parallel to originial tech tree with corresponding eras. Advancing in either tree could be advantageous and partially compensates falling behind in the other.Eureka and Inspiration boost progression of a tech or civic once specific condition was met.These changes differ from previous mechanisms in Civ franchise and require much more thoughtful and farsighted layout and priority decisions.Other prominent changes or additions include Religion system expands with religion war and a specific victory type. Cultural victory is reshaped with more tourism sources wonders religion district with religious relic national park and seaside resort on high appeal tiles etc. Government types replace ideologies and unlock with early civics. Adherence to one type brings Legacy Bonuses. Policy Cards resemble Civ5 social policies but can be switched and combined flexibly. City states provide various benefits to suzerains rather than mere yields.Civ6 is visually appealing with bright colors elaborate textures and models decent reflection and shadow effects etc.Day and night cycle and wonder construction replay are new to the franchise as well.The BGM is nice but not as grand as in BNW overall.Just like precedent games the AI still needs improvements as displayed by many ilogical decisions such as choosing settling positions or commanding battles etc.
title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: So. I put over 200+ hours into Civ V across a few accounts before finally giving in and purchasing the next in the series to check out what it had to offer.The way I would describe it is a cleaner simpler to use (In terms of interface and playstyle) game that is well rounded and offers a lot of game time. I'm still currently compelting my first long game (6 hours and about 300 turns in now) and I'm loving it!The game is basically the same game with improved quality and new content to explore (with the only lacking aspect being the maps imo)Get this while it's on the last day of the sale. Even if you have never played the series before this still works as a good entry point to it while also offering more variety for those who have rinsed time in the older versions too!Edit #1 So upon further playtime I have come to the conclusion that I still think the previous Civ V was better than this one simply because of the amount of content put into the DLC's and the way it's layed out isn't so colourful it blows your brain out after a long 6 7 hour session like I sometimes do. But hey it's still a good game with great potential! I reckon I will play a couple more games then wait for more DLC which they hopefully put into a bundle as to encourage more people to buy it as currently I either spend 35 on all of the DLC seperatley or use the 50% off discount to purchase the deluxe edition standalone which is still around the same price also not worth it imo for only around 6 7 more civs and a few more maps. Just wait it out most civ games improve over time with more DLC's!
title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: DO NOT BUY! IT'S INCOMPLETE PRODUCT.I've bought it a week ago. There are three type of problems with this game 1) some things doesn't work as described (bugs?) 2) AI turns take quite long time (6 civs + 6 city states) (Intel i7 4771 ram 32GB Nvidia Titan X 12GB) 3) Sometimes the game hangs during the AI turn. The only option is to kill the game start it again and load a save from 2 3 turn ago and replay them (never managed to reload the last save thus concluding is some kind or bug which can be reproduced but is ignored).Despite above problems if you like to punish yourself with a repetitive reload experience the mechanics and introduced elements are pretty interesting. Although one cannot simple open a view where all districts are clearly shown and their impact on each other is shown. Such functionality seems to be mandatory when introducing such feature. And when you think about it for a moment you realize that a district mechanism is not so cool. I mean if you know the buildings from future it's an easy optimization problem. I guess it's a matter of time when someone will create an extension showing how to design an optimal city.

title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: I am someone who logged a large number of hours on Civ V and I can say that this latest addition to the Civ series is a net improvement to the game. While there are many things that I loved about this game such as the district system I will focus on a few things that I think could use improvement. And though I criticize a few things I still love this game and will continue to log many more hours on it.Firstly the AI is pretty annoying. It feels like they're always denouncing you and starting wars though you the player are the only one who really suffers from warmonger penalties which are a bit too strict in my opinion. Also the AI tend to be unreasonable in their trade requests.Perhaps I am just not good enough at the game but another thing that sometimes bothers me is the housing requirement which if you dont build your city near plenty of water can be quite hard to keep up with. If there were even just a few more buildings that provided housing it would be incredibly helpful. Lastly I would just like to reiterate that I love this game and will be playing it quite a bit and while its not perfect I still believe it to be an excellent addition to the Civ franchise.

title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: Ok so it seems like all the upsides and downsides vary per user so my tip is if you trust the over all steam reviews for this game D O N T. My gripes with this game is i dont like the religion system and the religion victory is pretty stupid when playing single player although i imagine in multiplayer it could be intresting. I also dont like the animated kids movie feeling the style gives me but the art style they give the map and units i do like. And also many people seem to not like the new governing system. See this is the reason i say they vary because unlike what others seem to think i enjoy the district system. Because it feels more sensible because why would you have baracks in the heart of the city when you can have a whole plot of land for milltary things that do those sorts of things. I also like how workers work by a charge system and work instantly. It makes the beggining of the game feel more rewarding and generaly lessens the hassle of them getting stolen back and forth alot. I also like how you can personalize your government more. another thing i like is that trading in this game is less of a hassle and more fun and rewarding. with cities giving different values and build on their own without the help of workers. Over all i dont think it better than 5 but it is different and not worse so in short. Not fantastic but good.

review: Sadly I cannot recommend this game to anyone. While there are some really great features (like the tech and society trees) there are also horrible elements like religious combat that completely take you out of the experience (and the AI that makes diplomacy basically irrelevant). But two things destroy this game so completely that I have absolutely no desire to ever play it again. First the district system which is the bane of any immersion. Sure on a tile based strategy game you cannot expect realistic scaling but the one tile cities of Civ V made you actually feel like building a vast Empire with strategically placed cities and lots of productive countryside and infrastructure between them. Now half of your tiles are cities and there is simply no feeling of distinction. The second great sin is the utterly horrible mind blowingly idiotic art style. I said districts remove the immersion from cities but even worse is that they now have about four buildings and look more appropriate for a mobile game where it's all about min maxing and nobody cares about worldbuilding.In Civilization V I would always enjoy having a long single player game building my empire not to achieve victory but more like a worldbuilding sandbox even to RP a bit I would be immersed in the experience and forget about time. If someone forced me to play Civ VI again I'd probably just click whatever my advisors say and watch a good TV show or a football game on the second monitor.

review: Bought it for $12 on Humble Bundle wish I'd left it alone. Interesting ideas but obviously not much work put into them. Also there are issues in back in Civ 6 that were cleared up in CIv 5. Why do I still start a game surrounded by 80% of the city states with no place to expand no other Civ's near me? All of the casual problems still in the game show how much effort they put in to this game (like changing a worked tile doesn't change the city's displayed growth/production time). Also UI changes end up needing a lot more clicks to manage your empire not very intuitive. With no Civpedia in this addition there are a lot of questions about game mechanics left unanswered exacerbated by not being able to show certain things side by side.

The music art and interaction with the other AI Civs is just great. I've logged 1555 of online hours and and about as many offline. All of my games are diety and the games are incredible on a huge real world map of Civ V a great and challenging game every time. I was extremely excited about Civ VI but was quickly dissapointed. There were plenty of great ideas but it all came down to the basic feel of the game for me. In Civ V you start to actually hate some Civs ( which is awesome ) I want enemies that feel like enemies. Civ VI just made me feel like I was playing against Disney Characters and Deity was far too easy to beat. I'm hoping that Civ VII will be more like a Civ V as far as feel with some of the ideas and tweeks added from CivVI. Until then you'll catch me on Civ V.

review: I've noticed the majority of the reviews are hating on the AI and not liking the art style. While I have to say personally I like the art style I get it isn't for everyone. Especially since it's a lot more cartoony compared to the other games. But I'll start with my thoughts then adress the AI complaints. Pros Districts add a nice micro manage to the game with series benifits when maximized. Ramped up barbs make the early game much better in my opinion The new policy system is much better Tech tree is better Reduction of wonder powers helped with balance in both mid and early game Religion Victory making religion semi viable The art style is nice in my opinion Penalties for going to war The housing system helps keep extreme agression at bay (I've always been more of a tall player anyways so I don't mind the more restricted city building) The seperation of leader and country bonuses is very nice Cons Religion is still pretty much useless. However if 1 player decides to focus on it then others are forced to in order to not lose which is nice Learning curve is much steeper in this game (although this is not a bad thing. It just means newer players are going to struggle more) Penalties for war are very harsh and often shut down the losing member(s) of the war Diplomicy is fairly weak. There's not a world congress however this has been adressed by the devs. They're waiting to see how things develop in the games playerbase to see how they want to gear congress Ramped up barbarians can be extremely punishing if you aren't prepared The housing system is also very limiting (also not a bad thing. However due to the map generations sometimes you end up with terrible cities because you needed a resource that you cant have access to near a mountain river or coastline.)Okay. For the most part I feel those are all pretty straight forward. As for background on me I have a few hundred hours in Civ V and have looked a lot into this game beyond just the 30+ hours I have in it.As for the AI problems. Yes I will agree that the AI is terrible in this game. However the AI was terrible in Beyond Earth and Civ V. Even with all 3 expansions in Civ V the AI is pretty trash. They're pushovers that declare war on you for little to no reason. The AI has never been good. I understand everyone is upset that the AI is bad but it's always been bad. Play this game with friends and you have an entirely different experience. Players will always beat AIs in these kinds of games for enjoyability. Trust me.This game isn't bad by any means. I personally think it's a step up from Civ V especially now that there have been enough updates to bring some of the basic functions back (like city naming queues etc.).Mid game got sped up by quite a lot Late game toned down and Early game is much cleaner in my opinion. Now we don't have 3 or 4 eras of mid game which to some might feel weird but I like the quicker feel of the game.All in all this is still a pretty good game. It isn't quite to level as full expansion Civ V but it's on the path to it. It has a lot of neat features and once you've learned how to utilize them it works out to be a very fun game.
title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

And the game's pace of production reletive to technology is frustrating (though I'm sure the workshop will eventually take care of that). My advice to a propective buyer is to play a game that has better value or just wait about a year to buy a more mature Civ 6 at a more reasonable price.Or just buy the game and enjoy the process.

review: I've been addicted to the Civilization franchise since the first game but this game very much feels like a backward step since IV and V. The graphics are colourful and certain new features such as coastal terrains and active progression are great. However the AI is dreadful the overall balancing for each difficulty level is botched AI forward settle within only one or two tiles because of the new soft border set up barbarians are rampant and progress through technology faster than actual civilizations and resources clearly spawn to encourage expansion. There is no benefit of buildng tall as in Civ V which was a welcome change and there is no downside to warmongering if all of the AI hate you anyway. Even on low difficulties there is no time to breathe and enjoy building because diplomacy is broken. Lastly I sure that this will change with time but the current leader roster is devoid of diversity and the inclusion of countries like Australia and Poland (despite fan popularity) really is a joke when there isn't yet a single South American South East Asian or Polynesian civilization included so far. European and colonial civilizations also have a massive bias against the rest of the world. Allowing both leaders of Greece to play in a single game feels like a cost saving excuse to not provide more content even if you take into account the historic city states.I'm addicted to the franchise and hope that further expansions fix issues here. However I'll only be playing for novelty. I'll be going back to Civ V for my actual Civ fix.
title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: I don't think I have anything to say that hasn't already been said however I'll try to say it in a more concise way. As a long time fan of the Civilization series I cannot recommend this game at this time although I believe this could be the greatest Civ game to date if Firaxis makes the appropriate changes with DLCs.Pros A lot of the game mechanic changes from Civ V are fun and help remove the monotony of earlier versions. Something as small as delegating road building to your trade units instead of having to manually build road on each tile is fantastic. District building adds another level of complexity to the game that is rewarding and wonders are very pleasing to look at now. Happiness is now local and not empire wide which is fantastic. Feels like the player is punished less for wanting to go big.Cons AI. As I believe you will see with most reviews the AI RUINS this game. Part of this is just due to general idiotic AI but then the agenda system really takes it to another level. The developers were either really lazy or really dumb when it comes to this feature what they should have done was exclude random agendas that contradict the civ's historical agenda. Here's an example of what I mean in one of my playthroughs I had impressed another civilization with my large military which was that particular civilization's historical agenda. The civ came to me and gave me compliments. The next turn however the same civ came to me with threats because it just so happened that their random agenda was "paranoid " meaning they also DISLIKED players with big militaries. How could the developers not realize this? It makes the game so stupid which leads to another one of my poitns. Another con is the fact that you can't have any meaningful diplomacy nor does it seem as if you can pursue a less militaristic playstyle. What I really loved about CIv V was the level of strategy added by the world congress. Towards the end of the game it's so fun to enact your Machiavellian desires as you tiptoe around political eggshells to shape the world as you see fit. Although I realize that each game of CIv will require military and combat to some degree Civ 6 seems to predispose you to playing a militaristic game even if it's just due to the paranoia that the AI you're playing with is as devious as HAL from that one famous Stanley Kubrick flick.
title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: Great game until my civilization became 'war weary' during peacetime. Then it kept getting worse. Peace for 100s of years! But my citizens were 'war weary' and thus unhappy and eventually revolting because they kept getting MORE weary of the war that did I mention? DIDN'T EXIST AND HADN'T EXISTED FOR 100s OF YEARS. Game broken. No until they fix this bug. Otherwise it's not much of an improvement on 5. So no even after they fix this bug at this price.
title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: Very different from Civ V but in a refreshing way. Builder charges are a really cool concept and I love the civic system vs the different paths in Civ V. The fog of war map thing is kind of weird but the visible map is beautiful. Districts and tile management spices up the micromanagement side and provides another way to obsess way too much about the optimal choice. Great game so far.
title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: It's funny. I understand the frustrations regarding the current state of this game but it's only been out for six months. Six months into Civilization V Firaxis released six dlcs one was a free civ another was a double civs/scenario and the other four were map packs. The community absolutely hated Civ V for most of the first year it was released. A bunch of talk about how it was more athstetic but lacked AI and content making it inferior to Civ IV in "almost every way" It's still too early to fully appreciate this game. Firaxis seems to be slowly working out the AI through each patch.As they continue to add more civs city states maps and scenarios they'll eventually and hopefully be able to better work out diplomacy war factions and maybe even bigger changes like weather seasons disasters or even historical attributes like plagues world wars or even rebellions and revolutions. I'm not saying that this game is perfect obviously it's not in any way. But understanding how Civ V developed all I have is the highest hopes for the game and patience. I only recommend this game if you're patient and willing to understand the complexity and hard work they're currently putting into Civ VI but if you're looking for a complete game Civilization V is always out there

title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: Civ VI is a beautiful shiny toy that is broken and no fun to play with. I held off reviewing this game to give the developers adequate time to address gameplay and bugs and to see if the DLC would enhance gameplay. After 200 hours I uninstalled the game because it's just frustrating. The AI is hopelessly dumb and only gains advantage by penalizing the player at higher difficulty levels. Movement rules are so restricting that it takes 20 turns to move units to the front. Production is frustratingly slow even for maxed out cities. Religious combat shows promise but since the interface doesn't focus on it you may not even know you're under attack unless you keep very close tabs across a very wide empire. Naval combat pointless. Air combat...I haven't even see the AI build an air unit. Graphic glitches carry over from Civ 5 including dancing units and the obscenely slow process of watching an air unit take off fly to its target then fly back to base. You have to watch catapults reload. Why? Great people have been reworked but appear broken (even focusing on culture I can't produce a great writer or artist). Resource restriction often means you're helpless. Late games are always hopelessly deadlocked. All games evolve in the same way with regardless of civilization. No reason to buy the game in this state.UPDATE This game has now been out more than a year. DLC has so far consisted of nation packs and scenarios that no one cares about. OH WOW I CAN PLAY AS AUSTRALIA???? Big deal. I finally saw the AI build an air unit. It did nothing with it as I attacked. I can now get great writers and artists. UI continues to be infuriating. Unit scrollng worse than worthless. Religion needs major rework. Late game still pointless. Game usually crashes the entire computer on exiting. Three stupid splash screens whenever you start. Needless time sinks when dealing with other leaders. Turns take too long partially because the game is animating things you can't even see. Still no reason to buy the game in this state.UPDATE Last update for this game as the 1st expansion is out. Someone is going to look at my 350 hours in this game and think that I enjoy it. I don't. The early game of exploring and founding cities is fun. After that it is a long and unrewarding slog. The AI is simply stupid both on offense and defense. I've never seen the AI use an aircraft other than to fly around a city. I've never seen the AI build an aircraft carrier. I have seen the AI embark a tank army in waters where they know there are enemy submarines...repeatedly. Being 'denounced' an absolute joke. Game still crashes on exit. The expansion just adds more problems. Firaxis should be ashamed.
title: Sid Meier’s Civilization® VI

review: My ImpressionEverybody probably knows this game by now.But there is way more to it than big balls and little cars and that's what makes it so interesting and worth playing for a long long time. TL DRBeing quick is an essential part of the game so let me give you a fast overview PositiveMediocreNegative+ Fun for beginner intermediate and pro but sometimes very frustrating + Loads of cool mechanics take a lot of time to learn + great car and item variety a lot has to be unboxed traded or bought + Great arena designs some may lag on older systems + Cool and fresh soundtracks some might not like environmental sounds Manual and Automatic Report/Ban features toxic community+ regular huge awesome and free updates The GuideI will put the main part of this review into a steam guide the foremost reason is that there is far too much I want to talk about.To justify making it a guide review I will put a lot of reference to it and go into more detail so I hope you can accept my decision and enjoy it regardless.http //steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id 947564753The VerdictThe game is designed to be pure fun for everybody and it achieves this goal with flying marks.A definite recommendation for just about anyone coming by trust me that you can have fun without investing a ton of time.Just mind that it's a big online game and like any other of the size it attracts trolls plain idiots and other sorts of human scum so do yourself a favor and disable voice and maybe text chat in the options and you are good to go. NoteIf you have read this far thank you.I hope this review helped you in deciding to buy this game and if it did I would be grateful for a 'thumbs up' if you didn't like it you can give me a 'thumbs down' but I would be glad to hear your opinion on what you didn't like.
title: Rocket League®

review: Rocket League is less of a "sports game" and more of an actual sport. In FIFA or Madden you have a "pass" button but to make a pass in Rocket League you have to drive your car into the ball at the right speed and angle to send it over to where your teammate is going. You have to create the pass yourself and it can be anything from a hard bounce off the back wall to a soft lob over the defender. Passing shooting dribbling tackles jukes they're all in the game but you have to make them happen yourself not just press the right button. At first just driving car to ball is a challenge but as your skill grows the freedom to create any play you can imagine and execute is unlike anything you'll find in a "sports game". Together with the mechanical skill to do what you want with the ball you'll have to develop positional awareness and learn proper rotation and game sense. There are very few games that are consistently rewarding for hundreds or thousands of hours that can keep challenging you as you improve and improve and improve beyond what you ever imagined you'd be capable of. In fact this is the ONLY one I know. Best.Game.Ever.
title: Rocket League®

review: When you buy this game it will take about 20 30 hours to actually start hitting balls. By 100 150 hours you'll be flying around the map to score some crazy looking goals (in your opinion). But then that's when the fun actually begins mastering the basic moves of the game is basically mastering 1% of what you can do in this game. You'll end up playing more and more and more until you realize you've just spent three hours in practice hitting the same shot again and again. Yes this game is higly addictive. My favorite game ever without any doubts.

Cross platform+ Much more to experience for yourself!Cons Servers were pretty bad to begin with but that's fixed now tho' so this should not count as a con.Everything else that I would have written as a con is currently being added so I have no complaints about this game at all.''Just one more game'' everyone.
title: Rocket League®

review: Rocket League has one of the best progression systems I've ever seen in a video game before...Rookie You can't hit You are a disgrace to your team and the game.Semi Pro You can now sometimes hit the ball. Don't even try to hit it in the right direction or think about your positioning. You're only Semi Pro so you can just go ahead and hit that ball! You also made a bicycle hit that one time but yeah nah you're still Pro You have learnt how to shoot the ball accurately from the ground. You're the best! Late into Pro level you would have likely looked up advanced tips for Rocket League. Worst mistake of your life. You now know what aerials are. You think you can fly. The ball comes up high and you go for an aerial. Once you jump you fly straight into the ground and continue to do frontflips until you land on your back... What the happened there? Oh. You're using keyboard. Yeah nah time to get a controller head.Veteran You now have a controller and go for terribly unlikely aerials. You think you're good. You can hit the lower aerials consistently and you can now be considered an addition to your team. Congratulations!Expert You can now consistently hit aerials accurately at any height. This game is now your life. You can also score off a wall every now and then. Good times.Master You are now a god to every level lower than you. You have perfected the art of wall shots. You are an extremely cool person. A nice little bonus is that everyone under the level of Pro will now spam "Sorry!" every time they do something wrong to you.Legend The most badass looking title you can have. Rocketeer. You probably now have an extreme case of false confidence. Once you get used to the badass title you'll wreck anything and anyone with ease. You can also pull off freestyles consistently. Nice job! Also be sure to prepare for an endless stream of "You're not good enough for Legend!"Rocketeer You can now 720 freestyle backflip reverse backwards aerial air dribble off a wall with ease. You probably boosted for that Rocketeer tag. But if you didn't still prepare for another endless stream of "You're not good enough for Rocketeer!"But in all seriousness I absolutely love this game and I'm sure anyone will. I've literally never seen someone dislike this game after they've played 10 hours. (Rocket League moves onto a whole nother level of fun and addiction once you learn how to fly.)If you're still contemplating buying this game after reading this review just trust me when I say it is one of the most fun and addictive games I've ever played (more gripping than Skyrim and GTA). Think about it this way You wouldn't have made it this far through the review if you didn't secretly want this game. Ignore the childish looking pictures on the store page. Just get this game. This is the one.EDIT 2/13/2016 You know a game is amazing when the servers go down and you'd rather train offline than play any of your other 100 games... ty for the read

review: Okay let me say this honestly. I'm 1279 hours into this game. I have both learned so much from this game and had the most mentally frustrating moments of my life in this game. It takes true practice... true skill to play this game. No you are not gonna hop on and 5 seconds later you're Rocket Jesus. No. Just no. We all had that dream once. But learn from us you future fools of physics. Listen up you psychotic shadow dwelling PC zombies It was once said "Through sheer will and determination shall we make it through this cruel fate". Yeah well that's Rocket League. If you can put up or shut up take the initiative and learn the movements you can become truly amazing in this game. Not to mention you will laugh up a friggin lung half the time when you get respectful and good natured community.Over all.It's a hell of a gameconnection depends on your rig. review: Excelling in sport means knowing when a moment is outside of your control and recognizing when an opportunity is there to seize. In Rocket League both events occur countless times in any given match not surprising for a game heavily inspired by soccer. It caters to the competitive realist who thrills in having sole control of the ball for a few seconds despite knowing it can be snatched at any time. The best part is that you get to kill opponents' dreams and agonize in your own losses from the comfort of a very very fast car.Every moment in Rocket League demands split second judgment. Are you the assertive type who takes control of the immediate situation at the risk of being in the middle of a chaotic unpredictable scrum? Are you more of a long term planner one who watches your cohorts fight over a ball in a corner with the confidence that the ball will inevitably escape. When this happens are you ready at the top of the penalty arc with the hope that the loose ball will roll between you and the goal? This echoes Wayne Gretzky's words of wisdom "A good hockey player plays where the puck is. A great hockey player plays where the puck is going to be." Rocket League offers countless opportunities to be Gretzky or Nostradamus.Rocket League thrives on speed and momentum. This is best exemplified by the gravity defying excitement of driving up the side of any of the game's arenas. This ability is useful as well as thrilling. Without the curves along the edges of the pitch cars would simply bang into the wall. Constantly having to reverse and make three point turns over a five minute match would be a disappointing series of momentum ending buzzkills. Rocket League has none of these obstacles. The curved corners means you do not lose momentum. Your tires will smoothly caress these bends as you ride the walls horizontally chasing the ball in parallel with rest of the cars on the pitch. Given that the ceiling is also fair game every player will feel compelled to attempt a gravity defying loop across the width of the roof. The game's physics and your limited boost will prevent you from completing such a stunt but you'll attempt it anyway.The ball in play is comparable to that perpetually bouncing beach ball you find at every music festival only slightly less buoyant. It bounces and flies in unpredictable directions when touched by two parties at the same time. This is where fortune favors the Rocket League sportsperson who embraces chaos. Transcendence comes when you realize you don't have to be in control of the ball at all times you should chase it only when you think you can make a difference.A goal scored ends the fleeting yet fulfilled existence of a ball. In its death the ball's life is celebrated with a literal bang. It's a colorful smoke filled explosion that sends all the cars flying away at heights and velocities that would kill any human in real life. It is so spectacular that you can't help but savor the blast even if you weren't on the team that scored. Rocket League is that rare kind of video game sport where you're compelled to play your best even when you're being blown out 5 1 and there's only a minute left on the clock.There's no shortage of advanced ball handling in online multiplayer. In Rocket League experience leads to tactical thinking. Tactical thinking leads to performing with finesse. You cannot open car doors to use them like arms that would be the equivalent of a handball in soccer. Instead you can spin your car forwards backwards and sideways which is analogous to bicycle kicks and headers. Once you learn to use these moves to advance the ball you are soon ricocheting shots on goal. Over time you also discover that your chances of scoring are boosted by hitting the car closest to the ball rather than the ball itself. It's all obvious highlight reel material which is why the replay save option is so welcome. Learning and mastering these advanced moves makes playing Rocket League endlessly absorbing even after you've logged over 50 matches.Playing a single player season in rookie mode is as useful a practice ground as the training mode itself. Without real life competitors ruthlessly charging to the center of the field for the drop ball you can practice making spectacular goals from midfield. The drawback is that imperfect A.I. applies to both teams meaning that your computer controlled squadmates will average at least one incompetent move per match whether it's taking the ball to the far side of your end of the field or blocking your path to the ball.Rocket League's replay value lies in the draw of constant participation not in a progressive system of unlockable advanced abilities or shoehorned novelty modes. All the arenas are uniform and consistent in shape without any bells and whistles like the terraces in its predecessor Supersonic Acrobatic Rocket Powered Battle Cars. The only variables are the team sizes A.I. difficulty and season lengths. This lack of flexibility adds legitimacy to the sport mirroring the steadfast traditions within many professional sports some of which are over a hundred years old.This thoughtfulness extends to the studio's crafting of a convincing world where Rocket League is the number one sport. You see it in the multi tier sold out arenas and you hear it from the indistinct chants of allegiance from the fans. The crowd goes 'Oooohhhh!' or 'Aaaaahh!' whether it's a goal or a key ball hit at midfield. These sprinkles of realism aren't strictly necessary but are greatly appreciated for instance the pitch itself features blades of grass that all move independently. These manicured fields are best admired during the pre match camera shots but you can't be faulted for staring at them in the middle of a game. They are complemented by the myriad customization parts from wildly swinging antenna flags to neon blue engine exhaust trails.The joy of Rocket League rests on the countless plans that are conceived and discarded every other second in any given match. Trying to predict where and how the ball will bounce next is a game within the game. Despite the use of cars Rocket League emulates the emotional surges typical of The Beautiful Game such as the rush of an unexpected fast break or a well timed header into a goal. With Rocket League the promising concept of combining two wonderful things cars and soccer is equally magnificent in execution. You can't say the same thing about say combining cake and fruit to make fruitcake as the comedian Jim Gaffigan observed.

review: Rocket League on the surface is a simple concept but look under the hood and you will find some truly amazing examples of game design. The game can appeal to all players of all ages. Driving a rocket powered car around to hit the ball can be fun and relaxing for a young player or a non serious player but taking the time and effort to do training packs and begin to understand the mechanics is exhilerating and rewarding. The level of complexity this game exhibits is truly amazing considering the simple premise upon which it is based. The skill ceiling is incredibly high yet Rocket League manages to make the game fun and intense the whole way up. Oh and did I forget to say that Rocket League is in my opinion the most e sports ready game despite still having a growing player base. I really have nothing bad to say about the game. The loot crate system is completey cosmetic aside from some cars that are reskins of base game cars and even the DLC cars are nothing special compared to the starter car the "Octane". Although this is great that the starting car is "the best" I would like to see some variance in "viable" competitive cars in the future. But hey if you want to dominate with the scarab then be my guest. 10/10 Masterpiece of competitive multiplayer.

review: Really good game in my opinion. Improvement is rewarded in a satisfying way by you hitting better and better shots. A decent part of the community can be quite toxic but there are also a good lot of friendly people playing the game. Great graphics and smooth gameplay but the game might lag on older systems. Rocket League can be played both casually and competitively. If you play casually you can joke around with some friends and if you play competitively you can steadily see yourself improving if you are willing to put time and effort into it.

review: Rocket League began for me as some random new free game to try out on Playstation Plus. From day one I loved this game (despite servergate). Little did I know what was to come. Through the following years I would love this game and hate this game. I would rage and I would squeel from excitement. Multiple times I claimed I was done but I always came back. The physics are though to learn but if you're patient and remeber to always HAVE FUN you will love this game. Sure the player base can be very toxic seemingly all the time just like every other online game but the few well behaved players you'll find can make up for it all. Rocket League is on my top 5 favorite games of all time and It's taught me so much about gaming and the point of it all. If you do not have Rocket League in your library that is a huge mistake. Just remember to ignore toxicity and play the game for you. Good luck Have fun!!
title: Rocket League®

review: Rocket league is a very thrilling at arcade style game whose objective is to basically play football with rocket powered colourful cars. The idea is very unique and is well implemented. Psyonix has done a great job in transforming a great idea to something truly amazing. The game is best played with friends and with the added cross platform support over all consoles it makes this game even better. The variety of modes like hoops and rumble are refreshing but the classic mode steals the show. 1v1 duel involves pure skill while other 2v2 3v3 and 4v4 require strategic planning and teamplaybut still manages to be a ton of fun. The game is quite approachable to new players and has a skill ceiling high enough to involve competitive players and eSports. I have a ton of fun playing this game and it is an amazing experience which anyone should must try. There is a lot of in game cosmetic and trading in the game which I got pretty hooked up to. The only issue I have encountered so far are the servers in this game which has connectivity issues even though having a good enough internet connection. But none of this ruins my experience of playing the game. Also the gaming community is pretty friendly and cooperative which is again a plus. To wrap this up Psyonix has done a brilliant job in transforming the simple idea of cars playing football to something wonderful and the community is still growing after 3 years and we are still getting new updates in the game. With such growing support there is never been a better time to pick this game up and have lots of fun.
title: Rocket League®

review: There are many addictive and time sinking multiplayer games but few are as fun to play and satisfying as Rocket League.The general theme of car soccer may seem weird and immaturish to many at first glance but upon dwelling deeper into the game you will find a depth of gameplay that is awesome and scary at the same time. The game allows an immense amount of freedom to car control and ball interaction so much that you will spend hours upon hours trying to get better at it . https //www.youtube.com/watch?v wXEp6vEL4pE With intuitive controls and short match lengths (avg. 5mins) the game provides an easy environment for begineers to master the basics. Those basics become the foundation on which you improve your individual skill and advanced gameplay methods through constant practice self learning and analysis. It is a strangely appealing and satisfying feeling when you can notice your own improvements.Even after thousands of matches and many many goals the feeling of zipping through the air and slamming the ball into the goal or flying backwards to stop the ball from going into yours brings joy and happiness. This game will make you feel like a flying god raining judgment upon goal posts.Apart from the standard competitive and casual modes the game also features fun modes like experimental arenas hockey basketball powerup and a dedicated trainer with support included for community made training modules. Rocket League is a testimony to the strength of gameplay design and its one of the most fun multiplayer games in history.
title: Rocket League®

review: I picked this gem up shortly after release. I had no idea there was a predecessor on Playstation 3 Supersonic Acrobatic Rocket Powered Battle Cars. This game is absolutely ridiculous. So ridiculous it has caused me to neglect many other games I have impulsively picked up during Steam sales. This game has been such a problem that I have put in over whopping 400 hours. That is just nuts over 16 days of gaming. In all honesty I love this game. All the various cars you can choose from and all the many possible customization options are dope. This review is way late and the latest update is the Aquadome and crate system. All just awesome. My only gripe is the fact I do not like that the crate keys are about a buck a piece and that you can often get repeat items out of the crates. If there are just a small group of people to play with trading becomes hard and crates build up due to the fact I cannot justify spending money constantly to open items that I will most likely already have. In my honest opinion I believe each key should be about 25 cents with a minimum four pack being a dollar. Just pick it up and play. It is fun. I currently game with an XBone One Elite Controller and use two paddles on the back for ball view and drifting/sliding. Pretty rad.
title: Rocket League®

review: I've recently taken a more serious liking to Rocket League but sometimes it makes me not want to play (rank) due to some game flaws that may or may not be able to be fixed. My biggest issue is Teams vs Randoms I hate getting matched with random guys with random skills and 0 communication and getting slaughter by wack teams. I'm barely moving when I do win vs other randoms but losing to a team and getting demoted a division because of it feels like a punch in the face everytime it happens and if I somehow manage to beat them I don't get extra xp or anything (there isn't any sense of accomplishment). Next is AFK or DC's and rank when it happens and you clearly don't have extreme car control you are doomed and whomever you are against is getting free ranks. you don't get a replacement player you have to deal with the 2v3 or worst 1v3 and still get demoted or drop division for losing. I don't know what they can do about the AFK/DC stuff but it would be real cool if they could force teams to face other teams or premade groups and let us randoms struggle amongst ourselves. I still like the game I just get frustrated with a few things.
title: Rocket League®

review: At the beggining it may seem silly but once you get into competitive play and start watching pros and all kinds of sick plays you will truly see the potential of the game and how competitive it is in high ranks. On video lots of stuff like freestyle air dribbles dribbles ceiling shots do not seem so complicated but when you will try to execute all of those you will realise how much skill it takes. The fact is that everything will come with tons of practice and playing the game and when you will get to land a crazy shot it's going to feel great realising that every moment of practice was worth it. For me Rocket League is the one of the best examples of what E Sports really is and how it should be seen by every person not just a simple video game.

review: It's fun to play as a novice until about the time you hit gold level play then it feels like a grind to get out of the pool of other struggling teammates. Plat is filled with players that cant believe their teammates are ranked that high and will tell you that they would have stopped that ball. Diamond seems to be a nice place where the only time you run into people who are toxic are when someone is doing bronze level cycling. The game is really enjoyable and to notice the changes in your play style and abilities is fun. It's a game that can be played by yourself but can be greatly improved with 1 or 2 friends of similiar skill.7/10 Bronze/Silver 5/10 Gold 8/10 Platinum 9/10 Diamond 10/10 Rumble/Dropshot

The camera sometimes mucks up around the edges of the map. There is many cases of getting stuck in the goals when trying to turn.Turning speed on some cars are dreadful sometimes the follow ball camera sometimes make you seem like you hit the ball but rather you missed it. The boosting creates an unique turn on what happens.The community on most online games are People are chat spamming "Nice Shot" every time someone scores.I can't say much negative things about this game but you don't need cosmetics at all which is good.My final verdict is a high 8/10 I would make it 9/10 if it wasn't for the every so often breaking camera.

review: "Soccer meets driving once again..." I was surprised with the amount of fun I had when I first played Supersonic Acrobatic Rocket Powered Battle Cars on PSN some years ago and Rocket League improves on pretty much everything and it's even better. (plz add metal slug tank on this game lulz.) +Tons of different cars to choose from. (plus there is a lot of DLCs that add even more to it.)+Tons of maps with different themes. +The devs are always updating the game adding more stuff into it and changing some mechanics. +The progression system is waaaay better now. +The performance is ok on low spec PC's. +The report system actually works. +Workshop.+the soundtrack is dope. Matchmaking its a joke. Playing online its fun when you're not on that "lost package" thing. the community is horrible as every other online game. Scammers here are way worse than scammers on TF and CS GO combined. There is no option to add your own custom skin on any car.

review: This game is amazing. I'm hooked to it. The graphics are really good the developers care for the game so useful and good updates are quite frequent in comparison to some games. The game is great as it also has a competitive game mode which can be fun to grind. There are also various game modes you can play that are fun too! You can also play with friends both competitively and casually. The trading system is great and the cosmetic items make the game stand a bit out but this game like many is not perfect.With almost 600 hours at this game I have to say I have met my fair deal of dissapointing and annoying moments. For example the community is not great. In comparison to some games it is alright but overall not something that I can say is good. People are toxic especially in competitive and use different annoying ways to make your experience less fun. There is a good 15% chance you will meet these types of people and if you do then I feel sorry for you as they completely ruin a match experience. There are also quite a few scammers in the trading community but with lots of trading experience this can easily be avoided if you have an IQ that is higher than 30. And finally the servers. I need to stress that the servers are quite bad. Firstly if you live in the middle of the USA chances are you will get a lot of lag as there are NO US Central servers. Secondly the odd 'bad' server in the game because the servers are sometimes poor makes playing the game seriously more difficult and less fun. Finally these slightly goes against my point about useful updates but the game developers of RL Psyonix release crates with cosmetics for your cars TOO OFTEN instead they could add more game modes or updates to fix the issues mentioned above! This game also suffers from repetetitivity so if you get depressed from doing the same thing I don't recommend this game.Even though I wrote more disadvantages than advantages I still love this game. With the toxic community scammers and bad servers the game has much more to give than make you hate it. Please if you like football/soccar cars and games that aren't P2W I seriously recommend trying this game out. Preferbly when its on a dsicounted offer you will save a bit of your money.Please thumbs up my review it helps me out!Thanks for reading this far!Delta...
title: Rocket League®

review: A really good game to pass the time. I've always played casually and its matchmaking is almost perfect in the sense that it matches you with people who are (roughly) on your level. That way you don't feel overwhelmed during your "noob" period. Psyonix has also been adding tons of new content for free since the game came out. There is usually a tournament or a championship going on if you're serious about the game.There are also microtransactions and DLCs but every single one of them is purely cosmetic. There is absolutely no pay to win here.The servers are quite good. I've never had serious lag and even if you have lag it usually goes away quickly.I've always played the game with an Xbox controller and it feels very natural and you get used to the controls very easily. I can't say how smooth the gameplay is with a keyboard and mouse though.All in all an awesome game that is as casual or hardcore as you want it to be. Definitely recommended!
title: Rocket League®

review: Rocket League is an awesome game that many don't know until they try it. It is very competitive and still remains fun to play. You spend the first few hundred hours managing your steering on the ground. Then you start hitting the ball while flying through the air. Then you go back to trying to master the ground more by using fakes and juggles to your advantage. This is the type of game that doesn't take long to learn how to play but takes a lifetime to master it. Personally I'm not really into sport type games but I think I can honestly say that this game hits the nail in between the sports and pure arcade fun. I'd even pay full price if I had to get it again as it is totally worth it. )

review: My ImpressionEverybody probably knows this game by now.But there is way more to it than big balls and little cars and that's what makes it so interesting and worth playing for a long long time.TL DRBeing quick is an essential part of the game so let me give you a fast overview Positive Mediocre Negative+ Fun for beginner intermediate and pro but sometimes very frustrating + Loads of cool mechanics take a lot of time to learn + great car and item variety a lot has to be unboxed traded or bought + Great arena designs some may lag on older systems + Cool and fresh soundtracks some might not like environmental sounds Manual and Automatic Report/Ban features toxic community+ regular huge awesome and free updates The GuideI will put the main part of this review into a steam guide the foremost reason is that there is far too much I want to talk about.To justify making it a guide review I will put a lot of reference to it and go into more detail so I hope you can accept my decision and enjoy it regardless.Start your Engine! Una guida per Rocket LeagueDi BashThis Guide is part of my Steam Review for the game however fear not you will find a lot of information in here. My main focus lies on the mechanics of the game nonetheless I will also tell you about the basics ...The VerdictThe game is designed to be pure fun for everybody and it achieves this goal with flying marks.A definite recommendation for just about anyone coming by trust me that you can have fun without investing a ton of time.Just mind that it's a big online game and like any other of the size it attracts trolls plain idiots and other sorts of human scum so do you a favor and disable voice and maybe text chat in the options and you are good to go.Note If you have read this far thank you.I hope this review helped you in deciding to buy this game and if it did I would be grateful for a 'thumbs up' if you didn't like it you can give me a 'thumbs down' but I would be glad to hear your opinion on what you didn't like.

review: Rocket League is a bit like marmite You either love it or hate it.A good time waster and fun to play with friends but be aware The community is VERY toxic. Often team mates will turn against each other if a mistake is made be it a bad pass miss or even an unlucky own goal. It s even worse in ranked matches as a lot of people take it for a lot more than it actually is (a game) leading to an onslaught of abuse through the text chat system and numerous reports of complaints against users just because the option is there.Personally I enjoy the game but I usually only play with friends and hardly ever on my own. Sometimes you encounter players that are far more skilled than you (of which you will have no chance) and this is down to the flaws in the matchmaking. It s not simply pairing you with better players to increase your skill as quite often you will be faced against people with over 2000 hours in game (I have around 300 hours at time of writing).Overall its a great game to play with friends and a lot of fun. It s difficult to resist buying keys to open crates (for which you gain additional customisation items that are purely cosmetic). Just try to ignore the toxic community.
title: Rocket League®

review: This review is for KBM players and not controller players This is a Great game thats very enjoyable but the PC controls are a mess and they have no sense of urgency to make the KBM controls much better So If you like using a Mouse to Steer or to pitch in the air than this game some how ruined what other PC games have mastered with precision driving and pilot steering Most of your vehicle control will be from your keyboard and it will be based off press holding time for how quickly you accelerate pitching or steering which is controllable in settings but never feels like the free range movement you get from a joystick The mouse control is too stiff and acts more like Left to right button instead of raw free movement. I have heard babies on these fourms say some games just play better on a controller But this is only beacuse the devs wont make rocket league have 100% mouse steering control and they added crazy acceleration and deadzone resets to a mouse which is 100% dumb Besides my rant it is worth the buy if you prefer controllers or dealing with keyboard controls w/out mouse steering I assume a small precentage complained about it which makes sense since most players i know prefer controllers and there population is mostly console.

review: I've logged about 12 hours in this game so far and here is my critique The good This game's physics reflect what kind of game this is A game with rockets strapped to the back of cars. It makes the movements easier and the vehicles easier to control within the environment The customization is superb with more items that can be used to customize your vehicle earned through each match and The selection of game modes is a reflection of all that can be done in the game! Not to mention the steam workshop games that can be downloaded as well )The bad My only real complaint is that connections can sometimes be shoddy (#servergate) however that is a fact with most online oriented gameplay (that I've experienced anyways). As well the online matches can be unbalanced at times whether in your favour or against. You always have to be on your A game (which is what I like personally).Overall This game is definitely worth its weight in gold! I enjoy every minute of gameplay (even if I'm pounding my fists on my desk in frustration... ) Its comuppances outweigh the shortfalls by a longshot and the game is definitely worth playing even if that's just with a friend or competitively.

review: I wish I could review neutral. Though Rocket league is fun and hard to learn at first. I can see myself enjoying it. However my issue has become with toxicity. This may be a childish complaint but I feel the community makes the game. And with that said when the people you are playing against do nothing but spit at you and insult you and not just around and place nice but instead play like its life or death then proceed to spam you with "Great job!" when they score on you. That just ruins the mood. Its hard to have fun when playing against people you dont know when those people are complete assh*les. Again its hard to learn and fun to play. If you are new you are going to be insulted by complete c*nts. The same applies if you are experianced. If you arent playing competitivly and just trying to enjoy the game for what it is. You will be insulted for everything you do. Then again I havent played this game recently in defense. And I only have 24 hours. But I still feel thats enough to know the community. Most my matches when I still played were full of people being rude c*nts and really sweating their off to win even though its just a casual match. I think people who act like this ruin games. When they have to go to casual to inflate their ego. Its pathetic. Aside from the community this game has lootboxes and car DLC something I was 100% unaware of when I bought it. most this stuff is cosmetic and doesnt change things one bit. I think the cars may change some things. but thats it. You can put hats on your car more stuff like that.I havent played in so long all I have to say is all and all. Its worth it if you can tolerate cocky little kikes.

review: A shining example of a small studio with a sleeper hit going the big boys path to money grabbing by all means necessary. It is a shame that in a few decades the gaming industry went from free skins to micro transactions to changing money for the possibility to give you the thing that you want. It is only visual may apply for the most decals rims and so on but they are aimed at making you pay in order to also have such nice goal explosion animated body paint flashy rims etc. Then we have all the new cars which look and feel different. Whit Psyonix not bothering to show any actual hit boxes or official stats only blind trust holds their statement of not selling power .The new season pass creates a nice new twist. You buy a pass and they have to play matches in order to unlock items from the season s item list. Therefore you ought to both pay and play hours in order to obtain the locked items. At least you know beforehand which items to expect. However if you do not buy the pass you can still play hours and unlock something. Yes this something is among the most boring uninspired items nobody would care/pay for if there were micro transactions.On a technical note the servers in Europe (Sept 2018) are ok. There are occasional WTF moments when the you could sworn you are about to hit the ball only to see it fly by or to pause midair in a momentary physics/server panic or to have lag spikes and Saudi players with three digit pings in competitive games but this is Rocket League. Forget matchmaking issues. The server issues persist through the years but that is ok. We are here to sell loot boxes and do cross platform marketing. Come buy the new Hot Wheels DLC!

review: At a first glance this game seems to promote all men's fantasies while they sculpt their best shape of a couch potato. We're dealing with a football game starring big good looking vehicles and in which the best way to boast is car tuning. Let's not mention the fact that this testosteroned environment like the Call of Duty franchise is fulfilled with 12 15 years old players wanting to show that they don't need a driving license to be cool.But when you set this aside and fully play the game for what it is and not what it looks like you find a balanced competitive and entertaining action game. You will need lots and lots of playtime maybe some practice and trial and error sessions if you want to improve but in the end the more you play the more you enjoy the game. You come for the entertainment and you stay to master the tool between your hands.The competitive modes are in my opinion the soul of the game. The rank system gives a lot of motivation to climb without any upper rank seeming out of reach. With the casual modes only I don't think I would have trained and played this game that much far from it.Don't play this game if you know you're a tryharder and do not have that much time to play.Don't play this game if you expect to make ceiling shots with a keyboard and a mouse.Otherwise don't even think twice before putting that game in your cart. One of the biggest (even though not the most friendly) Steam communities awaits behind this game and playing a few matches will show you why they are still here !

review: First of all this is one of those games you can just jump in and enjoy. It's unique the physics are wonky but predictable and the entire game play experience is great. If you wanted to hear the good then stop reading here because crap takes a turn for the worse in this game quickly.That being said the actual players make this game almost unplayable. Hop in a random match with cross platform play enabled and you get stuck with a team of PS4 players who can't play the game you lose miserably and learn nothing as you scramble to fix their mistakes. PS4 players get the game free with their PS membership so you have a lot of new players all the time hopping on and the teams are horrible when cross platform play is enabled. Hop in a game without cross platform play and you find groups of players who would rather trash talk then play the game let alone help your team. Just today I watched a team mate finish a goal and then watched another team mate refuse to play the rest of the match while continuously trash talking both me and his other team mate. It's hard to want to play a game where that's common and it's common. Hop on competitive first error a team mate or yourself make and you can watch at least one team mate leave the game immediately.Too be clear I want to love this game. I like sports games. I like racing games. I like PvP but Rocket League is broken. I know they're trying to fix it. I know they put bans in place and they brag about their automatic ban system but the community is still the community and it's horrible. It's worse than CS GO and that takes a lot of effort from a large group of players to be that bad.
title: Rocket League®
